titleStmt.title: Microbiblion or The Bibles epitome: in verse Digested according to the alphabet, that the Scriptures we reade may more happily be remembred, and things forgotten more easily recalled. By Simon Wastell somtimes of Queenes Colledge in Oxford.
titleStmt.author: Wastell, Simon, d. 1632.
Wastell, Simon, d. 1632. True Christians daily delight. aut
Shaw, John, 1559-1625. Biblii summula.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by Miles Flesher] for Robert Mylbourne, and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the Greyhound in Paules Churchyard,

notesStmt.note: Based on: Shaw, John. Biblii summula.

The paraphrase of the Old Testament is a different, longer text from that in Wastell's "A true Christians daily delight"; first line of Genesis is "At first Iehovah with his word,". The New Testament text is unchanged.
"A true Christians daily delight" has separate title page; register and pagination are continuous.
With four final leaves of verse.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: MICROBIBLION OR THE BIBLES EPITOME: In Verſe.
Digeſted according to the Alphabet, that the Scriptures we reade may more happily be remembred, and things forgotten more eaſily recalled.
By Simon Waſtell ſometimes of Queenes Colledge in Oxford.

q.l: A good Diuine hee's counted ſtill,
In Scripture text that hath good skill.

p.hi: Bleſſed is he that delighteth and meditateth in the law of God day and night.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Robert Mylbourne, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the ſigne of the Greyhound in Paules Churchyard. 1629.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT Honorable his ſingular good Lord, Sir William Spencer Knight, Baron Spencer of Wormeleighton, and to his Honorable Lady: Simon Waſtell wiſheth encreaſe of honour in this life, and eternall happineſs in the world to come.
div.p:
RIght Honorable; Excellent is that ſentence which Agapetus wrote to Iuſtinian the Emperour long agoe, viz It is the crowne of Fi •• ie which adornes a Potentate; for riches 〈◊〉 with vs, and glory vaniſheth (ſaith hee)
〈◊〉 that renowne, but that care of leading 〈◊〉 liues according to Gods will, hath the promiſe of a Reward euerlaſtingly permanent, and of a Crowne immarceſſible. And ſuch hath
beene Gods mercy to your Honours, that he hath accumulated both internall and externall bleſſings vpon you, adding to your temporall greatneſs, ſpirituall graces, which make your Honors far more amiable in Gods ſight, then any terrene (though tranſcendent) felicitie can make you admired in the ſight of men. The very Ethnicke could ſay, Nobilitas ſola eſt at
que vnica virtus. If the glimmering light of their purblind intellectualls, could appropriate ſuch like Panegy rickes, onely to their Morall and Socraticall vertues, how great are thoſe prayſes which are due to thoſe Theologicall and heauenly graces, which by a more diuine Spirit, are breathed into the ſoules of Dauids Saints on earth: Wherein though your Honors endowments haue not the meaneſt portion (they not being in you, meane, but euen Heroicall,) yet leſt I ſhould ſeeme (as the manner of ſome Dedicatory Epiſtle is) to make my way to your Honour by a Paraſiticall ſalutation of all your reſplendent vertues in my paſſage, and leſt I do therein offend your right Noble and magnanimous diſpoſition, whoſe property it is not to be very much affected
with thoſe your deſerued praiſes; and becauſe alſo the action in mee would bee cozen-German to baſe flat • erie: I therefore paſſe them by in ſilence, whereat my mind ſhall neuer ceaſe to afford the due tribute of perpetuall admiration. May it therefore pleaſe your Honor (as formerly it pleaſed your worthy Father my good Lord, now deceaſed) to patronize this little worke, which with all ſubmiſſion I preſent vnto your Honours. Sure I am, that thoſe manifold fauours which I (vnworthy I) from time to time haue receiued from him and you, may challenge requitall; which to be performed by mee is impoſſible, and to be teſtified by ſo ſmall and ſlender a Dedication is in a manner indecent, as being in no waies proportionable to your large and copious demerits. But I am ſomewhat incouraged to make it trauell vnder your Honours Patronage. I know that in all ingenuous and heauenly begotten ſoules, there is an affection in ſome ſort analogical to God himſelfe, of accepting the deſire for the deed▪ Receiue it therefore I beſeech you, it is performed as I could, not as I would; 〈◊〉 your Honour looke to the matter of that
booke, it is an Epitome of Gods Oracles, and containes ſome of that aqua coeleſtis, or liuing waters of life and grace: If to the manner of handling the matter, it is briefe, and Alphabeticall, and metricall, for the better and ſurer memorie. Plaine alſo it is becauſe the pure and ſpirituall word needs not the mixture of mans depraued braine; and alſo becauſe the ſimpleſt Chriſtian may reape the greater benefit, when all things are done to edification. Thus preſuming vpon your Honorable protection, & intreating the Almightie, that in bleſſing hee would bleſſe both your Honors, and honorable Progeny, I humbly take my leaue.

closer.signed: Your Honors euer to be commanded, SIMON WASTALL

div.head: To the Chriſtian READER.
div.p:
IT is the ſpeech of all, almoſt, and the complait of the moſt ſincere, that theſe our laſt and worſt dayes, are dayes very wicked, dayes very dangerous, and therfore ſurely very dangerous, becauſe very wicked; yet if we looke to the meanes of knowledge and of piety, neuer time enioyed larger, or better: Great is Gods mercy, ſmall our amendment. And where's the fault? why our owne conſciences doe condemne vs, as delinquents, who will not receiue that which Gods mercy would afford vs. Chriſt may now take vp his Elegies againſt England, as once againſt Ieruſalem, How often O England, England, would I haue gathered thee as a henne gathereth her chickens vnder her wings, but thou wouldſt not. I haue ſent my Ambaſſadors to declare my good will and pleaſure to thee, and my loue which I reſerue for thy people, if ye would returne,
but thou wouldſt not. I haue often knockt at the doore of thy heart for entrance, that thou mighteſt bee enriched with my Spirit, but thou wouldſt not. I haue offred thee, that, aske and thou ſhalt haue, knocke, and I will open vnto thee, but thou wouldſt not. I haue exhorted thee to crucifie thoſe carnall luſts, which fight againſt thy ſoule, but thou wouldeſt not. I haue beene crucified, dead, and buried, that by beleeuing in mee thou mighteſt haue life, but thou woldeſt not. I haue aſcended from death to life, that by my example thou mightſt riſe from the death of ſin to the life of grace here, and to glory hereafter, but for all this thou wouldſt not. Theſe or ſuch like words might Chriſt iuſtly vſe to the moſt part of the men of England, whoſe ignorāce is almoſt groſſe & affected, and whoſe knowledge (except it bee practiſed) will but augment their condemnation: for this is condemnation, that the light is come into the world amongst vs, and wee loue darkeneſſe more then light. We know indeed our Maſters will, but will not do it. Or if we haue but ſo much of the gold of the Sanctuary as wil tip our tongues, & guild ouer our externall cariage, we thinke we haue enough; whereas the heart was requiſite in euery ſacrifice, and that being firſt formed,
and giuen vs of God firſt, ſhould be reformed firſt and giuen of vs to God againe. But alas, moſt men now content themſelues to liue in this our Church which hates Idolatry, and popiſh ſuperſtition, and thinke this will bee ſufficient to flit them to heauen after death whereas (poore ſoules) they ought as well to looke to the truth of their profeſſion, as to their profeſſion of the truth, leſt he, who is the Way, the Truth & the Life, do for their want of truth, deny them the way to euerlaſting life. But if theſe men, or any other, would in ſinceritie, ſee footing into the wayes of Gods commands, it is then neceſſary, neceſſitate á priori, that they firſt know what it is which God cōmands: now this is reuealed vnto vs in his word, and his word muſt be a light to our feet, and a lanterne to our pathes, wee muſt talke of this when wee riſe vp, and when we lye downe, and meditate therein day and night, which that we may doe, we muſt labour (Chriſtian Reader) to get it into our memories: and to this purpoſe, at alſo for a direction to our whole life, is this little Breuiary of the holy Scripture compoſed into this forme, which if it profit, let all the praiſe be giuen to him, who is the Author of euery good and perfect worke. Now if any yet deſire to be more curious in prying into the
ſtrictneſſe of the Chronologie, I referre ſuch to Herlinus, Gemma Fabri, Funccius, Beroaldus, Broughton, Pantaleō, Schubertus, Cariom, Lodowick LLoyd, Bucholcerus, and others that haue profeſſedly vndertaken that taske: As for the Graecian computation by Olympiads, and the Caldean, Aſſyrian, Egyptian and Perſian Chronologers, let them agree with them no further then they agree with the holy writ which was 2000. yeares before any of them. Thus intreating thy charitable cenſure, well-wiſhing, and prayers, I bid thee farewell, reſting

closer.signed: Thine in any Chriſtian ſeruice that he can performe, S. W.

lg.l: TO keepe vs blameleſſe what excuſe haue we
If ignorant in Gods Commands we be?
Since to informe vs, what his pleaſure is,
So many helpes we haue that others miſſe:
And are not now compelled to goe ſeeke
The hard phraz'd Hebrew, nor the copious Greeke,
For, God ſpeakes Engliſh to vs; and aſſayes
To worke true knowledge in vs diuers wayes.
Some men interpret, ſome againe expound:
And this our Author here, a meanes hath found
To helpe the Memorie: And not in vaine
If others adde endeauor to his paine.
Peruſe it Reader. And ſo mindfull be
Of that, whereof this Booke remembers thee;
That others in thy life, may copyed finde,
What thou art hereby taught to beare in minde.

div.head: The names of all the Bookes of the Bible, as they follow in order.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AT firſt Iehovah with his word,
did make heauen , earth and light:
The firmament, the moone, and ſtarres,
BY him, the earth was fruitfull made
He maketh man like to himſelfe,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: Plants Eden , and the fruit forbids,
DVſt of the ground, was man made of:
of rib out of his ſide

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: EVe by the ſerpent is deceiued,
God them arraignes, doth ſerpent curſe,
FOule Serpent twixt and womans ſeed,
Their firſt cloathing, their caſting out,
The Lord at them did frowne.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: GIuen are to Adam here two ſonnes;
Their trade, and their religion ſee,
HEre Caine is curſt, firſt citie built,
Here Sheth and Enoch both are borne,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: IN his likeneſſe, male and female,
Then Adam in his owne likeneſſe
KNow here the pedigree, age and death
From Adam to the daies of Noe,
how Enoch An. Mundi 987 is tranſlated.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: And fearfull flood to drowne the world,
but Noe is ſafe and ſure.
MArke all the order of the Arke,
All that the Lord did bid him doe,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NOe An. Mundi 1656 with his family: and paires,
The floods doe flow: God ſhuts them in,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: The Doue, and Rauens ſending forth,
will curſe the earth no more.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: QVite freed from feare, God bleſſeth Noe
mans feare; the meat, the bow:
by Noe the world doth grow.
REad how Noe doth a Vineyard plant,
He curſeth Cham, for Iaphet prayes;

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: SEe here of Noe, and of his ſonnes

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: THe world one language had at firſt

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: VP Abram An. Mundi 2023 and thy Country leaue;
Dearth makes him fly, feare makes him faine,
and ſay ſhee's not my wife:
A Plague on Pharoh, and his houſe
the Lord did ſend that day
For Abrahams wife: the King reproues,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: BOth Lot and he richly returne,
Lots lot is ſinfull Sodomes ſoile,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: COnquered are fiue Kings by foure,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: But firſt his ſeed muſt ſeruants be,
EVen by his faith hee's iuſtified:
And by a figne confirmes the Land,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: FOr iſſue Sara giues her maide,
GReiuing full ſore, the Angell cheeres,
a fierce man and a wilde.

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: their names are chang'd, they bleſt,
Abraham here is An. Mundi 2440 circumciſed

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: At Gods ſtrange promiſe, Sara laughes
and is checkt for her paines.
KNowing that Abraham his would teach,
The fall of Sodom; Abraham praies,
for ten iuſt men to ſpare.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: Lots ſonnes doe mocke, he Zoar craues,
MAke haſt (ſaith th'Angell) ſaue thy life,
Lots wife a pillar of ſalt is made,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: The Lord reproues him in a dreame
full ſore for that ſame thing.
OF him , both man and wife's reprou'd;
The King then and his houſe are heal'd

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: PAſſing great ioy good Sara hath,

for Iſaac An. Mundi
• 0 • 0 newly borne.
at him doth ſcoffe and ſcorne.
QVite out of doores Hagar and he,
a League of peace is ſworne.

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: REad here how Abraham tempted is
his Iſaac An. Mundi 2061 deare to kill,
His faith, and how he ready is
STayd is his hand by Gods Angell;
The place is nam'd : marke Nahors race,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: THe mournings marke which Abraham makes
for death of Sara An. Mundi 2085 old:

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: VNt' Abram here his ſeruant ſweares,
he prayes: a ſigne doth craue;
Rebecka meets: An. Mundi 2088. fulfills the ſigne,
ANd then ſhe ſhewes her kindred deare,

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: His age, his death, his buriall;
DEclared is his age, and death,
But Iſaac praies, and ſhe conceiues,
for meat An. Mundi 2113 prophanely ſells.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: FOrc'd by a famine Iſaac is
His wife he to the King denyes,
GOd both inſtructs, and bleſſeth him,
in wealth he growes and thriues,
He diggeth wells: the King compacts;

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: HE ſend; his ſonne for Veniſon;
And of his father then is bleſt
ISaac doth feare and tremble much
Too late; An. Mundi 2140 yet by his earneſtneſſe
KIndled full ſore is Eſaus wrath
and bids him flye for feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: To Padan Aram for a wife,
MArke Eſaus wife, and Iacobs ladder;
And ſets it vp, anoints with oyle,
a vow to God he makes.

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: NOW Iacob comes to Harans well:
hee's ſet to keepe his ſheepe.
OF him, for ſeuen yeares ſeruice, he
in her ſtead An. Mundi 2185 Lea gaue.

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: So Leah, who her husband buyes:

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: Iacob departing An. Mundi 2205. with his wiues,
THen Rahel ſteales her fathers gods,
both by his ſonne and daughter.

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: AT Ma • h • nim Iacob Angells ſee's:
Whom he doth feare: he prayes to God
BY ſeruants he a preſent ſend • :
Doth vſe him kindly , home returnes

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: Of Hamois children, where he doth

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: ENtiſing Sechem An. Mundi 2213 doth defloure
Doe kill them all, their City ſpoile

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: From Idols all, an Altar An. Mundi 2228 builds,
HEe's bleſſ'd of God, call'd Iſrael:
The ſonnes of Iacob: Iſaacs death:

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: With wiues, and ſonnes: mules are firſt found:

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: for two dreames which he had,
And for complaints of brothers made,
LEt vs this dreamer ſtay (ſay they)
To viſit them) to murther him,

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: NOw Iud • h doth three ſonnes beget,

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: OF Iuda An. Mundi 2222 ſhe conceiues two ſonnes,
He wiſht her burnt; ſhe ſends her pledge;
he cleares her to his ſhame.

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: He flat denyes; ſhe falſly lyes;
QVite void of grace him to accuſe
She is beleeu'd, hees caſt An. Mundi 2227 in ward,
but God is with him there.

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: REad how the Buttler and Baker
How Ioſeph hath the charge of them,
Haue me in mind, O Baker marke,
and thus they came to paſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: VNto the King is Ioſeph brought
The Butler had him told that he
ALl wizards failing in their skill,
And giues the King moſt graue aduice,

BY Pharoh
• Ioſeph is An. Mundi 2236 aduanc't

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: COrne for to buy in Egypt land,
his ten ſonnes An. Mundi 2238 Iacob ſent,
DOe this (ſaith Ioſeph) and you ſhall
Your brother Ben: (you told me of)
goe all ſaue one and fet.
Euen then they haue remorſe in heart
God plagues vs iuſtly for our ſinne,
FOr pledge, is Simeon kept in ward
with corne they home doe goe,
Tell all to Iacob who will ſtay
his Ben: he loues him ſo.

lg.head: Chapt. 43
lg.l: GOe buy ſome food (good Iacob ſaith)
the ſonnes they durſt not goe
HE very loth yet ſends his ſonne,

lg.head: Chapt. 44
lg.l: Should both in their ſackes mouth be put,
with them backe to be borne.
KNow that in ſacke of yongeſt ſonne
Which, found, they feare the fathers pledge,
for Ben: would now be ſtayd.

lg.head: Chapt. 45
lg.l: LOe now doth Ioſeph make himſelfe
and bids them not to feare.
and bid him come to me,
For him, and his, I will prouide:
NOw when the King of this did heare,
OH how they kiſſe, and weepe for ioy,
When Iacob heares this ioyfull newes,
An. Mundi 2240. a ioyfull man is he.

lg.head: Chapt. 46
lg.l: PAſſing great comfort from the Lord
Thence he and his to Egypt goe
with all things to their minds.
He tells his brethren what to ſay

lg.head: Chapt. 47
lg.l: REporting that his friends were come,
With his father before the King,
SEe here how Ioſeph gets the coine,
All that the Egyptians did poſſeſſe,
THe Prieſts land was not bought nor ſold:
he maketh An. Mundi 2255. Ioſeph ſweare.

lg.head: Chapt. 48
lg.l: he comes and ſons doth bring:
And ſaid, I will thee multiply
and make thy ſeed as land.
BEhold Manaſca An. Mundi 2280. and Ephraim
as his owne ſonnes he takes,
Of mothers graue, of their returne,

lg.head: Chapt. 49
lg.l: CAlling his ſonnes, in bleſſing them
He chargeth where to burie him,

lg.head: Chapt. 50
lg.l: Who weepes, and bids he ſhould be balm'd,
He will maintaine both them and theirs
GReat age he liu'd, and of his ſonnes
He makes them ſweare An. Mundi 2310 his bones to beare,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l:
Though new
• King Pharoh them oppreſt
BInding the midwifes that in birth
But they fear'd God, and did refuſe,
then brookes with babes were fill'd.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: Kings daughter finds him, ſeekes a nurſe,
DEliuered then to Court he was:
At Hebrues checke, he fled, and wod:

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: EVen as he kept his fathers ſheep,
he ſees a buſh on fire:
God was therein, and Moſes fear'd,
FRom Pharohs curſt and cruell bonds,
Tell them I AM hath charged thee,
to free them from that King.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: GOe doe theſe wonders: Moſes rod
His hand is leprous; loath he is
HIm Aaron meets, and muſt aſſiſt:

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: The peoples taske he doth increaſe,
for plaints he doth not care;
LOud cry their officers to the King,
And Moſes; then he to the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NOw Moſes old, to Pharoh goes

So wizards
• doe: the brookes are blood,
his heart God hard doth make.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: O Moſes pray frogs, flyes, and lice,
but will not let them goe.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: PLagu'd are the beaſts, with murraine much,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: QVite is the land with Locuſts fill'd:
And he ſomewhat inclines to let
REpent he ſeemes: he prayes them pray
Darkneſſe is ſent, hee's call'd againe,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: SEe now hee'll thruſt you out require
Egyptians cry, his owne are ſafe

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: THis moneth, tenth day, kill paſchall lambe
Beſp • inkle poſts: firſt borne are ſlaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: ALl the firſt borne ; vnleauened bread
BOrne are good Ioſephs bones from thence,
God guides them in the day by cloud
and in the night by flame.
God tells his people what to doe
and what way they ſhould take.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: DIſtreſt with feare they murmure , but
They paſſe the Sea vpon dry ground;

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: EVery one ſung prayſe to God,
The people grudge , twelue wells are found

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: FRom God are quailes and Manna ſent,
which vs'd not right doth rot:
None could be found on ſabbath day:

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: him ſtrike the rocke with rod:

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: HIs wife and ſonnes old; Iethro brings,
Giues Moſes counſell how to rule,
which done, he goes his wayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: I brought you forth with wonders.
They promiſe; muſt not touch the mount,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: KNow, here the ten Commandemēts giuen
they will'd are not to feare,
Nor any Gods to haue but him,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: LEarne lawes for ſeruants, and for them,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: MArke theft forbid, no damage doe,
For borrowing, oxe, ſheepe or ought;
NO witch nor beſtiall man ſhall liue,
O Keepe not poore mans rayment, layd
as pledge with thee, all night:
firſt fruits pay me of right.

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: PVt farre away a ſlanderous tongue
Be iuſt to all ; loue charity:
let land the ſeuenth yeare reſt;
See what to doe with blood, and fat,
REpay firſt fruits vnto thy God:
Whom if thou ſerue, he will thee bleſſe,
SEe that thou bow not to falſe Gods,
Feare God, and ſickneſſe hee'l remoue

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: TO'th Mount goe ſeuenty Elders call'd;
He ſprinkles Altars with the blood:
VNto the Lord (they ſay) theyle yeeld,
Moſes aſcends the mount, and ſtayes

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: and all as God hath ſaid.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: Ram skins , doore hangings alſo make;

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: Pure oyle for lamps, and laſting lights,

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: At morne, and night giue God a lambe;

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: The holy oyle, the ſweet perfume;

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: They muſt not worke on Sabbath day,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: HOt was Gods wrath for golden calfe,

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: I Meane to ſtay, goe on your way,
The people mourne, then he to them,

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: KNow here the tables are renew'd,
LEagues with the heathen make thou none,
and hides his face with vaile;
Obſerue theſe lawes, and I thy foes

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: NO man muſt worke on Sabbath day,

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: OF peoples offrings ſtay is made:
As couering , curtaines , bars are made,

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: PVre gold the Arke is guilded with,
are made, with oile moſt ſweet.

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: The ſumme of ſiluer, gold and braſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: The girdle , all theſe Moſes ſees;

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: Gods glory ſeene, his will perform'd,
cloud guides them on their wayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALl ſpotleſſe males out of thy herd,
And foules, for thy burnt offerings:
thy hand on head muſt ſtay:
The Prieſt muſt kill, and ſprinkle blood,
DOe this (if in an ouen or plate,
Or fried in pan) no leuen thou,
EAres of greene corne, well dried thou muſt
For thy firſt fruits, and offer ſalt

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Out of the herd; ſee that no ſpot,
GOd bids here kill, and lay on hands;
learne what muſt ſerue for meat.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: The Law of God tranſgreſſe and ſinne,
IN ſuch a caſe muſt bullocks blood,
or goats or kids be ſhed,
For that ſame ſinne and (as before)

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: KNow thou that doſt thy knowledge hide,
Or ſinn'ſt in making of an oath,
LAmbe , kidd, foules, flower: in ſacriledge
A lambe is ſlaine for ignorance

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: The Law of the burnt offring learne;
NOw learne the law of meat offrings;
Learne what the Prieſts muſt doe when they

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: OF treſpaſſe offering learne the lawes,
a vow or gifts moſt free.
PRieſts portion in the peace offerings,
No man muſt eate the fat nor blood,
but they may eate the reſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: QVickly take Aaron and his ſonnes,
REad here what their ſinne offring is,
the place, the time, the guiſe?

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: SEe the firſt offrings Aaron made,
Which Moſes taught him, after that
the Lord to him did call.
THe ſinne and the burnt offerings,
• re here ſet downe, they pray that God
VNt' all the people then the Lord
• ire came from him vpon th'Altar,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: AS Aarons ſonnes ſtrange fire did bring,
So fire them both doth burne,
The Prieſts are here forbidden wine,
BEſide the Altar muſt the prieſts

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: COme learne what beaſts, what fiſh, and ſowles,
Vncleane and creeping things touth not,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: DEliuered wife muſt in her time,
Or Turtles two, and on th'eight day

lg.head: Chapt. 13.
lg.l: in skin, fleſh, bile, or cloath;
Put ſuch apart, them purge with fire,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: FOr clenſing of a Leper learne,
And how to purge a houſe that is

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: GOd here declares how men to clenſ •
For vncleane iſſues what to giue

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: HEre learne how high prieſts enter 〈◊〉
What for himſelfe he offer ſhould
INto the deſert with their ſinnes,
the ſcape goat muſt be ſent.

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: KIll nothing in, nor out of campe,
Blood (where is life) ſee thou eate not,
LEt no man ſacrifice to Deuills,
Who breaketh any of theſe lawes,
muſt be cut off each one.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: To Moloch offer not; for theſe
let liue in land with thee;

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: OBey thy God, yeeld filiall feare,
PVt farre away reuenge and hate,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: QVite cut off Moloch mungers all,
leſt land doth ſpue thee out.
REgard no wizards, leſt thou dye:

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: SEe how the Prieſts muſt Virgins wed,
His whoriſh daughter muſt be burnt,
THe Prieſts muſt mourne, but for his kinne,
No blind, lame , crooked, drawſe , as Prieſts

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: From holy things, vntill that they
in Prieſts houſe muſt not eate,
which muſt be that dayes meat.

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: BEhold the feaſts which God commands,
when you your field ſhall reape
A ſolemne feaſt of your firſt fruits
DAyes ſeuen eate all vnleauened bread,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: EVening and morne the high Prieſts muſt
And the Shew bread; blaſphemers muſt
be ſton'd in all mens ſight
FOr killing man, man muſt be kill'd,
Breach for a breach, a tooth for tooth,
God will haue blood for blood.

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: GOd bids that fields the ſeuenth yeare reſt
In fiftieth yeare how houſes, men,
HEre fruit the land ſhall largely giue ,
• f theſe my ſtatutes ye obſerue ,
let no ſuch poore man pay.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 6
lg.l: KNow, keepe, & doe theſe Gods commands,
and then thou ſhalt be bleſt:
• eſpiſe his lawes, and looke for plagues,
LEt grauen pictures none be made,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 7
lg.l: MEn making certaine vowes to God,
no man, beaſt, houſe, or fields;
• y tithes pay truly to the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALl fit for warre by Moſes here,
Euen tribe by tribe, yet Leuites are

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: they campe and pitch their tents,
Each tribe his captaine hath, Leuites

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: CHarge here of holy things is giuen,
To Merari, for the firſt borne,
Which Moſes had of th' Iſra'lites,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l:
Commit thē
••• iage of the tent,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: FRom out of campe exclude vncleane:
Gifts are the Prieſts: ſuſpected wiſe

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: GIue ye no wine to Nazarites ,
let them not ſhaue their head
nor muſt they mourne for dead.
HEre is the forme, the Prieſts muſt vſe

l.hi: God thee preſerue, ſtill on thee ſhine,
his
Gratious loue expreſſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: IN ample ſort the Princes giue,
From mercy ſeat God of his will

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: KNow how the lights muſt lighted bee,
How long to ſerue, and when to ceaſe

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: LEt Paſſeouer be kept firſt month,
A cloud of fire directs and guides
MOnth, day and houre appointed here,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: NOw th'uſe of ſiluer trumpets learne,
The order of their marching marke,
OBſerue when arke remoues or reſts,
To turne to Iſrael, and to quell,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: for fleſh they weepe and cry,
with quailes in mouth they die.

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: His loue to Moſes: Miriam ſtrikes
REad how at Moſes prayer ſhe
Seuen dayes ſhee's ſhut out of the hoaſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: SEarchers are ſent: commend the land;
Some fright with Giants , Caleb bids
go on , feare no ſuch thing.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: THe people murmure at the newes:
And Caleb; God doth threaten all
VNto the Lord then Moſes prayes,
muſt not come in the land.
That would inuade the holy land

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: BRing ye theſe offrings to the Lord,
Who muſt be ſton'd: God bids them all

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: DAthan, An. Mundi 2467 Korah and Abiram
The earth doth ſwallow ſome vp quicke:
FO • thwith then Aaron incenſe ſweet,
He ſtands betweene the ſicke and whole,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: GOd bids that Princes of each tribe,
Whoſe rod God chuſeth An. Mundi 2470. (Aarons rod)
HIs rod is left for monument,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: On Aaron, and his ſonnes; to him
KNow that the portion of the Prieſts,
are here ſet downe at large.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: LEt red cowes blood be ſprinckled,
And let the clenſed man thereof

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: at Kadeſh An. Mundi 2490 Miriam dies:
NOw Aaron to his ſonne reſignes,
he dies, his race is runne:
Then all the houſe of Iſrael,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: King Arad; not without ſome loſſe:
They all are healed by looking

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: The Aſſe doth ſaue that coniurer;

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: REad what God puts in Balam's mouth,
twice he is bid to bleſſe ,
God he repents not as a man,

SEe Balam's wiſh, to dye the
• death
In Iacob God beholds no ſinne,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: Balack is angry bids him packe,

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: Here Phineas for his zeale is bleſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: ALl count from twenty yeares vpward.
Let thoſe diuide the land by lot

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: BY Gods law daughters lands enioy:
He for a good ſucceſſor praies,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: COme offer euery day two lambs
At Paſſeouer and at the firſt fruits ,
learne here what muſt be done.

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: DVly your feaſt of trumpets keepe,
which eight whole dayes muſt laſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: EXhort and charge men keepe their vowes,
Let maids and wiues performe the ſame,

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: FIerce Midian ſpoil'd, baſe Balam ſlaine,
The prey is giuen vnto the men,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: Halfe of Manaſſes tribe the ſame,
KIll ye the hearts of your brethren,
Shall they goe fight, and you ſit here?
LOc thus your fathers did before,
They ſay they will goe fight with them,

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: MArke here their iourneyes forty two,

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: NOw learne the borders of the Land,

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: OF Cities giuen to Leuies tribe,
Their ſuburbs and their meaſure marke,
PVt him to death that murthers man,
QVite clenſe the land from blood hereby,
But life for life; defile it not

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: let An. Mundi 2492 daughters husbands take
In their owne tribe, and ſo thereto,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AGaine is Moſes ſpeech rehears'd, An. Mundi 2492
how God would giue the land
To Abraham, and his ſeed which ſhould
BEaring all your affaires my ſelfe,
Then officers were giuen to you,
from thence twelue ſpies were ſent,
Who prais'd the Land, ſome were affraid,
DRead not (ſaid I) God then did ſweare,
The reſt for vnbeliefe did dye,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: EDom ye might not meddle with
But Sihon you were will'd to kill,
FIght not with Ammon , for his land
to you I will not giue;
Lots children I haue giuen it to,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GOd then did giue into our hands
The bigneſſe of this Gyants bed ,
HEre I to two tribes and an halfe
And pray'd that I might enter in,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: ISrael adde not • o my word,
but ye liue till this day.
KEepe therefore thou my ſtatutes well,
and thee moſt wiſe ſhall call.
LEt not Mount Horeb be forgot
But only heardſt a voyce, and where,
MArke images , and looke for death:
this teach to thine and liue.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: That Moſes ſhould teach them from God
O That my people would feare me,
and walke in all my wayes,
Then they and theirs ſhall proſper well ,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: PLeaſe thou thy God: ſerue him alone ,
Obey my lawes, teach them thy ſonnes,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: QVite ſhun and flee all fellowſhip
Deſtroy them all , and holy be ,
REpay with ruine will the Lord,
euen to the face of thoſe

That hate him, and
• tranſgreſſe his lawes,
he takes them for his foes.
to them that doe his will:
the Lord their foes will kill.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: THis God obey, he hath you led,
fed, cloath'd, and giuen a land:
Dwell not in pride, in feare abide,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: VAunt not, it was not for thy worth,
that God thoſe foes did quell:
They for their ſinnes were all caſt out,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: A Trend Gods loue in that he doth

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: BE louing to the Lord thy God:
Let bleſſings, , or his curſe preuaile,
Ye ſhall enioy, where raine doth fall,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: Worſhip both where, and how he bids
FAte thou no blood, inquire not how
Thou ſhalt not worſhip thy God ſo ,
for feare thou feele his rod.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: FRiends neereſt, deereſt of thy kinne,
if they thy heart will turne,
Or Citie to a falſe worſhip,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: GOds children muſt not ſhaue thēſelues,
Theſe holy feaſts keepe to the Lord,
learne how all tithes to vſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: If he will ſtay then bore his eare,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: IN due time keepe theſe ſolemne feaſts,
Chooſe Iudges iuſt: but plant no groue

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: KIngs muſt not horſe, money, or wiues
But read and keepe the Law of God,
LEt ſpotleſſe things be giuen to God,
In doubtfull caſes let the Prieſt,
So other will be ſore affraid

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: NOte here the Prieſts and Leuites due,
Chriſt muſt be heard: who preacheth ought
that God bids not, muſt dye.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: OF Cities ſet apart for him
Stirre no landmarkes , two muſt witneſſe

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: PVt hartenings in the ſouldiers hearts,
let ſuch and ſuch be free:
Grant peace to them that peace accept,
QVite ſpoile and kill thoſe cities males,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: REad how to deale with man found plaine,
on tree let none be ſtaid.

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: SEe how to deale with neighbours beaſt;
THe dam and young thou muſt not take,
AFfraid who is of Maſters houſe,
Nor grapes, nor coine beare thou away,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: Of pledges which thou muſt not take,
when hire is to be paid.
DIſcharge new maried man from warre;
Let iuſtice ſtill be done to all;

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: EXceed not forty ſtripes to giue;
The oxe muſt not be muzzeled:
thou muſt cut off her hand,
Falſe weights and meaſures God abhorres,
let none be in thy land.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: GIue thy firſt fruits in time to God
Confeſſe and ſay he is our God,
HE that doth pay his third yeares tithes,
If wee ſerue him, he ſure will vs

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: on ſtones the Law to write;
Twelue tribes diuided: ſix muſt bleſſe:
Build altar alwayes of whole ſtones,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: LOue, feare, obey the Lord thy God,
If not, he will ſuch curſes ſend,

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: MY mercies great and workes ye ſaw,

If any bleſſe himſelfe
• in ſinne,
Ile plague him in mine ire.
NOw ſtand they all before the Lord,
All ſecret things belong to God,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: to ſuch as leaue their ſinne;
The Law is cleare: eternall death

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: POſſeſſe yee ſhall all Can'an Land,
the Lord with you will goe;
Be ſtrong ô Ioſhua, God will daunt
QVickly you will corrupt your waies,
when I am dead and gone;
And cauſe the Lord for backſliding ,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: REad ye the law, hear Ioſuah chargd,
SEe Moſes ſong; which ſhewes Gods loue
to them that will doe well;
But direfull vengeance to his foes,
THeir hearts they muſt ſet on theſe words,
God ſends him vp to Nebo mount,
to ſee the land and dye.

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: VPon his folke Gods glory ſhines,
Before his death, and then doth bleſſe
ALl haue their ſeuerall bleſſings here;
He is their God, and therefore they

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: His age and buriall both obſerue,
Then Ioſuah full of heauenly skill

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ARiſe now Ioſhua Ile thee aide,
Be valiant, ſtout, couragious, An. Mundi 1493
and I thy foes will fright.
is yours both farre and neare ;
Euen all where euer you ſhall tread,
DVely their promiſe made, to keepe,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: the ſpies to hide and ſaue
who ſought their liues to haue.
FOr this they make a couenant,

They hide in hills: they bring
• good newes,
the land doth faint for feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GOe after th'arke▪ then campes remoue:

The waters part:
• the riuer's dry,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: HEnce take twelue ſtones , for Gilgal mount;
Tell ſonnes that this is done that they

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: the Kings doe quake and feare:

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: God giues to Ioſhua; he the walls
LEſt you be curs'd, (ſaith he) refraine
The walles fall downe: who them repaire,

MArke here how Rahab is
• preſen • 'd
with all the friends ſhe had;
She hid the ſpies: now dwells with them,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NOte Achans ſinne: how Iſr'el fled;

He bids them ſearch: Achan is
• ound,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l:
O Feare not Ioſhua A ••
is thine,
they ſaine to flee, but turne;
They ſlay them all, hang vp their King,
He writes the Law vpon the ſtones,
QVite through did Ioſhua read the Law,
Curſing the bad, but bleſſing thoſe,
He life doth promiſe by an oath,
their ſlaues they all muſt be.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: but kill'd with ſword and haile:
The Sunne ſtands ſtill, thoſe fiue are hang'd,
Seuen moe are made to quaile .

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: Hazar is burnt , that chiefe City,
they kill both all and ſome.

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l:
ALl the
• whole land ſtout Ioſhua takes
Rich ſpoile and prey the people got;
the land did reſt from warre.
BEhold here thirty Kings and three ,
Their land on both ſides Iordan did

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: COme marke the limits of thoſe lands,
The ſame to nine tribes and an halfe,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: to An. Mundi 2500 Caleb Hebron fell
By lot, the nine tribes and an halfe,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: GReat lands & large hath Iudahs tribe ,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: HEre of the ſonnes of chaſt Ioſeph

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: IOſeph his ſonnes, and his ſons ſonnes,
Are bid poſſeſſe the woods and hills,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: KNow that at Shilo th'arke is plac'd,

three ſen •
more land to ſee: An. Mundi 2510

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: Receiue their land: a part is giuen

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: At high Prieſt death, to his owne houſe

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: NOw eight and forty Cities here
With ſuburbs for their Cattle: then

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: POſſeſſe ye ſhall this promiſt land,
If that you cleaue vnto his lawes,

One man ſhall chaſe
• a thouſand foes,
• f not, the Lord will cut you off,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: SVch and ſo great from Terah's time,
• hat neuer people had like cauſe,
• oth I and mine will ſerue him ſtill,
then ſets he vp a ſtone.
VNder an oake, as a witneſſe,
At hundred and ten yeares of age,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ACrs of Iudah and Simeon: An. Mundi 2511
they both are made to • ue.
The Kenites dwell in Iudah land:
Gaza , with all the coaſts thereof,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: EVen by an Angell at Bochin ,
Becauſe they did the voyce of God
FVll well in dayes of Ioſhua,
GOds anger marke for this their ſinne,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: HEare marke the Countries which were left
Who by their fellowſhip with them,
IN their diſtreſſe, from Cuſhans rage,
good An. Mundi 2530 Othniel ſets them free,
by An. Mundi 2550 Ehud ſau'd they be.
KNow after this that An. Mundi 2580 Shamgar ſtew
With an oxe goad: ſo they were freed

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: Deborah, and Barak ſets them free, An. Mundi 2630

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: A Prophet cheeks them: Gideon ſent
Is quite conſum'd, and how that he
His ſignes obſerue, his armies great,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l:
QVickly the moſt An. Mundi 268 •
are ſent away;
He is encourag'd by a dreame,
REad here of trumpets, pitchers , lamps,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l:
SVccoth and An. Mundi 269 •
Penuel both refuſe
thoſe townes doth ſpoile and grieue.
TWo Kings are taken: Gideon doth
with ſword he ſtopt their breath.

VNwilling is he to beare
• rule,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: His brethren kills; the kingdome gets,
And truly doth foretell and ſhew,
and ſowes the towne with ſalt.
DEſtroyd by him with fire then is ,
At An. Mundi 2710 Thebez ſlaine; that curſe befell

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: ENding his reigne thus, with his life,
Then An. Mundi 2717 lair rul'd, whoſe thirty ſonnes
God ſends them to their fained gods
to helpe An. Mundi 2737 them in diſtreſſe.
GRieu'd was his ſoule for Iſr'el then

He pitied them, and Ieptha
• then

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: his treat' of peace is vaine
all An. Mundi 2758 vanquiſhed and ſlaine.
IEphtha did make a vow to God,
He did with griefe of heart performe

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: They are diſcern'd by An. Mundi 2760 Shiboleth,
Then Elon , and then Ammon rule,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: they were ſore plagu'd for it.
NOw to the wife of Manoah,
Then to her husband, telling them,
that ſhe a ſonne ſhould beare.
But is much cheared by his wife,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: as wife to pleaſe his mind:
an iournying he a Lyon ſlew, An. Mundi 279 •
His riddle told, from thirtie foes
both life and goods he takes.

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: REfuſing then to giue his wife,
for this wrong at their hands,
SAmpſons wife, and her father both,
And Sampſon ſmote them hip and thigh,
THen he with lawbone of an aſſe,
In Lehi God makes for him then
a ſpring, call'd ENHAKKORE. An. Mundi 2802

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: The City gates he bare away,
To tell her where his ſtrength did lie,
BVt at the laſt hee's ouercome,
and they put out his eyes:
He pulls the houſe vpon their heads,
A Prieſt he gets; a Leuite hires,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: At Micha's An. Mundi 2831 houſe with Ionathan
FVll well they hartned by him are
To Danites of good hopefull newes
Of Prieſt and gods they Micha rob,
for which he mournes and cries.
HEe cries in vaine , is threatened,
They ſet vp Idols, the Prieſthood

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: IN Iſrael there was no King
A Leuites wi • e abus'd to death
KNow that at Gibeah this was done.
His wife into twelue parts to cut,
which to twelue tribes he ſends.

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: His wrong ſuſtain'd ; the tribes for this
NOte when they did all faſt and pray,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: O How the people mourne, forlone
of Ben: his tribe, and lines,
Which daunced there, and ſo their tribe

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: His wife Naomi, and his two ſonnes
The father died, the ſonnes then tooke
CHil'on and Mahlon wo •• their names:
They did not long enioy the ſame,
That they ſhould not turne home with her,
EXceeding conſtant good An. Mundi 2663 Ruth is,
and cleaues with all her heart
FVll gladly are they both receiu'd,
ſhe was of ſuch good fame.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: in An. Mundi 2670 Boaz barley fields,
He taketh knowledge of her then,
HE bad her gleane with his maidens,
and at meale times to eate:
She caried ſtore of barly home,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Her kinſman he doth ſay he is,
he gaue to her that day;
She brought it home to Naomi,
and told what he did ſay.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: LOe Boaz then next kinſman calls,
To him before the Elders graue,
He buyes the land, takes Ruth to wife,
NOte that of her was Obed borne,
Who to King Dauid father was,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: An. Mundi 2810Hanna his wife (though barren) yet,
and for a child doth pray;
Lly at firſt reproues her ſore,
Till he be wean'd, An. Mundi 2820 and then ſhe doth

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: DOwne to the graue; and backe againe,
Marke here the ſinnes of Elie • ſonnes
which death vpon them brings. An. Mundi 2830
ELkan' and Hanna both are bleſt.
Ely reproues his ſonnes of ſinnes,
FEaring not God nor fathers checkes,
Therefore the Lord both ſons and fire

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GOd thrice call'd Samuel laid to ſleepe
Of Elies houſe: then he (though loath)
And was his holy Prophet made,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: They fetch the Arke into the campe,
KIll'd then were thirty thouſand moe
Hophni and Phineas both are ſlaine,
LOe Phineas wiſe in trauell falls,
the glory of God was gone.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: MArke Aſhdod in with Emrods ſmit,
Before the Arke; Gath's plagued and

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: NOw feare doth force them cart the Arke,

For looking in An. Mundi 285 •
it God doth moe

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: OF th' Arke brought to Abinadab:
Put for to keepe it: twenty yeares
PRepare your hearts, ſerue God alone,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: the people aske a King. An. Mundi 2875
He ſhewes his manners: God's caſt off:
God yeelds, but hates the thing.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: THen ſeeking Fathers An. Mundi 2880 Aſſes out,
He feaſts him, counts him chiefeſt gueſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: V • all of oyle is pour'd on's head,
By them confirm'd, his heart is chang'd,
AMong the Prophets he is one:
His ſubiects are of diuers minds,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: thruſt out all the right eyes
he kills the foes , out right;
Great ioy at this his kingdome is,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: they all his life doe cleare;
EVen in wheat harueſt God ſhall ſend
He comforts them in Gods mercies,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: The men of Iſr'el feare and fly,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: A diuine terror makes them quake,
KIng Saul aſſaults ; the Prieſts anſwer
for haſt, he would not ſtay:
all ioyne with him that day.
He doth reſtraine from eating ought,
MAny there are that reſcue him ,
and ſay he ſhall not dye:
So Saul ſurceaſeth , marke his might,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: He ſpareth Agag , and beſt things,
and ſo God wrath doth winne.

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: his ſonne to weare the Crowne.
QVite otherwiſe God lookes then man:
Saul ſends for Dauid, for to play,
and he great eaſe doth bring.

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: Encountreth, and with ſling and ſtone,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: SAul feareth Dauid: hates his prayſe;

and ſeekes to take
• his life:
His ſonne him loues; his daughter's giuen ,
as ſnare to be his wife.
TWo hundred foreskinnes he doth giue,
But Dauids fame, and glorious praiſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: VNto his ſonne here Saul doth ſweare,
Yet ſends to kill, at Rama he,
BY oath their cou'nant they renew,
He token giues, and farewell takes,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: COmming to Nob he eates ſhew-bread,
He takes Goliahs ſword at Gath,
To kill the Prieſts , but Sauls footmen

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: Thence flies to Ziph, thence to Maon ,
there ſau'd; to Engedi cau • s .

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: GOod Dauid cuts Sauls skirt and robe,
Saul weepes and prayes, (when he is King )

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: HEre Samuel dyes, and Nabal churle
He would haue kill'd him, Abigail
IN ſhort time after Nabal dyes,
To Phalti Saul gaue Dauids wife,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: KIng Saul purſues his ſonne againe,
Checks Abner, that he did not guard
LEt wrath ſure eaſe, and in thy fight,
O let my life be deare :
(Thus Dauid ſaith) and bids Saul ſend
I haue beene fooliſh; bleſt be thou ,

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: NO more doth Saul for Dauid ſeek,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l:
O •
Achiſh truſt in Dauid put,
Saul feares to ſee his foes:
All witches he had once deſtroy'd,
and yet to one he goes:
PVt in great feare, when he did heare
He faints; but is aduis'd to eate,

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: Q • arrelling Princes chide the king,
He and his men, are all diſmiſt,
to warre they muſt not goe.

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: which made their hearts to rue:
SIcke man receiu'd, directs them to
their foes, whom they doe foyle:
The moſt are ſlaine, their owne are ſafe,
they haue rich prey and ſpoyle.
THen Dauid ſends gifts to his friends,
Who keepe the ſtuffe, haue iuſt as much,
as they that goe to fight.

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: VExed full ſore, Saul loſt the field,
all his three ſonnes are ſlaine:
Iſra'lites flye; for ſake their townes:
The men of Iabeſh burne their fleſh,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Man of Amaleck bringeth newes,
and ſaith he Saul did kill:
His death and ſonnes, Dauid laments.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: BY men of Iudah Dauid's King,
Here Ioabs men and Abners fight,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: DVring the warre, King Dauid growes,
Him Dauid feaſts, but Ioab ſtabs,
all mourne for him that day:
EVer more curſt be Ioabs houſe,
He bids bring Michol home againe:
ſix ſonnes to him are borne.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: FOr Abners death great troubles grew;
Their King doe kill, to Dauid then
they both doe bring his head.
GReat gifts they hoped to haue had,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: At thirty yeares; he Zida takes,
IN Salem are eleuen ſonnes borne,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: KIng in a Cart doth fetch the Arke, An. Mundi 2929
LEft is the Arke at Obeds houſe,
Its brought to Sion with great ioy,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: MInding to make the Lord a houſe,
But then reproues; for no ſuch charge
NO word was ſpoken of an houſe,
Without command to build him one,
OVt of his bowels he ſhall come,
Shall build an houſe; for bleſſings great
the King doth praiſe his name.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: the King gaue God a ſhare.
QVite quell'd when Toi theſe enemies ſaw,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: REſtor'd by him are all Sauls lands
he with the King did eate.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: he puts his men to ſhame:
Twice he and his are vanquiſhed,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: VNto the warre is Ioab ſent,
AFfirming that ſhe was with child,
He goes not home, then Dauid he

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: BY Nathans parable of th • ewe lambe,
An. Mundi 2910the King himſelfe doth blame,
Reprou'd, he doth confeſſe the fact,
CHild being ſick, for life he prayes,
but life he could not get;
Sonne Solomon's borne: King Rabbah takes ,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: doth force, hate, An. Mundi 2512 turn away:
EVen ſo he did at ſheep ſhearing,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: FOr feare of looſing both her ſonnes,
a widow for helpe doth cry;
Her ſute is all for Abſolon, An. Mundi 29 • 8
GReat beauty, and great weight of haire,
By Ioabs meanes, after two yeares ,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: HE by his flatt'ry ſteales away
Pretends a vow, to An. Mundi 2922 Hebron goes,
IN feare when Dauid flees from him,
The Prieſts and Leuites are ſent back,
the Arke with them they take.

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: And Shimei railing calls the King
MArke Dauids patience; how that he,
And thoſe who would haue had his head,
Vile filthy whordomes here are taught,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: To Dauid ſecret word was ſent,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: QVickly he muſtereth all his men,
and bids them haue a care
Which when the King of Cuſhi heares ,
he mournes too much for it.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: SO doſt thou mourne? cheare vp thy men,
they ſtriue to bring him backe,
TO ſtirr vp Iudah Prieſts are ſent,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: Abel is ſau'd by Sheba's head,
whom they in towne did ſlay.

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: ALl Sauls ſeuen ſonnes once hang'd and dead,
In fathers tombe Sauls bones were laid
By foure of Dauids valiant men,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: DAuid doth in theſe his laſt words, An. Mundi 292 •
Which was beyond all humane ſenſe,
EAch Belial brat is curſt of God,
His Worthies names, and noble acts,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: FOr, Iſr'els ſinne God's ſore diſpleas'd,
His Captaine Ioab for to count
the people of Iſrael. An. Mundi 2927
GOds plagues propounded, of the three
the plague he likes to haue;
doth put the King in mind
Of former promiſe made to her,
which he with oath did bind;
And bids they ſhould anoint him King,
And he ; but if he loyall grow,
the King will ſet him free.
FOr murther Ioab muſt be ſlaine:
for curſing An. Mundi 2930 Shimei kill'd:
Then Dauid dyes, when he his age
GReat is the glory Solomon hath;
Sues for to haue Abiſhag giuen,
but that ſute coſt his life.
Is ſlaine; for (he confin'd) to Gath

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: LOe here his Princes of renowne,

Great gifts are
• brought: great peace ech where.
His prouerbes; ſpeech of trees, fiſh, foule,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: men to the yong King ſends,
He Hiram tells, to build a houſe
Here Hiram prayſeth God for him
QVite hew'd were all the temple ſtones,
No axe nor hammer there was heard,
Among them in that houſe of his,
how all the houſe was guilt:
The Cherubins, the doore, and Court,
the time when it was built.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: THe building of king Solomons houſe,
The porch of pillars: of iudgement ,
VNto his An. Mundi 2952 Queene an houſe he built,
BY Prieſts and Leuites the Arke is brought,
The glory of God doth fill the houſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: DOe what I bid (ſaith God) and I
Rebell, and I will cut thee off,
that King to King doth giue :
As bondmen doe the An. Mundi 2940 gentiles worke
FRom Dauids City to her houſe ,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l:
GReat
• gifts doth Queen of Sheba bring,
his wiſedome ſhe admires: An. Mundi 2957
HIs gold, and targets all of gold
IN golden veſſels did he drinke,
In regall pompe he doth exceed

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: KIng Solomon in his old age
By his owne wiues , and Concubines,
And Rezon who did runne away,
all theſe the Lord did raiſe,
His reigne and death, how Roboam

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: OVr yoake thy father grieuous made
This ſute the people brought, when they
PRoudly An. Mundi 2970 Roboham doth refuſe
Hees rul'd by youth; their yoke (he ſaith)
QVickly the ten tribes then reuolt,
makes feaſts the Lord to try.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: SEe how his An. Mundi 2971 hand is dryed vp,
Yet at his prayer it's reſtor'd,
THe man of God ſeduced is,
Hee's checkt of God, by Lyon ſlaine,
VPon his aſſe the old Prophet
the good mans corps doth lay;
He buries him, confirmes his word,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: is ſicke he ſends his wife
BY God the prophet is forewarn'd
In Chronicles thou maiſt them read,
DEaling moſt wickedly with God, An. Mundi 2972
by Shiſhak Salem's ſpoil'd: An. Mundi 2986

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: EVen as the ſire ſo doth the ſonne
But his ſonne An. Mundi 2974 Aſa after him
yet he a league An. Mundi 2987 doth make
payes him and his their hire.
HIs acts are writ in Chronicles,
To warre with Aſa all his dayes,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: Becauſe he God prouok'd, his ſonne
KIng Elah drunke , of Zimrie's kill'd,
he in his ſtead doth raigne:
LEwd An. Mundi 3013 Zimri forc'd to burne himſelfe
An. Mundi 3020Om • i doth ſo aſſaile
MVch miſchiefe did this Omri worke,
In firſt ſonnes daies, and built the gates,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: O Ahab heare that for ſome yeares,
no raine on earth ſhall fall.
POore widow then An. Mundi 3035 of Zaraphah
He rayſeth vp their ſonne was dead,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: QVickly thy ſelfe ſhew to the king,
him in that way he went.
REad here how he good Prophets fed,
to An. Mundi 3040 Ahab then is brought
by fire from heauen, then ſlaine:
obtaines great ſtore An. Mundi 3041 of raine.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: and ſaith he ſure ſhall dye:
Hee flees; is by an Angell chea • 'd
VNto mount Horeb then he goes
from thence he ſends him then

He tooke his
• leaue then of his friends,
DIſpitefull King at that yeares end
his hopes were all but follies.
Was with a couenant ſent away,
no hurt at all he had.
FOr this a Prophet makes Ahab

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: GRieu'd is the king and ſullen ſicke,
To grant his vineyard; hee's accus'd
HE dead, his ground king did poſſeſſe,
Denounceth plagues on him and her,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: KIng by falſe prophets is ſeduc'd,
LEwd Ahab hauing loſt his life,
the dogs licke vp his blood;
MAking the word of God his guide
He turneth not aſide from God,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: An. Mundi 3041 Ahazi ſends t' enquire
BVrnt were two captaines which the King
But ſpares the third, and tells the King

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: COmming to take his laſt farewell

With cloke An. Mundi 334 •
Eliah parts Iordan,
They find him not, Eliſha makes
GOod Prophet is by children mockt,
bald head they doe him call:
For this, two Beares out of the wood
did teare and kill them all.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: HEre Ioram reignes, he caſts away
IN theſe daies Meſha Moabs king, An. Mundi 3050
KIng eke of Edom ioynes with them,
For want of water; ſtrangely are
LIght and a ſmall thing to the Lord,
Deceiu'd with colours they are ſpoild
who lookt and hop'd for ſpoyles.
Iſr'el is grieu'd, from thence departs,
and ſo the warre is done.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: NOw is the widdowes oyle increaſt,
with which her debts ſhe payes.
He giues the Shunamite a ſonne
and him from death doth raiſe. An. Mundi 3052
O Man of God death in the pot,
He ſweets it, and with twenty loaues

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: That by Eliſhaes meanes he might
And to the king of Iſrael
REad how An. Mundi 3051 Eliſha Naaman ſends
But to receiue his profferd gifts
he did not thinke it good.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: THe Prophet giues yong Prophets leaue,
Makes An. Mundi 3052 yron ſwim, kings counſell tells,
VNto An. Mundi 3053 Samaria armies brought.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: By Lepers foure, of Syrians flight
BY Spies the king then finds it true ,
they runne both more and leſſe
To ſpoile the tents of Syrians,
a Lord's kil'd in the preſſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: At ſeuen yeares end ſhe doth returne
DEclared firſt it was to th' king,
that ſhe was that mans wife,
That by Eliſha had her ſonne
To him by Hazael; here obſerue
FOr he ſucceeds when firſt he had
In Iudah thou doeſt here obſerue,
An. Mundi 3054 Ahazi raignes and Ioram ſees

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: HEre by Eliſha a yong Prophet
There to anoint ſtout Iehu king,
IEhu made king, king Ioram kills
At Gur Ahazi king is ſlaine,
ſhould be throwne from the towre;
Her blood was ſprinkled on the wall,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: by An. Mundi 3058 Iehu then were ſent,
Caus'd ſeuenty ſonnes to loſe their heads,
He two and forty brethren kills,
And of the worſhippers of Baal
OBſerue how Iehu An. Mundi 3066 followeth

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: PReſeru'd is Ioaſh by his Aunt
Six yeares in Gods houſe he is hid,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: RIghtly did Ioaſh rule and raigne
in all the high Prieſts daies, An. Mundi 3084
He bade the Prieſt repaire Gods houſe,
And after him then doth ſucceed.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: By Haz'el: but by prayer God
AFter his death, Ioaſh his ſonne
A dead man caſt in Prophets graue, An. Mundi 3107

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: Yet not like Dauid faithfull King
EAch man (as yet) on high places
hee's made full ſore to rue. An. Mundi 3190

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: High places ſtayes: he Leper An. Mundi 3190 dyes
He reignes a month, and Menahem
LEwd Menahem made ſtrong by Pul,
OBſerue here good king Iothams raigne,
High places yet were not remou'd,

And thereof he a patterne
• ſends
Right ſpeedily to V • iah Prieſt,
SEe how he doth the Temple ſpoyle
He dyes, and his ſonne Hezeki
good king rules in his ſtead.
now Iſrael doth goe, An. Mundi 3210
they mixe religions ſo. An. Mundi 3230

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: braſſe Serpent he deſtroyes, An. Mundi 3226
ſends on the King to raile:
Who moues the people to reuolt.
and makes their hearts to qu • ile.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: To pray for them, he ſaith that God
pride, fall and end of dayes.
GReat bleſſing muſt on Sion fall,
One Angell of th' Aſſyrian hoaſt
doth vaniſh, An. Mundi 3238 kill and ſtay
the King is then full ſtill,
He haſteneth home ; before his gods

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: is told that he muſt die:
He prayes, his life is lengthened;
KNow that this wonder God did worke
The king ſhewes to the meſſengers
all treaſures which he had. An. Mundi 3239
and blames him for his deed:

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: Which caus'd againſt all Iuda Land
NExt him his ſonne Ammon ſucceeds,

He God forſooke, and Idols
• ſeru'd,
that did ſo vile a thing,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: Hilkiah finds the Lords Law booke,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: The booke of God; An. Mundi 3342 he then deſtroyes
STanding then by a pillars hee
On Bethels Altar burnes mens bones:
Gods wrath yet did not ſtay.
VEry ſore kindled was his wrath
DIſtreſt is Iuda , by ſuch bands,
GReat is the anger of the Lord,
all's ſpoil'd without all pity. An. Mundi 3356

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: Zedkiah ſonnes are ſlaine, An. Mundi 3353
He taken, hath his eyes put out,
KIngs captaine of the guard ſpoiles all,
The Nobles are at Riblah ſlaine,
LOrd, and chiefe ruler was ordain'd,
They need would into Egypt fly,
He ſets his throne aboue thoſe Kings
that were in Court with him.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ADams of-ſpring to Noe is told,
Noahs ſonnes, and all their race:
Shems Sonnes to Abraham here obſerue,

The Kings
• of Edom, and the Dukes,
a few or none were good.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: Ieſſes, and Calebs ſonnes who were,

The line of Caleb ſonne of
• Hur,
is ſet downe in this place.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: F • ithfull king Dauids Children ſee

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: IN order here read Rubens line,
He loſt his Birthright the defil'd
Their chiefe men, coaſts, and conqueſts all,
for ſin they loſt their place.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: LEarne Leuites line; and A'rons race,
Which Moſes taught, vntill they went

OBſerue the ſonnes of Aſhur
• here,
How were they plagu'd by men of Gath,

lg.l: and chiefe men are ſet downe;
who firſt did weare the crowne.

lg.l: QVickly here maiſt thou reckon vp,
• he charge of Leuites, and the ſtock

THe cauſe why God thus caſt off Saul,
and crown'd the ſonne of leſſe,
• as that he went vnto a witch,

lg.l: a foes driuen out, he Sion tooke,

lg.l: BLeſt Dauid will fetch home the Arke,
Vzza ſtrucke dead, Obed and his

lg.l: COme ſee how kindly Hiram deales
In ſending wood to build his houſe,
DAuid perceiues the Lords great loue;
His children, wiues , he twice preuailes,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: EXpreſt is here the cauſe why God,
Becauſe they brought not home the Arke,
FOr it a place the king prepares,
They beare it: Dauid danc't for ioy,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: A Quire he orders to ſing praiſe,
HE made a Pſalme of thankſgiuing,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: INtending to build God an houſe,
KNow here God promiſe made to him,
and his ſeed for his ſake:
which he to God doth make.
MArke how king Tou, by Hadoram,
for ſo their warre did end.
NOw both the preſents and the ſpoile

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: O See how Dauids ſeruants ſent
Are ſore abus'd, but this abuſe
QVickly a new ſupply is made
• y Shophach and by Dauid king,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: • e takes the kings crowne off his head,
SEe how king Dauid and his men,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: and faith he did not well.
VNto him are three plagues propos'd,
There builds an Altar; there God giues
BY Gods command the plague is ſtaid,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: CEdars great ſtore; Iron • and braſſe
He knew before the Temples place,
DEare ſonne (ſaith he) build thou Gods houſe,
But was forbid; God make thee wiſe,
EVen all the Princes of the Land
he bids to helpe his ſonne
To ſerue the Lord , who to them all

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: FRom all the quarters of the Land
and taught them all Gods wayes.
The Leuites numbred: charg'd to ſerue

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: but two for ſinne are ſlaine,
Off • ing ſtrange fire, the other two
INto a booke the chiefe were writ,
Aſſign'd by lot, • hey all muſt ſerue
at t • eir ſet times and turnes.

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: By lot they are diuided all,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: LOe how the porters parted are
by lot , who had the gate;

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: MOnethly each Captaine ſerues in courſe
and each tribe hath his head:

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: And in the great aſſembly he
OF all the promiſes God made
to him , and to his ſonne:
Of all the fauors he had ſhew'd,
and workes which he had done.
PErſwading all to feare the Lord
as long as they ſhould liue:
Euen Solomon to whom he doth
Full forty yeares; his facts are blaz'd

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: For asking wiſdome he is bleſt
BOth wiſedome, honor, wealth and ſtrength
• ike him in dignity was none,
COme ſee the multitude of men,
• o build the Temple, ſome to worke,
and ſome the worke to guide.
EVen wood and workmen both he grants,
• e praiſeth God that ſuch a ſonne
• he Temple lie begins to build,
GOd taught him how and what to doe,
• o make, and guild porch, beames and houſe,
HEe made two pillars, and the vaile,
• n right and left ſide of the houſe

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: The molten Sea on twelue oxen,
Courts, inſtruments of gold and braſſe,
euen all as God had ſaid.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: LOrds houſe and worke thus finiſhed,
NOw ſolemnly bring in the Arke,
They praiſing God, he ſhewes to them
a ſure ſigne of his grace.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: O Marke how all the people here
And how he praiſeth God who built
When as the houſe was conſecrate,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: QVickly then God ſends fire from heauen
His glory fill'd the houſe ſo full
Prieſt there could haue no place.
VNto the Lord, himſelfe , his Queene
• nd of thoſe Gentiles which were left,
AS for the Iſralites he made
〈◊〉 Queene from Salem to her houſe,
CHarg'd were the Prieſts and Leui • e • all,
•• ch in his courſe great ſtore of gold
•• e Queene of She • a brings him gold
EXceeding bleſt ſhe thought thoſe men
that might with that King liue:
•• en he to her 〈◊〉 ſhe did aske,
• Vlly is here ſet downe his gold▪
which Kings brought • arre and nye.
GReat ſtore of horſes, chario • s,
• nd then is call'd by death.
LEwd Prieſts he made for calues, and deuill •
Good people went and ſerued God
MAde ſtrong ſo long is Iudah land,

His many wiues, and children
• marke,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: God therefore ſtirres vp Shiſhak King,
OF former ſinne when they were told,
God ſaued King and Princes all
PRoud Shiſhak yet did beare away
then death for him doth call.
and puts them all to flight.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: THen good king Aſa doth ſucceed,
And all falſe worſhips: God then gaue
ASſaulting him; he then to God
for helpe and ayde doth call:
He heares: and Aſa kills and ſpoyes

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: And moſt of men of Iſrael,
though Queene) he did not ſpare.
And then enioyeth peace and reſt
King Aſa turnes him from that worke
• o by Syrians helpe and aid.
GOod Hanani is put in ward
HE in his paine ſought not to God,
His acts are in the Chronicles,
All Iudah's people for to teach
how they ſhould ſerue the Lord.
LIft vp his heart was to the Lord,
High places, groues and Idols all,
Some bring him gifts, and preſents in
NOte here his greatneſſe, and his might,
to fence him from all wrong.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: to ioyne with him in ſinne.
PErſwaded were they both to goe
who ſpake the thing was right;

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: REprou'd he was by good Iehu
for his loue, helpe, and aide
To Ahab lent, whom God did hate,
doth ſhew his care and paine,
Both in Gods houſe, and Common-wealth,
To Iudges , Prieſts and Leuites giuen,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: And prayes that in their great diſtreſſe,

to helpe he would make
• haſt.
The ioyfull newes from God which he.

King them
• exhorts and fingers ſets
to praiſe, and land the Lord.
And how when they had praiſed God,
DOing the will and worke of God,
But God was angry when he ioyn'd
the Lord on him would bring.
IN this diſtreſſe he ends his dayes,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: As in his throne ſo in his ſinne,
as bad in word and deed.
To fight with Hazel Syriahs king,
MArke how Ahazi goes to ſee
God is diſpleas'd; and by Iehu
Euen all ſaue Ioaſh, hid by's Aunt,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: Yong Ioaſh then he maketh King,
PVt then to death is Athali,
They vow to worſhip God aright,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: He makes the Temple be repair'd,
REad here the death of Ioiada,
SPoyl'd then is he of Syrians,
and in his roome doth reigne.

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: THoſe traitors that his father ſlew,
ANd when he firſt came to the Crowne,
BVt yet not with a perfect heart,
He for an hundred talents hires
are thouſands put to th' ſword.
As they returne they kill and ſpoyle,
And with the gods of Edomites
Ioaſh he doth prouoke to warre,
GOd caſt him off, when he left him,
He fled to Lachiſh, there is ſlaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: HEe yong Vzziah is made king,
A while he ruleth very well,
IN time he waxed wondrous proud,
and did not ſerue God right,
But playes the Prieſt , and after liues

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: Who ruling well was bleſt of God,
LOe how he fights with th' Ammonites,
Prepar'd his wayes before the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: He did forſake his fathers God,
NOw by the Iſra'lites, they all
But though he brib'd th' Aſſyrian King,
PReſt and diſtreſt he treſp • ſt more,

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: QVickly this good King doth repaire
His ioyfull praiſe, and of Leuites,
THis note, that all the inſtruments,
Or Dauid into Gods owne houſe,
VNto Gods worſhip, were not brought
of their owne minde and will,
But as the Lord by his Prophets,
BVt many mock'd, and many came,
The ſecond moneth, when altars all
And then the people by the Prieſts
EAch Prieſt and Leuite King appoints
And both what worke and maintenance
each one of them ſhould haue.
FVll forward are the people all,
To bring the tithes of oxe and ſheepe
all things kept in due order.
HE in the ſeruice of his God
He ſought the Lord with all his heart,
Tells them that by the power of God
MArke how an Angel then deſtroyes
By his owne ſonnes that king is ſlaine,
that did ſo brag and boaſt.
He then obtaines of God a ſigne
OBſerue how then he waxed proud,
and God did bring him low:
PAſſing great were his wealth and workes,
God grac'd him for his deeds;
He dyes, and his ſonne Manaſſen,
in kingly th • one ſ •• ceedes.

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: QVickly this wicked king ſets vp
And is releas'd when he to God
His acts, and prayer made to God,
Two yeares, he did diſpleaſe the Lord,
then by his men was ſlaine.
That Gods houſe ſhould be well repair'd
CVnni • geſt workmen are ſought out,
Shaphan did beare it to the King,
And certifie him what ſhe knew
FOr that, the King did rend his cloathes,
From all theſe plagues (during his life)
GOds law is read by kings command
They couenant to ſerue the Lord,
and on him ſtill to call.

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: doth charge to ſerue the Lord,
Whereto the Prieſts and Leuites all
Kiſſ'd at Megiddo was this king,
For whom the men of Iuda make
MOneths iuſt eleuen, and then is brought
NOte his ſhort reigne; three months, ten dayes,
And therefore he with veſſels all
To God he would not turne: but did
He and his people mock at them
The people captiue all are kept,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l:
The Temple at Ieruſalem, Jer. 25.11.
An. Mundi 3431
To goe to Salem there to make
the houſe for God their Lord.
COmmanding all the men that did
That they to helpe with needfull things
Gold, ſiluer, goods, beaſts, precious things,
EAch veſſell of the houſe of God,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: Both Leuites, Prieſts and people goe,
each one to his owne City.
Of Prieſts, which ſought, but could not find
HEre of their number and their wealth
KIndly they money, meat and drinke,
LAid by the builders of the worke,
The yong men thereat much reioyce,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: make ſhew that they would build
NOw ſeeke they with all ſubtilty,
To make the king their enemy,
their wits on worke they ſet.
OF treaſon they accuſe the Iewes,
The King beleeues, and giues in charge,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: ſtirre vp Z • rubbabel, An. Mundi 3446
With others to erect Gods houſe,
QVickly they ſet about the worke,
Who did command , or gaue them power,
to take thoſe workes in hand.
And that he would ſearch old records,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: Cyrus his firſt decree, An. Mundi 3450
Foroids his ſeruants that the Iewes
TO furniſh them with needfull things,
he charg'd that they ſhould haue.
VNto that man that ſhould intend,

Death is decreed he muſt be
• hang'd
euen by the helpe of foes,
BOth Prieſts and Leuites are reſtor'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: That Ezra for the houſe of God
ſhould lacke no kind of thing.
Who had to him before the king,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: a faſt doe keepe and hold.
GReat ſtore of ſilver and of gold
HEre in the holy houſe of God,
all done which he had ſaid.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: Becauſe the people tooke them wiues
He rent his cloathe, he faſts and prayes,
LAmenting ſtill he for them all
That God would pardon all their ſinnes,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: To doe away that fearfull ſinne
NOw Ezra mourning for this ſinne,
OBſerue the care the people haue
The names of them that maried,
Now deſolate, he mournes and faſts,
and prayes to God for them.
And that in all his counſells graue,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: The cauſe of his great heauineſſe,
the king doth ſhew him pity;
And ſends him into Iud land,
to build the houſe and wall,
He getteth letters from the king
G • uing them charge that they ſhould guard
To Salem, there to build the walls,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: HEre is the number of the Prieſts,
and men ſet downe at large,
Who did repaire the walles decaid,
IN managing this worthy worthy worke,
here maiſt thou ſee their orders,
And how to finiſh walls and houſe,
KNow that the men of ſericho,
this good worke of the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: T •• s building hinder, and with ſooffes
they ſet the ſame at naught.
M • ke then how Nehemiah prayes,
and God doth beare him ſo,
That he doth diſappoint the craft
NOw fall the Iewes againe to worke
That ſo they might both build the wall,
The goods they got by vſury,
SEt how his owne allowance due

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: By ſubtile craft , by rumors falſe,
VNto the teriour of their foes,
Betweene the Nobles of the Iewes,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: BEhold the charge of faire Salem,
That firſt came out of Babylon,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: and heard of all the rou • .
FOr knowledge of the word of God
They forward are to heare the word,
and to be taught it right.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: HEre Iſra'ls people faſt and pray, An. Mundi 3528
Strange wiues which they had maried.
IOyfully then they praiſe the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: LEarn here their names that with the Lord
And ſeale the ſame; they ſtill will giue
MArke wel the points of this their oath,
no ſtrange wiues will they take:
To buy or ſell on Sabbath day
NOne of Gods lawes they will tranſgreſſe,
They will adore, both they and theirs,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: The people choſen are by lot,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: REad here the number of Leuites
That did from Babylon come vp
SEe who of Leuites and of Prieſts,
See the ſucceſſion of high Prieſts

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: VPon the reading of the Law, An. Mundi 3539
He clenſeth cleane the chambers all
He did reforme the Sabbaths breach,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: To all his Princes vnder him, An. Mundi 3376
COunting no coſt a ſecond feaſt,
for ſeuen whole dayes he made,
This royall feaſt was in his Court,
Yet none were forc'd to drinke a draught,
EVnuches were ſent then by the King,
That of his noble Princes all,
FLatly the Queene denyes to come,
which frets the King full ſore,
An act is made which King confirmes,
GReatly the King and Princes all
That euery man ſhould rule his houſe

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: HIs officers were ſent to fetch,
and they with ſpeed doe bring, An. Mundi 3380
The faireſt virgins in the land,
IN ſtead of Vaſthi ſhee's made Queene,
Her kindred yet vnto the King
did ſeeke to kill the king:
they're hang'd for that ſame thing.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Aboue all Princes in the Court
All the kings ſeruants bow'd their knees,
as he paſt through the gate.
To this ſame vile ambitious wretch,
he would not bow the knee.
PRoud Haman then is full of wrath,
Not Mordech' onely: but the blood
of all the Iewes to ſpill.
QVickly he doth preuaile with King,
That Iewiſh people on one day,
REadily then the poſts went forth
The King and Haman drinking ſate,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: and at kings gate he went.
THe Iewes likewiſe in euery place
He tells her: bids her begge the liues
of all the Iewes o'th king.
AGainſt the law (ſhe ſaid it was)
Vncall'd: yet (ſhe thinkes) for that cauſe
the Lord had plac'd her there.
that they would faſt and pray,
She will doe ſo, and then (ſhee ſaith)

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: COſtly and royall robes put on,
ſhe in Kings ſight doth ſtand;
His Scepter which he held to her,
Though halfe my Kingdome thou demand,
King bids that Haman ſhould make haſt
FVll glad was Haman of this grace,
But Mordech's ſtourneſſe fill'd him full
GReat glory, wealth, and children ſtore,
HIs wife vnto; and to this friends,
Yeelds him no ioy, while Mordecai
IN friendly ſort his wife and friends,
And beg, that Mordoch' might be hang'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: The booke of records, where he findes
LEarning that he had no reward,
Kings royall robes, and that kings horſe
NObleſt Prince of the Kings Princes,
Haman did thinke this honor ſhould
Thus ſhall be done to euery man
whom King doth meane to grace.
