What things were done; ſhe then foretells
To haſten Haman to the feaſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: The King bids her aske what ſhe will,
ſhe ſure ſhould haue no nay.
That ſhe the life of all the Iewes,
and her owne life might ſaue.
THe King demands who ſought their liues,
She ſaid, this Haman: Haman then
VExed at heart to heare this thing,
he to the Queene did ſue:
Said, will he alſo force my Queene?
COmming in preſence of the King,
Said, a tree ſtood in Haman houſe
The King bids hang vp Haman there,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: Who giues to Eſter Hamans houſe;
That all decrees which Haman made,
Should in his name write to the Iewes
their foes to kill and ſlay.
HE then departing from the King,
With Crowne of gold vpon his head,
now all the Iewes are glad.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: IN that day when their foes did hope
The Iewes made hauocke of them all
KIng officers did helpe the Iewes,
Hamans ten ſonnes the Iewes hung vp,
LOe (ſaid the king) the Iewes haue ſlaine
What multitudes then haue they ſlaine
MOre men in Shuſhan then were ſlaine
Seuenty fiue thouſand in the whole,
NOw keepe the Iewes two ioyfull dayes,
Then preſents to their neighbours neere,
and gifts to th'poore are ſent.
ORdained here theſe two feaſt dayes,
both they and all their ſeed.
PVrim theſe ioyfull dayes are call'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: His glory, might and noble acts,
SEcond vnto the king he was,
He ſtill procur'd the peoples wealth

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AN vpright man, whoſe name was Iob,
in land of Vr did dwell,
BEhold the holy care he bad
His holineſſe and wond ous wealth
CVrſt Sathan came before the Lord,
DIſtreſt he is (by Gods good leaue)
and rob'd of all his wealth:
Yet was it greater griefe to him
Bleſt be the Lord that hath both giuen,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: good Iob to tempt and try,
From top to toe with ſores and boyles,
HIs wife that ſhould haue comforted,
Of all his vexers (next the Deuill)
ſhe ſeemes to be the chiefe.
that like a foole ſhe ſpake.
KNowing and hearing of this euill
Three friends come ſee him, but ſeuen dayes
they ſpake no words at all.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Iob cry'd, and thus did ſay,
Curſt be the night when I was borne,
MOſt dolefull mone be maketh ſtill,
As 〈◊〉 that d ••• did make • n end

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: As though to puniſh vpright men,
PI •••• d with 〈◊〉 , he ſaith that Iob,
QV ••• ing wh •• w •• his feare,
RA • ly he doth reproue him here,
• ob in the might to ſtrighted fore
SVch as may well bring downe the pride,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: doth ſhew and ſet forth plaine.
Which light vpon them all for want
ATtend vnto the power of God,
Bad men he plagues, but ſtill defends

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: His griefe feare 〈◊〉 for to be
COmplaine he did not without ca • ſt,
DEath is the thing he wiſheth for,
Therein he comfort hopes to finde,
Becauſe from them more griefe of heart

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: This Iob declares; and that it is
in length much like a ſpan.
both in the dayes and nights.
HE rather choſe to dye then liue,
To pardon it he asked God

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: IN ſharpe tearmes he is blam'd and checkt,
As if Iob by his ſpeeches had
KNowing that God doth deale with men
to proue it true pr • oceeds.
LEarne here the bane of Hypocrites
The righteous de aling of the Lord
If iuſt, he promiſeth that he

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: NOw is the iuſtice of the Lord,
ONe onely thing of thouſand things
And call him to a ſtrict account,
PLainly good Iob confutes his friends,
He ſaith that no man ſhould be iudg'd

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: QVite voyd of outward comforts all,
REſtleſſe he of his life complaines,
Some little eaſe he craues of God,
SEe here how Iob doth plainly ſay,
God doth him marke, and will not quit

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: THe ſpeech of Iob refelled is
Iob will be counted vile and baſe,
ALl words and workes God heares and ſees
Who would be wiſe; though borne at firſt
like yong aſſe colt ſo wilde.
BVt Zophar teacheth that the way
Is by repentance and true faith,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: that they are weake and naught.
which God had fram'd and made,
EVen all the ſpeeches of his friends,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: FOrgers of Lyes (he ſaith) they are,
HIs truſt and confidence in God,
IOb here affirmeth that the Lord
And that the Hypocryte ſhall come

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: KNowing the ſhortneſſe of mans life,
and death to be moſt ſure:
LIfe loſt can neuer be recall'd,
Yet he (ſtill waiting for his change)
and full of woe and paine;

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: Becauſe they had moſt falſly charg'd
SHewing that though men did condemne
Yet God was witneſſe of his cauſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: THus Iob appeales from men to God,
By wretched men; yet on the Lord
He ſaith he had no hope in life,
death ſtill was in his mind.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: Becauſe he did his friends aduiſe,
To be moſt fearefull; for the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: Of thoſe his cruell friends, from whom
he could no c ••• ort find.
FOr pity, twice he cals and cryes
GReat comfort yet at laſt he takes,
And haue eternall life in heauen
void of all griefe and paine.
HE then diſſwades thoſe friends of his
Leſt that the iudgements of the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: From Iob his words, which toucht him neare,
KNoweſt thou not (ſaith he to Iob)
LEarne how he doth confirme the ſame,
both by the word of God
And by his iuſtice, alſo by

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: MVch mou'd is Iob with Zophars words,
And therefore him and other friends
NOting vnto them all that he
had iuſt cauſe of his griefe;
Sith wicked men did flouriſh ſtill,
OBſerue how ſome doe proſper ſo
Some other come to wofull ends
POnder this well, that all muſt dye,
the beſt and eke the worſt.
Both yong and old, both rich and poore,
Where God will plague him for his ſinne,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: that Iob is plagu'd for ſinnes,
Mans goodneſſe doth not profit him,
Aſſuring him that then from God

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: ASſured of Gods loue to him,
and grieu'd at heart to heare
The chidings of his churliſh friends,
BEfore the Lord to be his iudge,
who though not ſeene with eyes,
Yet doth he ſee and well obſerue
our thoughts, our words, our wayes.
And that he in the lawes of God,
his time , and life had ſpent.
DOing what euer he doth pleaſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: Iob ſhewes what curſe to them belongs
Yet wormes muſt eate them in the graue,
both when and how he will:

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: Did ſtifly ſtand, and ſtill maintaine,
IN fight of God he ſaith no man
Can be accounted pure and cleane,
KNowne are the ſtarres to be impure
How much more than, a ſilly worme,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: LOe here how Iob, doth Bildads ſpeech
And doth confeſſe Gods mighty power,
MOſt infinite each kind of way,
His wondrous workes proclaime the ſame,
NO helpe therefore brings man to God,
He hath no power, nor no ſtrength
PLainly he doth reproue his friends,
That while he breath'd his tongue ſhould ſpeake
QVite rooted out ſhall bad men be,
both they, and all their race:
All mighty tyrants, and all ſuch
as lacke true faith and grace.

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: REad that a man things naturall
And giue a reaſon of ſuch things
SVch humane wiſedome man may haue,
It is a gift moſt excellent,
which God giues of his loue.
THis wiſedome is to feare the Lord,
and from all ill to flee

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: VNto his mind, when Iob doth call
A Bleſſing was vpon his houſe,
Both yong and old, both rich and poore,
BEcauſe he was eyes to the blind,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: Who (though he fed them all before)
He was the by-word and the ſong,

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: FVll fraught with vertue's faithfull Iob
Some of the ſame doth ſolemnly
GIuing no leaue vnto his eyes
to looke for feareſt of luſt:
in gold he put no truſt.
HE fed and cloath'd the fatherleſſe,
IN proſperous ſtate he was not proud,
Nor for the feare of mortall men,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: gainſt Iob , and his three friends,
His ſilence he by Iobs and theirs,
LEarne this from Elihu, that age
All diuine wiſedome doth from heauen
Marke how he checks for giuing Iob
His conſcience alſo forc'd him ſo

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: To reaſon here with patient Iob
He doth confute them euery one,
SEe here, how he inciteth Iob,
To marke his ſpeech, and if he will

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: in ſpeech to be too large;
Becauſe he did the Lord moſt iuſt,
Man therefore muſt ſubmit to him,
BEcauſe Iobs words did ſeeme vnwiſe,
God pulls downe proud and mighty men,
and ſets vp whom he loues.

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: Becauſe our goodneſſe, or our euill,
DAily men cry vnto the Lord,
• et are not heard, becauſe they want
and that in God he truſt:
And by the wondrous workes of God
that they are all moſt true.
HE ſheweth wherefore God doth plague,
• is becauſe that men are proud,
Or elſe he ſhould haue had both health
KNow here the guiſe of hypocrites,
Their liues are foule: they dye in youth,

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: LEarne here that God is to be fear'd,
euen for his workes of wonder:
As for his whirle windes, raine and ſnow
which no man can find out.
NOne without cauſe doth he afflict,
he wills vs ſinne to hate,
For he regards not any man,

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: and works wrought by him ſince.
POwerfull and mighty workes of his,
Proues Iob to be both ignorant
QVite deſtitute of might man is,

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: REad here the bounty of the Lord,
Read how the goats and aſſes wild,
SEe in the Vnicorne ſo ſtrong
Which teacheth vs in him to put
to th' horſe God giueth ſtrength,
By him the Hauke and Eagle flye,

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: That he is vile; and that to ſpeake
ALl power of man is very weake,
With Gods great works which he hath made,
which God did make and frame,
Thoſe bones are like to barres of braſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: Which ſheweth forth Gods mighty power
DAre any man (though fierce and ſtout)
once ſtirre him vp or moue;
Out of whoſe mouth goes ſparkes of fire,
This anſwer doth this good man Iob

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: GOd can doe all things (here Iob ſaith)
He doth ſubmit himſelfe to God,
HE for his friends doth prayers make,
He makes his friends ſubmit to him
who were ſo full of iarres.
So that he was made twice as rich
KNow his ſeuen ſonnes, and daughters three,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Preface this firſt Pſalme doth ſeeme
to be of all the reſt,
To ſtirre up all to godly life,
BEcauſe that all, who in the word
COntemners of God and his word,
Here for a time, yet they as chaffe
ſhall all be blowne to hell.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: that though his foes doe rage •
Yet God his kingdome will preſerue,
and that from age to age.
to Chriſt to bow and bend.
FOr though that wicked rulers rage,
and Gods yoke will not beare;
Yet he diſdaines and ſcornes their ſpite,
and makes them quake for feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GOod Dauid from his kingdome driuen,
For his great ſinne againſt the Lord,
HE calleth therefore on the Lord,
Againſt the terrours of his foes,
IN hope of helpe, he on the Lord
Euen then when nought but cruell death
KNowing the truth of Gods promiſe,
That God would plague his enemies,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: LEarne how when Saul did perſecute,
NO worldly wealth, nor earthly ioy
It is the fauour of the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: Dauid did call vpon the Lord,
PErſwading that it is moſt iuſt,
That he ſhould plague malicious men,
By comming to his holy houſe,
That when his cruell foes are brought
SEtting him free from all their force,
that God will doe no leſſe
To other men that feare his name

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: THe Prophet Dauid when he had,
And felt his hand againſt him ſore,
VNto the Lord with troubled ſoule,
• e ſhould deſtroy him, he could not
• od ſends him ioy and confidence
• o God to be his fence and aide,
• hewing that he againſt King Saul
FOr Gods glory he ſaith it makes
• gainſt ſuch men as neither God,
• e waxeth bold; and ſcornes the ſpite
HE threatneth them, that all that euill
Which they for good and godly men
• N ioyful wiſe vnto the Lord,
To praiſe and magnifie his name,
MVch wondring at his mercies great
who like God did him frame;
He ſaith, O Lord how excellent,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: NOw after Dauid had giuen thanks
Which God had giuen and granted him,
as he was wont to doe.
And turne the wicked into hell,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: REad how of fraud and tyranny,
and of all kinde of wrongs,
Which worldly men were wont to doe,
with hearts, or hands, or tongues.
And ſee the cauſe why ſuch bad men
THe cauſe is this, they are ſo drunke
That they deſpiſe all feare of God,
VNto the Lord he therefore calls,
that he ſome helpe would ſend
that had no grace to mend.
That he will ſuccour and defend

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: BEhold two parts in this ſame Pſalme,
he was, and griefe of minde,
When Saul did perſecute him ſore,
to whom God in his need,
Did alwayes helpe and ſuccour ſend,
who good and bad doth guide,
Who ruleth all the things that are

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: FVll ſore the Prophet here laments
When godly men are dead and gone,
HE then doth comfort both himſelfe
With full aſſurance of Gods helpe,
when they on him did call.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: And new aſſaults) doth flee to God:
LOng time did his afflictions laſt,
And yet his confidence in God
MAking the mercies of the Lord
NEw prayſes he will ſing to God

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: That they in heart perſwaded are
there is no God nor Sauiour.
PEruerſe they are in all their wayes,
They pray not , ſtill one ſinfull act
QVite void of all true feare of God,
• et he in heart perſwaded is

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: God did the Iewes ſo grace;
As for his people them to chooſe,
THe which was to th'intent that they
Might witneſſe to the world that they
Then doing well to other men

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: For ſuccour; not for his deſerts,
All Idols: yea their very names,
COnſent in heart, conſent in mouth,
of all Idolatries. An. Mundi Exod. 23.13. Epheſ. 5 3.
DEſiring that the Lord ſhould be
Who to his Church and choſen folke

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: Of Sauls great pride and cruelty,
Without all cauſe giuen on his part,
GOd to reuenge his righteous cauſe
And eke to rid him from their rage

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: And prayſe the Lord with all his heart
Who from ſo many perills brought
in all his warres and ſtrife:
Preſeruing him from all his foes,
LEarne further, that of Chriſts Kingdome,
Who in deſpite of all the world

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: MArke how the prophet to th' intent
of Gods great power and loue,
NOw ſetteth forth before their eyes
to be a God moſt kind.
Which by commending of this law,
is ſet forth in this place.

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: QVickly the people flee to God,
REqueſting him that it would pleaſe
Their King, and take his ſacrifice,
SAuing him from his cruell foes,
That he might ſaue and ſuccour ſend,
when they for ayd ſhould call.
THen he declares that heathen folke
But they truſt onely in his name,
But both the King and his people,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: AGainſt the cruell Ammonites, An. Mundi 1 Sam. 21
King Dauid and his people did
BY God and not by ſtrength of man,
In perſon of the people he,
CHriſt is the King to whom we are
By him the Kingdome of the Church

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: Hauing no feeling of his faith,
That he was forced night and day,
FVll long he fainted, yet at laſt,
in faith and hope he growes:
Chriſts figure in his perſon here,
GOd by the ſpirit of propheſie,
That Chriſts ſhould ſuffer for our ſakes,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: HAuing Gods mercies and his grace
That his great goodneſſe, and his loue,

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: KIng Dauid (when the grace of God)
MOuing all men to thinke vpon,
NOte that although the temple was
Yet onely they that purely liue

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: for ſinne, and with his foes,
By feruent prayer vnto the Lord,
PArdon he chiefly craues for ſinnes,
He did commit againſt the Lord,
REad how he doth begin each verſe
which in this Pſalms is ſet,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: SAul did good Dauid ſore oppreſſe,
He finding no helpe in the world,
Deſireth God to iudge his cauſe,
The power of God, and praiſe his name,
A Great deſire (he ſaith) he hath
When he was baniſhed by Saul,
That he ſhould ouercome them all,
DEſire he did a longer life,
To this end that he might praiſe God

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: To ſee the Lord by wicked men
FOr riddance of them, and for plagues
He cryes, and is at laſt aſſur'd
that God hath heard his call.
GOd was his ſtrength (he ſaith) and ſhield,
To whom he doth his people all
IN all the earth nought is ſo ſtout,
They breake the Cedars; cauſe both men
KNowne dreadfull yet although he be,
Becauſe he giues his people ſtrength,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: MArke how the Prophet Dauid here
Doth render thankes to God, who did
NOt ceaſing to exhort all men,
by him the like to learne,
And that the Lord is mercifull,
O Learne how ſoone his anger ſlakes,
That men from ioy, to aduerſe ſtate,
PErſwading this; he turnes to God,
And promiſeth to prayſe his name,

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: QVit, and ſet free from dangers great,
by ſorce of faith and prayer.
ROaring againſt him, when his foes,
When nothing but his very death,
SHewing to all that feare the Lord,
That Gods good fauour and his loue
THen he exhorts the faithfull all,
the Lord to ſerue and loue,
Becauſe he keepes them, as they might

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: The Prophet counts them bleſt to whom
ADdreſſing then his heart to God,
Bidding the wicked turne to God

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: For his creating heauen and earth,
with all things in this world.
and makes the proud to rue.
No ſtrength of man nor creature
can keepe out of his hands.
GOod men that put their confidence
Shall be preſerued from their foes,

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: HEre learne how after Dauid had,
eſcaped Achiſh King, An. Mundi 1 Sam. 21,11.1.
He praiſeth God with all his heart
IN like ſort (as he praiſeth God)
To truſt in God; to feare his name,
KNowing that he doth ſtill defend,
The Angels pitch their tents about,

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: MArke how while Saul, to good Dauid
Their cruell hate and malice great
O How he prayeth God to plead
That in the Snares they laid for him,
PAying them home, as they deſeru'd,
QVite quit likewiſe that they might be,
And that they might yeeld praiſe and thankes
to God with voyce and heart.
It will Gods Iuſtice and his power
Which he to all his creatures,
VEry well weighing in his minde,
the loue that he did beare
To all his children which doe ſerue
BOldly he then praies for the iuſt,
• nd ſaith the wicked ſhall fall downe,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 7
lg.l: • hen as they ſee the wicked men
• o ſee the godly to be grieu'd,
• et are they in Gods fauour ſtill,
FOr he preſerueth all ſuch men,
and frees them from the rage
• f wicked and blood thirſty men,
GReat glory though theſe wicked ones,
• hey doe enioy them but a while,
their ioyes are ſhort and vaine.
HAted they are of God and man,
to the pit of endleſſe woe,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 8
lg.l: IN bed of ſickneſſe Dauid laid,
•• ſay that God did him chaſtiſe
He vttereth the cauſe and griefe,
which made him for to mourne.
LAmenting ſore, he in theſe words
That he was hated of his friends,
MArke how the arrowes of Gods wrath
That he complaines he had no reſt,
nor eaſe on day nor night.
NOte yet how he in confidence,
To God; and hopes that he ſhall haue

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: OH how doth paines, care, griefe of heart,
and not a word to ſpeake,
QVaint and ſtrange-ſuits he here doth make
And that he wondrouſly did ſtriue

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: SEt free from many dangers great,
The grace and fauour of the Lord,
And promiſeth to ſerue him ſtill,
VNto vs all he then ſets downe
AFter all this he praiſeth God,
Then with good courage he doth •• ll

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: The Pſalmiſt doth pronounce him bleſt
Who of great friendſhip made a ſhew,
DAuid himſelfe had ſuch ſide •• nds,
but yet it may be laid
Of Chriſt more truely, who with kiſſe
by Iudas was ••••• aid. An. Mundi Iohn. 13.1 •
FRom humble hear • all laid and praiſe,
Deſiring that he may be bleſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: GReat mo •• n • good Dauid maketh here,
Becauſe hee was by cruell foes,
In body, yet his heart and mind
was with him night and day.
In th' end he ſheweth that he was
But that his confidence did ſtill

lg.head: Chapt. 43
lg.l: By humble prayer to the Lord,

That with his
〈◊〉 and ſhining light
and will wait on him ſtill.

lg.head: Chapt. 44
lg.l: With which he did his children deare
OBſerue how they with griefe complaine,
His former • auo •• and his loue
Becauſe that for his ſake their foes
did make of them a prey.
SHewing that to the great contempt
of his moſt holy ha •• e,
They did re • ound, they him intreat

lg.head: Chapt. 45
lg.l: His honour, be ••• ie, and renowne,
And ſhe is bleſt if ſhe forſake
Chriſts kingdome and the Gentiles Church

lg.head: Chapt. 46
lg.l: BEhold here is a Pſa ••• of ioy,
T'aſſwage the rage of wicked men

lg.head: Chapt. 47
lg.l: are all men of the world,
With true and vpright hearts t'adore
FRee fauour which he alwayes had
And to his ſeede the ſame i • here
GReat thankes and praiſe he bids them yeeld
Of Chriſts Kingdome in Goſpels time
The name of God is magnifi'd▪
When they did ••• bly ſeeke to him

lg.head: Chapt. 49
lg.l: LEarne how all dweller; on the earth
To thinke vpon the life of man
MEn mightie rich 〈◊〉 not the men,
The godly therefore are to feare
NOte how the Prophet Dauid here
this to their minde doth bring,
That Gods good pr ••••• ce doth rule
O See how after death he plagues
And how he crownes his owne with ioyes

lg.head: Chapt. 50
lg.l: With outward worſhips to he ſelu'd
QVite careleſſe of the inward heart,
REad how the Prophet Dauid here
And ſaith, that it is praiſe and thankes
to God procu • e and get,
for theſe the Lord doth call.

lg.head: Chapt. 51
lg.l: The ſame to God he doth confeſſe
that he in ſinne was borne,
TO all that ſhould liue after him
VNto the Lord he then doth pray,
his ſinne to blot out quite,
And that he would renew in him
A Promiſe then he makes to God,
that he will doe his beſt
To teach all 〈◊〉 thoſe good wayes
The Lord would puniſh for his faults,
But rather that he would increaſe,
and bleſſe it more and more.
ESteeming neither God nor m • n,
hee cauſ'd Gods Prieſts be ſlaine;
FIrme confidence he bids good m • n
in God their Lord to haue,

Whoſe iudgement •
〈◊〉 other foes ſhall ſeale,
but them he ſtill will ſaue.
GReat thankes he laſtly giues to God,

lg.head: Chapt. 53
lg.l: (Who ſay in heart there is no God)
they ſeeke not God nor pray;
They are corrupt, not one doth good,
KIndled againſt them i • Gods wrath,
But Dauid prayeth that good men,

lg.head: Chapt. 54
lg.l: • y Ziphims; alſo then from God
MAking requeſt that all his foes,
he would cut off and ſlay;
as long as he ſhall liue.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 5
lg.l: OBſerue how Dauid when he was
REad how (as though he had obtain'd
The louing fauour of the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 56
lg.l: SEe here how Dauid being brought
vnto the King of G • th, An. Mundi 2 Sam. 12.21.
in God ſure hope he hath.
THen he ſets downe the crueltie,
that ſought to haue his life.
VExing him ſtill he ſaith that God
His teares had regiſtred and put
That he will pay thoſe vowes to him
BRiefe ſumme whereof, was, that as God
So in his Church he will ſet forth

lg.head: Chapt. 57
lg.l: COme read how Dauid to the Lord
with faith doth cry and call,
When men at Ziph did him betray
EVer he truſts that God will ſhew
In heauen and earth, againſt his foes
FOr which he promiſeth to praiſe

lg.head: Chapt. 58
lg.l: GReat hatred in his deadly foes
did alwaies on him f • owne.
HIs bane in bloody wife they ſought
Vnto the Lord, who in due time
IN God (ſaith he) the iuſt ſhall ioy
That to the glory of the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 59
lg.l: KIng Dauid here a p • a ••• make •
By cruell Saul, who ſeruants ſent
to ſlay him in his bed,
LAmenting firſt he ſhewes to God
And then of his moſt furious foes
Vpon all thoſe that ſinne commit
NOting that though ſuch men doe liue
To try his people, yet he will
That he the God, of Iacob is,
whom he will alwaie a praiſe
QVelling them all, which thing did ſhew
He ſaith, they all ſhall proſper well,
RIght heartily he praies, that ſith
the Lord the thing had done,
He would vouchſafe to finiſh well

lg.head: Chapt. 61
lg.l: SOre danger was the Prophet in,
THen he for helpe doth call and cry
That he would be his ſtrong defence
When he hath foyl'd his enemies,

lg.head: Chapt. 62
lg.l: A Part of this Pſalme doth containe,
Stirring him vp to truſt in God
BIdding all people truſt in God,
and not in things are vaine:
COnfeſſing that all power is Gods,
He ſaith he will reward all men

lg.head: Chapt. 63
lg.l: DAuid after that he had beene
By cruell Saul, who him purſued
EVen then this Pſalme he eſemes to make,
His thankes to God for ſauing him
And of the happy ſtate of thoſe
that on the Lord ſhall call.

lg.head: Chapt. 64
lg.l: HEre are moſt hearty praiers made
Againſt the falſe reports of them
and all the ſpight they can;
KNow yet that Dauid in this Pſalme
That God will ſtrike them ſuddenly,
to plague he will not ſpare.
ſhall good men be and iuſt,
All ſhall be glad and much reioyce
that in the Lord doe truſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 65
lg.l: MArke here a Pſalme of praiſe to God,
NOt plaging them as they deſeru'd,
He did them chuſe, p • eſerue, and rule,
O How they praiſe him for his gifts
But chiefly for his wondrous loue
which to his Church he ſhowed

lg.head: Chapt. 66
lg.l: PRaiſes to yeeld vnto the Lord,
His workes, the Prophet doth exhort
all that on earth doe dwell.
QVickly the Lords moſt mightie power
That all ſtout rebells he thereby
SVre promiſe here he makes to God
And calleth all that feare the Lord
THen bids all holy ones to come
What God had done for his poore ſoule,
what loue he ſtill did beare

lg.head: Chapt. 67
lg.l: VNto the Lord the Church doth pray
And that with his ſweet countenance
ALl her ſuites are to this end made
that Gods wayes might be knowne,
And that to Iewes and Gentiles all
BLeſt Kingdome he of God, declares,
Throughout the world at his comming,

lg.head: Chapt. 68
lg.l: COme ſee how Dauid ſetteth forth,
as in a Glaſſe moſt cleare,
Th' exceeding mercies of the Lord
DEclaring how by all good meanes
To be a iudge of widowes cauſe,
Of worldly things the Church of God,
GRanting and finding this moſt true,
All men to praiſe and magnifie

lg.head: Chapt. 69
lg.l: HEre Dauid as a type of Chriſt,
with zeale and griefe of mind.
IN cruell ſort he vexed was,
Did giue him for his meat and drinke,
KNow here their puniſhments ſet downe,
where all his foes are durſt:
MVch more regarded is ſuch prayſe
NOw therefore he prouokes the heauens,
the earth and • ke the Seas,
To laud the Lord, and then of Chriſt
OF all his Churches he hath eare,
in which who ſhall liue well,
(Euen all the faithfull and their ſeed)

lg.head: Chapt. 70
lg.l: PVt to confuſion that his foes
may bee with haſt and ſpeed,
and to be helpt at need.
QViet peace that all godly men,
He of the Lord muſt earneſtly

lg.head: Chapt. 71
lg.l: And promiſe, that he in his need,
SVre truſt he had from his yong yeares,
Which he in his diſtreſſe and feares
THe malice of his foes was great,
And prayes that Gods good grace and loue,
VNto him then he thanks will giue,
He ſaith that he in thankfull ſort,

lg.head: Chapt. 72
lg.l: Vnder whom ſhall be happy peace,
BY iuſtice ſhall he rule and raigne,
Shall doe their homage vnto him,
CHriſts name and power ſhall firme endure,
In him all nations of the world

lg.head: Chapt. 73
lg.l: Nor yet the afflictions of the iuſt
And that we ſhould conſider well
FOr his owne folke, which thing ſhould cauſe
Doe quickly periſh, and in pit
HIm with his counſell God will guide,
After a while to glory great,
IN hope whereof with full conſent
Himſelfe into the hands of God

lg.head: Chapt. 74
lg.l: KNow that the faithfull make to God,
For the deſtruction of the Church
MVch truſt yet all the faithfull haue
both in Gods power and loue,

Which he did after promiſe
• them
and they full oft did proue.
NOting this well they ſuccour craue,
For the ſaluation of his Saints,

lg.head: Chapt. 75
lg.l: OBſerue how here the faithfull praiſe
the name of God the Lord,
Who will at his appointed time,
Moſt certainly muſt drinke each one,
QVite then abated ſhall their pride,
But godly men ſhall be aduanc'd

lg.head: Chapt. 76
lg.l: When they in Salem by their foes,
STouteſt he then did make to ſtoope,
All thoſe that roſe againſt his Church,
And thankfull to this mighty God

lg.head: Chapt. 77
lg.l: VNto the Lord in Churches name
The Prophet ſhewes , which makes him thinke
AForetime how he call'd on God
And (being heard) how he did ſing
BY that ſame conſtant courſe of God,
His truſt in God is ſtrengthened,

lg.head: Chapt. 78
lg.l: CHriſts Church from out of Abrahams ſeed
whom he did loue ſo deare,
yet in this ſeed was found;
EVill liues of fathers Dauid here
That ſo their children might be drawne
to hate and ſhun the ſame.
FOr all that God both led and fed,
and gaue to them his Law:
Yet ſires and ſonnes did ſtill rebell,
HAſtily they then flee to God,
With griefe of heart , and are in hope
IN this perſwaſion they are brought

Was ioyned with the great
• contempt
And that they will performe the ſame

lg.head: Chapt. 80
lg.l: would ſend his helpe and aide.
MAking it like vnto a vine,
Which wicked men like cruell boares,
did ſeeke to bring to nought.
NOw he deſires their firſt eſtate
that God would haue in minde,
When as his face did ſhine on them,
and when he was moſt kinde.
OLd fauour here he prayeth for,
That worke he had ſo well begun,
euen for his owne names ſake.

lg.head: Chapt. 81
lg.l: to praiſe with voice and heart
The Lord for all his benefits
QVickly come O my people deare,

And I will fill you
• full (ſaith God)
let all falſe Gods be gone.
REad here how hee condemnes them all
And ſhewes what good things they had loſt

lg.head: Chapt. 82
lg.l: SEe here how God is ſaid to be
THen faithfully he bids them deale,
He ſtiles them Gods; but plainly ſees,
that none of them did mend.
VNto the Lord then Dau • d doth
That he himſelfe would iudge the earth,

lg.head: Chapt. 83
lg.l: and from thoſe foes were neare,
But how the people of the Lord
Might as before he vs'd to doe
be ſtrucke with ſtormes and woes.
DEaling ſo that they might well know
that God is moſt of might,
And that no power can preuaile

lg.head: Chapt. 84
lg.l: He here deſires he might againe
FOr bleſt he counts them that may come
To ſerue the Lord; he doth bewaile
GReatly he prayſeth all them here,
that walke from ſtrength to ſtrength,
And are not weary till they come
to Gods owne houſe at length.

lg.head: Chapt. 85
lg.l: HIs people freed from captiue ſtate,
Becauſe that they did ſtill tranſgreſſe
IN humble wiſe they aske him then
They pray him for his mercies ſake
They reſt in hope, reioyce in heart,

lg.head: Chapt. 86
lg.l: quite to be freed from thrall.
MAking his moane to God, he doth
The name of God, whereto his heart
OF ſuch as ſought to ſlay his ſoule
He doth complaine, and prayes to be,

lg.head: Chapt. 87
lg.l: PRomiſe is made here to the Church
That God would her reſtore againe
That there among her members true,

lg.head: Chapt. 88
lg.l: REad here what mone the Prophet makes
SOre troubeled as left of God,

He cals vpon
• him, ſtriues by faith

lg.head: Chapt. 89
lg.l: THe Prophet here in many words,
Which he with his elect hath made,
VNto the Lord he then complaines
To Dauids Kingdome, euen to all
AS if Gods promiſe had beene broke,
He prayeth therefore to be freed
BVt at the laſt he mention makes
of mans fraile life and ſhort;

lg.head: Chapt. 90
lg.l: COme heare the prayer Moſes makes,
in which the Lords great loue,
Which he hath borne vnto his ſaints,
DEclared is, yet mans ſhort life
Him to be thankfull; nor Gods plagues
And to be mercifull to them,

lg.head: Chapt. 91
lg.l: FRom hurt protected are th' elect
Who onely put their truſt in God,
GOds promiſe here is made to all,
that in true loue doe liue;
The Angells muſt attend them here,
and heauen he will them giue.
HE need not feare the peſtilence,
the plague ſhall not come neere
His houſe, and when he calls on God,

lg.head: Chapt. 92
lg.l: INſpir'd of God the Prophet makes
To moue the people all day long
To know that when they flouriſh moſt
LEarne here the ſtate of righteous m • n
They planted are in Gods owne houſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 93
lg.l: MArke how the Prophet prayſeth here
In the creating of this world,
NOte how he beateth downe the pride
Obſerue what doth become Gods houſe,
QVickly that God would puniſh them
He warnes them of his plagues, that they
might feare and ſinne no more.
SVre ſhelter from the Lord they find,
Whereas the wicked go to wracke,

lg.head: Chapt. 95
lg.l: all men to praiſe the Lord,
Both for his goodneſſe and his power
VNto his name all praiſes due
To be his owne peculiar flocke
that they ſhould not be bold

lg.head: Chapt. 96
lg.l: CHriſts Goſpell was to be reueal'd
The Prophet therefore ſtirs them vp
DEclaring that ſith this is done
After his will they ſhould him ſerue,
to God all praiſe is due;
He comes to iudge moſt righteouſly

lg.head: Chapt. 97
lg.l: FOr Chriſt his Kingdome and comming
The Prophet bids all ſorts of men
GReat dread and terror he doth bring
His furious fire goes him before,
HE ioyfull tidings brings to thoſe
that ſeeke to doe his will,
to loue and feare him ſtill.
IN like ſort he exhorts the iuſt
To thanke him for his benefits

lg.head: Chapt. 98
lg.l: KNowing the Lords moſt mighty power,
LOuing his Church, in dangers great
He keepeth faith and promiſe made
To all beleeuers in the world,

lg.head: Chapt. 99
lg.l: NOte how the power and equity
Of Gods Kingdome, by Ieſus Chriſt
OVer both Iewes and Gentiles all,
To praiſe his name, and to ſubmit
As Moſes, Aaron, and the like,
〈◊〉 in the prayers which they made

lg.head: Chapt. 100
lg.l: RIght cheerfully to ſing and praiſe,
The Prophet Dauid bids all men
that liue here in this world.
SEeing he did vs make and chooſe
And kept vs from our enemies,
and freed vs from all feare.
THat we into his gates and courts
And for his laſting mercies might

lg.head: Chapt. 101
lg.l: VNto the Lord good Dauid will
Shewing what order he will keepe,
when he ſhall rule as King.
AN vpright man euen in his houſe,
BVt vpright men that faithfull are,
He will regard and cheriſh ſtill,
ſuch men with him ſhall dwell.

lg.head: Chapt. 102
lg.l: this Pſalme doth reach to pray
That God would helpe them in diſtreſſe •
DOwne from the higheſt heauens he ſees
And in due time doth ſend his folke
EXcit • d thereby are his ſaints,

lg.head: Chapt. 103
lg.l: To praiſe his name who pardons ſinne
He gaue him ſtore of earthly things
IN louing ſort as fathers deare
KNow here the frailtie of mans life,
his dayes like graſſe and flowers;
But vnto them that feare the Lord
LOe how the Angels are ſtir'd vp
Marke how his ſeruants and himſelfe

lg.head: Chapt. 104
lg.l: Gods making of this world ſo wide,
with all his workes of worth.
NOte how he ſtirreth vp his ſoule
OBſerue how Dauid here doth pray
Who are the cauſe why God from vs

lg.head: Chapt. 105
lg.l: Vnto the Lord, and for his loue
to feare him as their King.
QVickly to ſeek him in his workes,
His loue, his care, and prouidence
His loue to Ioſeph and Iacob,
THen ſee how through the Wilderneſſe
And how full forty yeares from heauen
Theſe things and more thou in this Pſalme

lg.head: Chapt. 106
lg.l: ATtend how that the Pſalmiſt doth
The Lord for all his mercies great,
To be againe brought to their land
CAlling to mind the wonders great,
DEuoutly they pray to be brought
That they might in their countrey praiſe
the Lord with heart and tongue.

lg.head: Chapt. 107
lg.l: are all both young and old,
That are redeemed by the Lord,
FOr many mercies to giue thankes
Who ruleth all things; and is ſtill
GOod things and ill he ſends to men,
that he might winne them ſo;
he ſends both wealth and woe.
HEreat as good and vpright men
Soe ſhall all ill mens mouthes be ſtopt,

lg.head: Chapt. 108
lg.l:
IN this Pſalme theſe things
• are contain'd
With heart prepared and with tongue,
KNowing his promiſe to be ſure
That he ſhould be the King thereof,
LEarne that although God for a time
Yet will he fight againſt his foes,

lg.head: Chapt. 109
lg.l: By flatterers; he prayes that God
NOw here of Iudas he doth ſpeake,
And eke of all ſuch traytrous foes
to be ſet free from thrall,
That euen his enemies might know
that God doth worke it all.
PRaiſes he then will giue to God

lg.head: Chapt. 110
lg.l: Of Chriſt, our Prophet, Prieſt and King
REad how Herod of his great power
Read how the Lord an oath hath made
SEe how of Leuies Prieſthood here
See how that Chriſt our king ſhall rule,

lg.head: Chapt. 111
lg.l: THe Pſalmiſt ſtirreth all men vp
To praiſe the Lord for his great workes,
and for his loue and care
VNto his Church and children ſhew'd
With all things fitting for this life,
ANd then he doth declare wherein

lg.head: Chapt. 112
lg.l: BLeſt is that man (the Pſalmiſt ſaith)
to whom his lawes are deare.
CVrſt is the ſtate of all thoſe men
They ſhall be grieued at the good,
And of this life and that to come

lg.head: Chapt. 113
lg.l: to ſtirre vp our dull ſenſe
To magnifie the name of God
FOr that he workes quite contrary
In ſauing of the Church from harme
GOD made vs for that very end
that we his name ſhould praiſe,
Who makes the barren women beare,
and poore mans ſtate doth raiſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 114
lg.l: HEare how the Iſraelites were brought
Obſerue the wonders that were wrought
IN that the Sea in Iordan fled,
The Rocke gaue water, earth did quake,
the Hils did leape like Lambes.
KNow therefore that we are to keepe
Who when the courſe of nature failes

lg.head: Chapt. 115
lg.l: LEarne how the Church doth beg of God
To be preſeru'd, and Tyrants all
And truſt in God moſt conſtantly
that they his helpe ſhall haue,
NOt doubting thereof at their need,
O How the godly are ſtir'd vp
to truſt in God their ſhield,
Who gaue the earth to ſonnes of men,
PRomiſe is made that they will praiſe
If he will free them from their foes,

lg.head: Chapt. 116
lg.l: QVite freed from danger and diſtreſſe
who gaue him peace and reſt.
REſolu'd he is to yeeld to him
To walke with him, to pay his vowes,
SEe here the care Iehouah hath
of all that doe him feare;
Their death is precious in his ſight,
as of his Saints moſt deare.

lg.head: Chapt. 117
lg.l: And all the people of the world
VNto them all as well as to
The promiſe made of life in Chriſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 118
lg.l: A Long time Dauid (tipe of Chriſt)
As alſo of his people all,
BVt at the time which God had ſet,
For which he bids all fearing God,
CHriſt Ieſus King, and his kingdome,

lg.head: Chapt. 119
lg.l: With this ſame Pſalme, and ſhewes wherein
EVen in the ſtudy of Gods will,
In faith and confidence in God,
who ſaues all ſuch from ſhame.
And to be kept from ghoſtly foes
his fleſh, the world, and ſinne,
He prayes for grace whereby he may
And of the goodneſſe of his cauſe,
IN faith he then commends to God
Of future life to Gods glory,
KNow that the Pſalmiſt here exhorts
all men their liues to frame
According to the Word of God,
and ſo be ſafe from ſhame.
LEarne here wherein his ſeruice true,
When as we ſerue him as he bids,

lg.head: Chapt. 120
lg.l: MArke here the Prayer Dauid makes
NO ſmall complaint and moane he makes,
In Meſheck and the Kedar tents
OBſerue what he by Meſheck meanes
Euen Iſraelites who now were full

lg.head: Chapt. 121
lg.l: PEruſe this Dauids Pſalme, for it
That onely from the God of power
they ought for helpe • o call.
QVite deſtitute of bu ••• nt helpe.
And all the members of the ſame,
His truſt in God, how he commits

lg.head: Chapt. 122
lg.l: In name of all the faithfull flock
THe ſtate of City, Kingdome, Church
God to them all would ••• d •
As wealth, and peace, and what thing elſe

lg.head: Chapt. 123
lg.l: A Faithfull praier here is made
By wicked worldling h •• ing them,
BEhold they lift their eyes to God,
That he would eaſe them of their foes,
This makes them ſeeke vnto the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 124
lg.l: That they were ſa • 'd not by their force
EXcept the Lord had ſaued them,
and ſtood on their right hand,
They ſay they had beene quite diſpatcht
they had no power to ſtand.
the name of God they praiſe,
And are aſſured of his helpe,

lg.head: Chapt. 125
lg.l: GOds loue and care ouer his Church
HOw ſhort alſo their troubles are,
he prayes that God, would giue
IN iuſtice he deſires the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 126
lg.l: KNow that this Pſalme King Dauid made
LIke dreamers were theſe captiues then,
to ſee ſo great a change.
MElodious mirth was in their mouthes,
their tongues were fill'd with ioy,
They pray that God would free them ſtill

lg.head: Chapt. 127
lg.l: NOte that the Pſalmiſt plainly proues
ON Gods meere prouidence and will
Mens words and purpoſes are vaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 128
lg.l: To all men, but to thoſe alone
REad how ſuch men are bleſt of God
In wiues and children which like vines,
They ſhall the wealth of Salem ſee,

lg.head: Chapt. 129
lg.l: yet nought at all to feare.
VNder the croſſe the Church hath beene,
Yet by the mighty power of God,
the Lord hath made them rue.

lg.head: Chapt. 130
lg.l: His patience alſo in his hope
CRying to God in deepe diſtreſſe,
The Lord in mercy heares his ſute,
and frees him from them all.
He will redeeme his people all,

lg.head: Chapt. 131
lg.l: Did ſay that Dauid proudly ſought
in God to hope and reſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 132
lg.l: The faithfull pray to God that he
the ſame to paſſe would bring.
HEre Dauids great and godly zeale
IN the remouing of the Arke
to him and to his ſeed.

lg.head: Chapt. 133
lg.l: KIng Dauid plainly here ſets downe
And eke the benefit that comes
Euen that which ſignifies to vs,
our head Chriſt oyle of grace.
MOunt Hermons dew this loue is like
Who liue in loue and concord thus
the Lord doth bleſſe them all.

lg.head: Chapt. 134
lg.l: NOw Dauid bids the Leuites all
To praiſe the Lord, becauſe they were
OBſerue their charge, which was, that they
And alſo ſhould both pray and praiſe
POwer they had and charge to praiſe
Power they had, and charge likewiſe

lg.head: Chapt. 135
lg.l: QVickned to praiſe the name of God
Of all eſtates, both for his power,
SEe how the heatheniſh Idols all
THen he againe exhorts all men
Gods name to praiſe and bleſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 136
lg.l: VNto the Lord all praiſe to yeeld
And for the ruling of all things,
all things from Gods good hand;
our thankes and praiſe doe ſtand.
to him from them is due.

lg.head: Chapt. 137
lg.l: Their griefe to ſee Gods truth decay
DAyly they liu'd in anguiſh great
With taunts, reproaches, mocks and ſcoffs
That God would plague the Edomites
FOr ioyning with that Babels brood
Of whoſe deſtruction in this Pſalme

lg.head: Chapt. 138
lg.l: GReat courage doth the Prophet vſe
HIs goodneſſe to him was ſo great,
Euen forraine Princes which with him
IN time to come he is aſſur'd
As he had done in former times
from his good God ſo kind.

lg.head: Chapt. 139
lg.l: KIng Dauid for to clenſe his heart
Doth ſhew that nothing can be hid
LYing him downe or riſing vp,
his thoughts, each deed and word,
Yea all his pathes, his walkes and wayes
MAn cannot hide himſelfe from God,
his hand will find him out;
The darkeſt night is as noone day
NOte how he doth confirme all this
• s zeale and feare of God he ſhewes,
OF all that vp againſt the Lord,
QVickly he hath recourſe to God
• d is aſſured that the Lord
will grant him peace and reſt.
due pray'rs to God to yeeld,
•• d to aſſure themſelues that he
will be their fence and ſhield.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 41
lg.l: • d then by prayer vnto God
THen he deſireth God, that he
• nd giue him patience to endure
VNtill the time was fully come

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 42
lg.l: when he was in the caue,
That from the cruell rage of Saul
the Lord his life would ſaue.
BEhold that neither mou'd with hate,
Of preſent death, nor was he forc'd
CRuelly then to kill his King,

lg.head: Chapt. 143
lg.l: DAuid doth in this Pſalme intreat
That all his ſinnes he would quite blot
Yet he confeſſeth all was done
FRom all ſuch foes to be ſet free
And that the Lord would him reſtore
GOds teaching he deſires to haue,
That he may lead a godly life,

lg.head: Chapt. 144
lg.l: and with a heart moſt ſound
of all his foes in field.
KEeping him ſafe, and placing him
• e craues Gods aid, and that he would
LArge promiſes to God he makes
With Pſalmes and fongs, of thankes and praiſe,
Who haue Iehouah for their God

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 45
lg.l: NOte that King Dauid then doth make

•
• uling man, and all things elſe
• ut to the iuſt doth euermore
that he would praiſe his name,
• nd that all fleſh for euermore

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 46
lg.l: • e zeale he had to prayſe the Lord
for his great loue and care.
SIng praiſes during life he will;
In Princes nor in ſonnes of men,
TRuſt onely in the Lord ſaith he,
VNto the blind who giueth ſight,
Who for the ſauing of his Church,

lg.head: Chapt. 147
lg.l: A Pſalme of praiſe here Dauid makes,
For he doth build it, though thereof
Feeding the Rauens when they cry,
A bleſſing which he hath not giuen

lg.head: Chapt. 148
lg.l: to prayſe the Lord of might,
Angells in heauen, men on the earth,
and ſtarres that ſhine ſo bright.
FOr he c • eated them of nought,
The Pſalmiſt doth prouoke his Church
When he had ioyn'd them to himſelfe,

lg.head: Chapt. 149
lg.l: HEre Dauid doth exhort Gods Church
Their hearts to ſing new ſongs to God
IOyfull he bids his ſaints to be,
they ſtill ſhould praiſe the Lord.
ſhall all be bound in chaines,

lg.head: Chapt. 150
lg.l: LEarne laſtly how the Prophet bids
all men the Lord to prayſe,
and by all meanes and wayes.
MOſt mighty acts and wondrous workes
wrought both by ſea and land,
In heauen and in the firmament,
doe craue this at our hand.
NOte that with ſound of inſtruments,
He bids them praiſe him, though (ſince Chriſt)
BY Wiſedome here complaint is made
And therefore when they cry for helpe,
ſhe will not heare their call.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: CRy for knowledge, as ſiluer feeke
This will thee keepe in holy wayes
The vpright ſhall dwell in the land,
He bids vs giue, loue, be content,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: GOod doctrine did my Parents teach,
To ſhun the bad, to keepe my heart,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: HOny , and worme wood harlots are,
their ſteps take hold of hell:
Sinne ſinners ſlayes; be thou content
with thine owne wife to dwell.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: Of primire learne; the law is light:
KEepe Parents lore, and then the Lord
yea his owne ſoule doth kill.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: LAy vp my wiſdome; marke, abhorre
Young fooles they doe ſeduce and kill;
ô come not neere their doores.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: Her excellence, which was of old,
NO gold nor rubies like to her,
they bleſt that loue her waies:
Who hate her, hate their owne poore ſoules:
God will cut off their dayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: Th' Adultreſſe ſaith ſtoln things are ſweet
her gueſts are deepe in hell.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: PRaters ſhall fall: of fooliſh ſonne:
The ſluggard ſent; the righteous hope,
ROt ſhall the name of ſinfull men;

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: SHame follows pride: falſe weights abhord:
in wrath no wealth will ſaue:
The wicked hopeleſſe: iuſt are bleſt:
Corn horders curſt: who truſts in wealth

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: A Good man gets Gods fauour ſtill;
Good women are their husbands crowne;
the iuſt not mou'd from peace.
BY til • h a man is ſatisfied:
The wicked ſnared by his words:
CAre makes the heart of man to ſtoop:
True dealers are the Lords delight;
the bad are full of ſtrife.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: The ſluggard wants; the iuſt hate lyes:
ſome rich will not bee ſo:
The wickeds l • mpe ſhall be put out:
A death to ſinners, ſinne to leaue,
the rod thou muſt not ſpare:
The poore mans tillage brings him food:
the iuſt right well ſhall fare.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: HE feareth God that walkes vpright;
wiſe wife her houſe doth build;
IN laughter oft times hearts are ſad;
Knowledge not hard to prudent men;
KNowledge doth crowne the prudent man;
the houſe of good men bleſt;
Wayes ſeeming good, oft wayes of death:
LIfe of the fleſh a ſound heart is;
fooles make a mock of ſinne:
Backſliders fall'n in their owne wayes;
MAny a friend the rich man hath;
who's ſlow to wrath is wiſe:
Gods feare preſerues from ſnares of death;

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: NO ill or good, but God beholds;
Wiſe tongues doe vſe their knowledge right;
OF righteous houſe where treaſure is:
Of meales of hearbs (where loue is) heare
PRoud mans dwelling God will deſtroy▪
Of ſloathfull men: words in ſeaſon:
the wiſe heare checks of life.
QVite from the wicked God's remou'd;

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: REferre thy workes vnto the Lord,
The wicked made for day of euill;
STeps God directs: ill purg'd by truth:
by Gods feare we leaue ſinne:
When we pleaſe God, our foes are friends;
TRue weights are Gods; Kings wrath as death:
Happy is he who truſts in God,
Gray head a crowne; lot's rul'd by God,
thereby contention ends. An. Mundi Chap: 18.18.

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: A Morſell better then good cheare:
who mocks the poore, reprocheth God;
BEware of ſtrife: a precious gift:
who hides a fault is lou'd:
No ſtripes will win a foole; the wiſe
COunted for wiſe, is ſilent foole,
Who frees the bad, the Lord abhors:

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: The ſloathfull as a great waſter:
God is our tower at hand.
EVen before Princes gifts will bring;
Lot ends contentions; ſome friends loue,
FInding good wife, thou find'ſt Gods loue:
A brother angred, hard to winne;

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: wealth ſtore of friends will win:
Both lyer, and falſe witneſſe plagu'd:
HE loues his ſoule that wiſdome gets:
Great glory to paſſe by offence;
good wife is from the Lord:
Who pitties poore. God will repay:
KEepe thou the law and keepe thy ſoule:
Bad teaching heare not, ſcorners ſmite,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: LOue not much ſleepe, be no deceiu'd
A King prouoke not; ceaſe from ſtrife:
MAke warre with counſell: ſluggards beg:
whoſe heart is pure from blame?
NO eare nor eye but God hath made:
a child's knowne by his deeds:
The lips of knowledge precious pearles:
OEat not that which holy is:
Lands got in haſt, in th' end are curſt;
PLagu'd ſhall the Parents curſer be:
Gray head doth grace; Kings throne preſeru'd

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: QVite deſtroy'd ſhall the robbers be:
Kings heart the Lord doth guide:
He ponders hearts: high looks are ſinne:
RIght are the workes of righteous men:
goods got by lyes bring death:
SOre dwelling with a brawling wife:
Who erre ſhall die; fooles waſt their wealth:
who keepes his tongue is wiſe.
No counſell is againſt the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: VNto the wiſe, bow eare and heart,
The wiſe foreſees, and ſaues from euill;
A Child will keepe good leſſons taught:
Caſt out the ſcorner, ſtrife ſhall ceaſe;
know that thou muſt not ſweare.
BY rod childs follie's driuen away;

No
• ſurety bee: no bounds remoue▪

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: The cauſe of Orphans God will pleade;
fooles care not what you ſay.
childs ſoule from hell ſet free:
Enuy not ſinners, feare thou God:
EVer buy truth, but ſell it not:
my ſonne giue me thy heart:

For whores, and wine as
• ſerpents ſting,
from it thou wilt not part.

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: FOoles cannot reach to wiſedomes skill;
ſaue thoſe neare to be kill'd.
GOD giues according to our workes:
Spoyle not the dwelling of the iuſt:
HE curſt that iuſtifies the bad:

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: IT's Gods glory things to conceale;
Haſt not to ſtriue, leſt thou be ſham'd:
thy foe God bids thee feed:
Withdraw thy foot from neighbours houſe:
LEt not a ſecret be reueal'd:
Who cannot rule his ſpirit's blam'd:
good newes the heart doth cheare.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: MEſſage ſent by a fooliſh man:
a rod for ſuch mans backe,
The curſe that's cauſeleſſe ſhall not come:
NO honour giue vnto a foole;
Who deales with needleſſe ſtrife's like him
that takes a dog by th' eares.
OF Parables in mouth of fooles
in pits they dig, they fall.

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: PRayſe not thy ſelfe: publike reproofe:
to th' hungry each thing's ſweet:
Sweet friends good counſell comforts much,
QVicke ſighted men foreſee the euill;
RIches for aye doe not endure:
Thou know'ſt not what one day may bring,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: SInnes of a land cauſe many Kings:
The law forſakers praiſe the bad;
Th' Vſurer hoords for righteous men:
VPright men all good things poſſeſſe,
great ioy when good men ioy:
His prayers curſt who will not heare:
A Faithfull man is greatly bleſt,
who tils his land hath ſtore:
Wh •• giu •• to th' poore ſhall haue no lack;
BLood thirſty men the vpright hate;
The wicked care not for the poore;
CHild left t' himſelfe ſhall mother ſhame:
DEſtroy'd are ſoules where preaching wants,
More hope of fooles then haſty men:
EAch mans iudgment is from the Lord:
the feare of man brings ſnares:
Partner with thiefe his owne ſoule hates;

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: Foure things which neuer will be fild;
foure hard to know their wayes.
GRieuous are all thoſe foure things nam'd;
The meaneſt are not to be wrong'd:
HEre Agurs word and faith confeſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: IT's not for Kings much wine to drinke;
t' women giue not thy mind:
who ſhall a good wife find?
KInd to her husband ſhe will be:
ſhee's praiſ'd in all mens ſight.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL humane courſes are but vaine:
All things doe change; in Wiſdome's griefe:

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: BEtter the wiſe is then the foole;
In Wine is workes of moſt delight,
(Not knowing who ſhall be our heire)
all is but griefe of ghoſt.
DRinke, eat, enioy thy labours frui ••
God giues to ſinners wealth, that hee

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Gods gifts t' enioy our labours fruits,
FRom ſeats of iuſtice iudgement's fled:
as beaſts ſo men muſt dye:
No future things thou canſt behold,
when thou full low ſhalt lye.
In him the people ſhall not ioy;

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: IN th' houſe of God addreſſe to heare,
Th' oppreſſed poore the Lord regards,
KIngs houſes ſerued are by fields;
The rich are often hurt by wealth;
let thine with ioy be ſpent.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: LAcking not wealth, but power to eat,
mans mind what thing can pleaſe?
Sight better is then mans deſire,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NO precious oyntment like good name,
wiſe heart's in houſe of woe:
The hearts of fooles at merry feaſts,
OPpreſſion makes a wiſe man mad;
in fooles heart, wrath doth reſt.
by proofe I found it beſt
PAſt skill of man to ſtraighten that,

No man on earth that ſinneth
• not▪
God at the firſt made man vpright,
SAints ſore diſtreſt in better caſe

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: THe like doth happe to good and bad;
Comfort is all our portion here;
As fiſh, or bird, ſo man is ſnar'd;

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: AS dead flyes ſpoile the oyntment ſweet,
Princes as ſeruants walke on foot,
BIte thee as ſerpents bablers will;
Where Kings and Nobles, eate in time
CVrſe not the King in ſecret thought;
through ſloath the houſe doth fall:
At feaſt and wine men merry make,
where tree falls ther't ſhal be:
Obſeruing clouds men ſhall not reape;
EArly and at the euening ſow,
O youth for all thy ſports, the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: FEare thy Creator in thy youth,
Before thy body turne to duſt,
GReat care he hath to edifie
wiſe words as goads and nayles:
HEre th' end of all, feare, keepe Gods lawes,
For euery ſecret worke and word

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Song of ſongs: ô kiſſe me (Chriſt)
Draw mee, and we will runne to thee:
BLack though I be, yet comely (Lord)
ô tell me where thou feeds.
O faireſt feed by ſhepherds flock:

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: DEare loue of Lillies among thornes,
I am the roſe of Sharon ſweet,
EVen as among the forreſt trees
So doth my loue all other men
FRuit of his loue is wondrous ſweet,
The Summer's come, my Chriſt is mine,
and I am his for aye.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GReat ſeeking vp and downe for Chriſt,
O wake him not, ſhe ioyes in him,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: HEre graces of the Church ſet forth
Which ſo doth rauiſh Chriſt, that ſhee
IN calling her to follow him,
The Church prayes to be fitted for
ſo great and worthy a gueſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: KNocking , Chriſt doth the Church awake,
He then departs, ſhe ſeekes him ſtill,
and's loue ſicke for his ſake.
LO here by comely corporall parts,
Chriſt Ieſus with his graces all,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: MAke knowne where thy beloued is;
we will him ſeeke with thee.
To gather Lillies, and to feed
NOw I am his, and he is mine,
as flock of Goates, thine haire.
I went to ſee how Vines did bud:

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: Thy nauell, belly, breaſts, and necke,
QVickly let vs goe ſee the Vine,
there ſhalt thou taſt and proue
The pleaſant fruits laid vp for thee:
there I will giue my loue.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: REſpected much, ô that thou wert
Thee would I bring to mothers houſe,
SEt me as ſeale vpon thy heart,
loue is as coales of fire:
One little ſiſter wee will build:
THou that in thoſe ſweet gardens dwellſt,
Cauſe mee to heare, make haſt (ô Chriſt)

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AH ſinfull nation, worſe then beaſts,
Ceaſe from your ſinnes, relieue the poore,
BE godly and your ſcarlet ſinnes
But God will curſe and kill you all,
CRuell, filthy, and treacherous, are they
that once were pure and iuſt.
But I will purely purge away
thy droſſe, thy tinne, thy ruſt.
But ſinners that forſake the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: EXalt ſhall God his glorious houſe,
Come let's goe vp, he will vs teach
his waies and paths to know.
FOr out of Sion goes the Law,
Of ſpeares ſhall pruning hookes be made,
When great and meane men bow themſelues
HAughtie and poud, God will pull downe,
Men ſhall for feare fly to the Rocks

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: IN Iuda for their grieuous ſinnes
The ſtaffe of bread, their counſellers,
Kings ſhall be children; babes and baſe
Againſt their Elders, men ſhall ſweare
LEwd tongues and deedes procure this fall;
Woe to their ſoules; but tell the iuſt
that they full well ſhall fare.
MY people are by women rul'd;

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: NOw women ſeu • n one man deſire
Gods glorious Branch; the iuſt are bleſt
who liue to praiſe his name.
OF Zion daughters, when the filth
And blood; then be will be to his

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: His ſeuere iudgments brought on them,
in hell fire muſt they fall.
REnewed woes to them that ſay
Who cleares the wicked for reward
SIth they caſt off the law of God,
He ſends vpon them furious foes,
who ſlew them with the ſword.
VPon his mouth the coale was laid,
God bids him goe then to his folke,
and tels him what to ſay:
ALl hearts make fat, eares, eyes ſout vp

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: BRought in great feare is Ahaz King
and bids him feare not thoſe.
CHriſt promiſed in ſtead of ſigne,
Th' Aſſyrians ſhall deſtroy the Land;
Gird vp your ſelues, prepare for warre,
but God will root you out.
FEare not their feare, God is with vs
To vs hee'll be a ſanctuary.
GOds lawes ſeale vp amoung his owne
Who ſpeake not as the word doth ſpeake,
In him there is no light.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: HEre by the birth and power of Chriſt
ſhall be great ioy in woe;
Thou break'ſt their yoakes, their ſtaues, and rods,
and frees them from their foe.
IEſus Chriſt here is borne to vs
With iuſtice he ſhall iudge his folke,
LEwd Leaders make the people ſinne,
no man ſhall ſpare his brother:

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: MVch woe to tyrants threatned here
NO helpe but from the Lord alone,
When thou haſt whipt the hypocrites,
thou whipt and burnt ſhall bee:
OF thy ſtout hearts and lofty lookes
As if that thou hadſt done the deed)
PVt feares away, ô people deare,
Thou ſhalt be freed from all thy foes,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: QVietly then ſhall Woolfe and Lambe
When leſſe's branch, euen Chriſt our King
and iudge the poore with right,
The earth with knowledge ſhall be fild,
SEt vp an enſigne then ſhall he
And call together all the Iewes
The riuers dried a paſſage made

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: VNto the Lord then ſhalt thou ſay,
Yet now thy wrath is turnd away,
ALL feare expel'd my truſt ſhall be
in God my ſtrength and ſtay,
My Sauiour, ſweet my thankfull ſong
BLeſt be the Lord, let all his workes
O Zion ſaints exult for ioy

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: CAl'd and commanded of the Lord
ſhall root and race the out.
in thee ſhall daunce and ſtand,
As Sodome ſhalt thou be deſtroyed

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: And placing them in their owne land,
no good thing there to lack.
FOr ſeruants ſhalt thou take thy ſoes,
And thou ſhalt rule th' oppreſſors all
For pride the Lord giues him and his
from his the Lord will take,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: IN one night, Air, and Kir were foyld;
Thy Cities ſack't, greene things confirm'd,
is heard of all thy ſlaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: LEt lambe be ſent to th' worlds ruler;
let out caſt dwell in thee,
The throne of Dauid ſhall in truth,
MOab muſt mourne, and howle for pride,
Moab ſhall pray but not preuaile;

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: NO man ſhall fray away the flocks,
Of Syria, Iſrael now forlo • e,
OF which a remnant ſhall be left,
A few like gleaned eares of corne
But Altars , groues, (workes of their hands)
they ſhall in no caſe brooke.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: But after he will plague their foes
that did them rob and racke.
God will out of the Land:
Then ſhall the people Preſents bring

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: SOre plagues for Aegypt God ſets downe,
Fierce cruell Kings ſhall vex them much
THeir folly and madneſſe here ſet downe,
Pure language Cities fiue ſhall ſpeake,
VNt Egypt and Aſſyria the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: AS nak'd and barefoot Eſay goes,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: COmfort me not, the Cities ſpoyl'd,
The walls broke downe, the people cry,
When they ſhould faſt, they feaſt, and ioy
till God did plague at length.

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: FOr Tyre and Zidon fearefull plagues
Who caried captiues, all their wealth,
GOe 'bout the Citie, ſing many ſongs,
But onely for the good of thoſe

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: HAughtie proud hearts, heard anguiſh ſore
to old and young each one.
His curſe therefore deuoures the earth,
much woe they feele and ſee.
KInde is the Lord (ſhall ſome few ſing)
In iudgements God ſhall be aduanc'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: LOrd who lai'ſt leuell lofty towers,
Thee will I praiſe and Nations all
MOſt kind thou haſt beene to the poore
thou wilt bring downe thy foes,
And make a glorious feaſt for thine;
NO death ſhall hurt his holy ones:
he will vs keepe and ſaue:

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: O Truſt yee alwaies in the Lord,
The lofty Citie he layes low:
For vs thou haſt ordained peace:
QVickly will they Lord ſeeke to thee,
Hide thou thy ſelfe: God will repay:

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: REd wine vineyard ſing yee to her;
SAfely will he ſtill keepe his vine,
his owne he doth not ſmite,
As thoſe that are their enemies,
THE fruit of their chaſtiſing is
Their altars, groues, falſe worſhips all,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: A Fading flower thy beautie is,
Thy pride ſhall vnder foot be trod,
great woes and plagues are thine.
to a remnant he ſhall be
CLeane are no tables, Prophets, Prieſts,
through wine erre from the way,
In Iudgement ſtumble; in viſion erre,
ſtrong drinke doth make them ſtray.
DIuine doctrine, whom ſhall he teach?
They would not heare, though they were taught,
the way that led to reſt.
Their ſecure couenant ſhall be try'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: Their foes ſhall not be ſatisfied,
GOds woes on all deepe hypocrites,
HEre promiſe made that deafe ſhall heare,
and eyes full blind ſhall ſee:
The meeke and poore in Iſraels God,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: who ſnare the iuſt for naught:
But Abrahams ſeed ſhall bleſſe the Lord
KNow here the threatned woes to thoſe
that ſeeke to man for ayde,
That aske not counſell of the Lord,
nor on his ſtrength are ſtay'd.
LEt this their ſinne be written downe,
and how they will not heare
The Prophets preach the word of God,
with lyes they muſt them cheare.
MOſt bleſt are they that wait for God,
for they ſhall weepe no more
He will be gracious to them all
ſhall brooke, but purge and cleanſe
And as a menſtruous cloath ſhall hate,
and ſay fye get thee hence.
O Marke the ioy Gods people haue,
Marke Tophet large and wide prepar'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: PRophet Iſay here proues them curſt
Who ware not God, their horſes fleſh,
QVite ſpoyl'd ſhall they and helpers bee,
God is moſt ſtrong and wiſe:
To ſaue mount Zion from her foes,
REturne to God whom Iſrael left,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: SVre bleſſings learne of Chriſts Kingdom,
men ſhall both heare and ſee:
Mens ſtammering tongues ſhall plainly ſpeake
TRemble women that are at eaſe,
all wealth and ioy ſhall ceaſe;
Vntill the ſpirit be powr'd on vs,
then ſhall come reſt and peace:

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: O Lord be gracious vnto vs,
ALL; nations ſcattered when thou ſtirſt,
BItterly ſhall ſtrong men cry out,
The vpright man ſhall dwell on high;
the King ſhall ſee moſt cleare.
COme looke on Zion thou ſhalt ſee
Iehouah is our Iudge and King,
to ſaue he will not ceaſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: th' earth drunke with Edoms blood,
God will take vengeance on them all
EVen ſtreames ſhall burning pitch be made,
Which night nor day ſhall not be quench't,

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: GOds glorious power th' Elect ſhall ſee,
they ſhall be fill'd with ſongs:
Weake hands and knees ſhall be confirm'd,
and birds be ſtout and ſtrong.
HE will come with a recompence,
The deafe ſhall heare, the lame ſhall leape,
the blind their ſights ſhall haue.
IN deſares ſhall be water ſtreames;
the tongue of dumbe ſhall ſing:
No ſighes, nor ſorrowes, ſhall bee ſeene,

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: Not truſt in God, nor in Epypt,
his King would win the field.
and ſay your God ſhall ſaue;
Thus is the Lord of Hoſts blaſphem'd
No, let this people heare (quoth he)
and ſaue their life and land.
NOne make him anſwer, (ſo the King
The Rulers rent their cloathes, and tell
the King, who grieues full ſore.

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: O How he mournes! ô Eſay pray,
it may be God wil pay
then he tels what to ſay.
the Lord will ſend a blaſt
they ſhall be ſlaine at laſt.
QVite ouerthrowne haue I great Kings,
and ſhall thy God thee free?
King reads the letter, prayes that God
RAging ſo ſore , God hooks his noſe,
The Angell kills his ſouldiers all,
he by his ſonnes are ſlaine.

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: SEt houſe in order, dye thou muſt,
And praying, God addes to his age
THe ſigne hereof is Sunne gone backe
God caſts his ſinnes behind his backe,

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: The Prophet then reproues the King,
and tells him what ſhall be.
ALl theſe to Babylon ſhall goe,
Good is the word of God (ſaith he)
I peace and truth ſhall ſee:

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: Th' Apoſtles preaching: ALL FLESH GRASSE
CArry ſhall he his tender lambes
his folke he well ſhall feed:
None like the Lord, the earth to him,
DAre any then compare the Lord
Proud Princes be pulls to the ground,
ETernall God hath all things made,
the young and ſtrong ſhall fall:
But they that wayt vpon the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: FRom th'Eaſt, who rais'd the righteous man
Them will I foyle , but helpe thee ſtill,
GIue forth your reaſons, tell what's paſt,
or ſhew vs what's to come:
Ye 're worſe then naught, and curſt are they
that chooſe you all and ſome.
there's none that heare their words,

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: I Haue my ſpirit put on him,
The bruiſed reed he will not breake,
to th'blind he ſhall giue ſight.
KEepe thee will I: all creatures ſing,
Great ſhame ſhall light vpon all thoſe
LEt deafe and blind now heare and ſee,
who is ſo blind as mine?
Who heare and ſee, but to obſerue,
MY people rob'd and ſpoyl'd becauſe,
they would not heare my voyce;
His Law he will make honourable ,

lg.head: Chapt. 43
lg.l: No fire ſhall kindle vpon thee,
I am and will be thine.
OVt of my hand no man can ſaue;
I am your Lord and King:
To Babell for your ſake I ſent:
PLead thou with me for my name ſake:
Yet gaue I Iacob to the curſe

lg.head: Chapt. 44
lg.l: My ſpirit, and they each one ſhall ſay,
REdeemer firſt and laſt I am;
there is no God but I:
The Image and the maker both
SIng ſeruant Iacob all thy ſinnes
I formed thee and all things elſe,
the wiſe men fooles I make:
My ſeruants words I doe confirme,

lg.head: Chapt. 45
lg.l: VNlooſe for him the loynes of Kings,
and breake the gates of braſſe,
For Iacobs ſake I call'd him ſo
ALL light and darkneſſe, peace and euill,
No God but I, Ile cauſe him build
BRing forth ſaluation, heauens and earth
to his great ioy he ſends.
COme ne are and know that they are foole •
that ſet vp wood and ſtone:
Looke vp to me and ſaue your ſoules,

lg.head: Chapt. 46
lg.l: DOwne fals falſe Bell: the beaſts did bear,
I cary you from youth to age,
EQuall to me, whom will you make?
O ſinners thinke on former times,
my power and grace yee proue.

lg.head: Chapt. 47
lg.l: FOr cruell pride is Babell plagu'd,
g eat ſinnes the Lord prouokes,
They ſhewed no mercy to his folke,
GIuen to delights and careleſſe life,
ſhe ſaid ſhe was a Queene;
But ſhee ſhall haue ſuch plagues for ſinne
HElpe of th' Aſtrologers ſeeke and craue,

lg.head: Chapt. 48
lg.l: ISraell ſweares but not in truth;
I often taught, and told them things
he ſaues for his owne ſake;
O Iſrael heare I will thee teach;
LIke ſands of ſea thy ſeed had beene,
If thou hadſt hearkned to my voyce ,
thou hadſt had ſtore of peace.
MAke haſt goe out of Babylon;
ſay ye the Lord doth ſaue
no peace at all ſhall haue.

lg.head: Chapt. 49
lg.l: NAm'd was I from my mothers wombe,
my mouth made like a ſword:
I ſpake, and ſpent my ſtrength in vaine:
my worke is with the Lord.
Th'art giuen to light the Gentiles all,
PRinces ſhall riſe and worſhip thee,
To lighten men in darkneſſe ſet,
QVietly then thou ſhalt them lead,
Shall ſmite or hurt thy holy ones,
Both Kings and Queenes with humble hearts
SAue thee, and thine will I from foes,
With their owne blood they ſhall be drunke,
and on their fleſh ſhall feed.

lg.head: Chapt. 50
lg.l: TO whom haue I your mother ſold?
your ſinnes haue made you fall:
My power can ſaue; my tongue doth cheare
VNto the ſmiters did I giue
my backe, and face to ſhame:
The Lord, doth helpe and iuſtifie;
ALl ye that heare, and feare the Lord
Who needs will ſtay vpon themſelues,
ſhall lye them downe in ſhame.

lg.head: Chapt. 51
lg.l: To Zion he will comfort ſend,
in her all ioy ſhall be.
COme heare my law, which is your light,
My ſauing health endures for aye,
DEare people who regard my law,
The moth and worme ſhall them conſume;
EVen as of old, ſtretch out thine arme
thou makſt deepe ſeas be dry:
Then mortall man why ſhouldſt thou feare?
My word I will put in thy mouth;
thee in mine hand Ile beare.
GReat dregs of dolour haſt thou drunke,
But I that plead my peoples cauſe,
will make thy foes full ſad.

lg.head: Chapt. 52
lg.l: th' vncleane ſhall come no more.
Within thy courts; thou haſt beene ſold,
IN thee who ſhall ſaluation preach,
Their feet ſhall be moſt beautifull,
KIngs then ſhall ſhut their mouthes at Chriſt;
the Lord hath ſet thee free.
LOrds veſſell bearers be ye cleane:
Depart from thence, the Lord doth goe

lg.head: Chapt. 53
lg.l: MEn did deſpiſe, and Chriſt reiect:
But as a plant he did grow vp,
NO fraud was found in him nor ſin,
ON him was all our lewdneſſe layd;
So hee to death, by which he hath
PRoſper ſhall ſtill, the Lords good will,
which he doth take in hand;

lg.head: Chapt. 54
lg.l: QViet your ſelues, ô Gentiles all,
Feare not he is your husband deare,
REdeemer ſaith, though I haue ſeem'd
for mine I will thee take.
SWorne haue I that I will thee ſaue,
Thy foes ſhall gather thee againſt,
THy children ſhall be taught of God:
But tongues nor weapons ſhall thee hurt:
my peace thou ſtill ſhalt proue.

lg.head: Chapt. 55
lg.l: Drinke freely, heare, beleeue in me,
A Couenant will I make with you
A leader to my folke I haue
giuen, Chriſt their ſinnes to cure.
BE Prieſt to ſeeke and call on God,
Forſake your ſinnes; returne to him,
then he will helpe and heare.
COnſider that my wayes and thoughts
My word doth not returne in vaine:
on his all ioy he powres.

lg.head: Chapt. 56
lg.l: DOe Juſtice, keepe the ſabbaths pure,
My ſauing health is neare to thoſe,
EVen Eunuches, ſtrangers and their ſonnes
To doe the things that I command,
FEild, for • eſt, beaſts come and deuoure,
Dumbe greedy dogs, ſleepe, gaine and wine
are all that they doe mind.

lg.head: Chapt. 57
lg.l: GRieu'd hearts none haue when good men dye
but they are freed from wo:
They reſt in peace, yea witches ſonnes
High mountaine haſt thou offered on
There is no peace to wicked men,

lg.head: Chapt. 58
lg.l: yet they will faſt and pray:
And ſeeme to loue and like my lawes,
KNow that the faſt that God doth chooſe,
is to reli • ue the poore:
Yee faſt to ſtrife and wickedneſſe,
LOdge, cloath, and feed the fatherleſſe,
Then God will bleſſe and guide thee ſtill
and heare thee when thou prayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 59
lg.l: MVch murther, and ſuch monſtrous ſinnes
Hath caus'd the Lord to hide his face,
NOne ſtands for truth, nor calls for right,
they ſpeake and truſt in lyes:
I could and would haue help'd and ſau'd,
like doues we mourne full ſore:
We roare like Beares, we looke for ayde,
but thou doſt ſend no more.
And who ſo doth depart from euill
QVickly did his owne arme faile,
And (wondring at their want of zeale)
he made his foes to quake.
My ſpirit and word ſhall not from thee

lg.head: Chapt. 60
lg.l: ſhall come to ſee thy light:
Euen royall Kings ſhall come from far,
THeir flocks, their ſiluer and their gold,
they then ſhall bring to thee:
And who their ſeruice will not yeeld
VIolence ſhall no more be heard,
the Lord ſhall be thy light:
A little ſmall one ſhall be come

lg.head: Chapt. 61
lg.l: ANointed am I for to preach
To Zion mourners bruiſ'd in heart,
BVilding the old waſt places all,
Gods Prieſts they ſhall be nam'd,
And double ioy they ſhall poſſeſſe,
Who ſee them and their ſeed ſhall ſay,
Though for burnt offerings made and done:

lg.head: Chapt. 62
lg.l: Vntill her brightneſſe ſhall breake forth
FOr famous ſhall thy new name be,
a crowne in Gods owne hand;
In thee he doth reioyce, and will
GIue him no reſt vntill hemke
Gatherers ſhall eate in my courts,
HIgh waies caſt vp, a ſtandard ſet;

lg.head: Chapt. 63
lg.l: I Haue the wine preſſe trod alone;
And I will trample vnder foot
my foes both all and ſome.
When I with wondring did behold
LOrd, of thy loue, and goodneſſe great
Thou ſaidſt, they are thy people deare,
MVch vex't was he when they rebell'd,
Then thought he on his ancient loue,
NOne knew vs (Lord) in heauen but thou,
Looke downe and helpe; what is thy loue
O Lord why haſt thou made vs erre,
and hearts kept from thy feare;
Thy foes and ours tread downe thy Church,

lg.head: Chapt. 64
lg.l: POwre down thy plagues vpon thy foes,
Nor eare hath heard, what thou prepar'ſt
for them that wait on thee.
QVickly thou Lord doſt meet the man
But thou art wroth; for wee haue ſinn'd,
REmember not our ſinnes for aye:
Our holy houſe thy foes haue burnt;

lg.head: Chapt. 65
lg.l: SOught am I of a nation
that did not aske for mee:
I called daily on mine owne
THey walked after their owne thoughts,
O come not neere, for I am pure,
theſe I with plagues will pay.
VNto a remnant that me ſought,
But you forſooke me when I call'd,
ALL things wherein I tooke no ioy,
My ſeruants therefore ſhall be bleſt,
BEhold new heauens and earth I make,
No want of bleſſings there ſhall be
CVrſt wolfe then with the Lambs ſhall eate,
they ſhalt not hurt at all:
I then will heare and anſwer make

lg.head: Chapt. 66
lg.l: DOgges necke cut off: killing a man
As when you offer Oxe or Lambe,
EArth is my footſtoole, heauen 'n y th • n
To poore and contrite ſoules I looke,
FOr my name ſake who caſt you out,
Said God be prais'd, but he will bring

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AH Lord I am but as a child,
Goe, I a Prophet thee ordain'd ,
BE not afraid of any thing,
To pull downe Kingdomes built and plant,
COme from the North ſhall mightie Kings,
But plague them for their falſe worſhips,
DIſmay not at their furious lookes,
Ile thee defend, and fight with thoſe

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: EVill ſhall betide all Iſraels foes;
What haue I done, that you ſo ſoone
FRom Aegypt who did you bring out
You neuer ask't, nor yet your Prieſts
And changed mee for Idoll gods,
that thou thus plagu'd ſhould be?

Thou haſt forſaken me thy
• God:
my feare is not in thee.
I Broke thy yoake, and burſt thy bands,
I planted thee a noble vine;
KNow that your ſinne is marked out,
a ſtocke ye call your fire:
Yet in their trouble they will ſay,
LIke Lyon fierce, your owne ſword hath
Becauſe thou ſaiſt I haue not ſinn'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: MOſt filthy haue thy whoredomes beene
Becauſe thou didſt defile the land,
NOne turn'd to mee with all their heart
they worſe did breake my law
O Iſraell, turne, confeſſe your ſinnes,
To feed your ſoules with knowledge pure,
PEruerted haue we all our waies,
Our Fathers children, flocke and heards

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: Or elſe the, land, King, Prophets, Prieſts
RAging and ruthleſſe foes draw neare;
O waſh thy heart from ſinne:
Thus art thou plagu'd, becauſe that thou
SOunding of trumpets haue I heard:
The ſouldiers ſlay, and ſlaughter all
TO Sinne, and ſerue the deuill, my folke
But to doe good, they're very fooles;

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: VPon the Iewes for fearefull ſinnes
They ſought not truth; they falſly ſwore;
this made the Lord to frowne.
ALL men refuſe to turne to me,
both poore and men of might
BReake down their walls, th'are not the Lorde,
A nation ſhall deuoure thy flockes,
COme heare (ye blinde and fooliſh folke)
what? will ye not me feare?
Which rules the roaring ſeas, and giues
DEpriu'd are you of theſe good things,
The Prophets lye, the Prieſts loue gifts:
The Word is a reproach to them
that haue no ioy to heare.

GIuen are they all to couetuouſneſſe
•
HEarken ye out the old good pathes,
And you ſhall find reſt to your ſoules ,
I Therefore will lay ſtumbling blockes,
both ſires and ſonnes ſhall fall:
I care not for your ſacrifice
KIlling is ſeene on euery ſide,
• hee haue I as a fortreſſe ſet,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: LIſten ô Iudah leaue your ſinnes,
• oe no man wrong, and you ſhall liue,
MAd people, w • ll you murther, ſteale,
• alle worſhips vſe, then come to me,
NO profit is in lying words,
• s Shilo will I lay it waſt,
ſith you liue as you luſt.
OBſerue their deeds (pray not for them)
Or ſuch things as they doe to me
PRophets were daily ſent to them,
QVake and lament, the wrathfull God
You burne in Tophet children deare,
which came not in my heart.
no mirth be heard that day,
Their ca • leaſſes the foules ſhall eate ,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: SPread ſhall thy foes the buried bones,
Before the Sun , which they haue ſeru'd,
and men for death ſhall call.
THey held deceit , would not repent,
but worſe and worſe did grow:
The fowles obſeru'd their pointed times,
but me they will not know.
VS hath he giuen waters of gall,
God will conſume 1 their grapes and figs:
AGainſt hearts griefe when I would ſtriue,
my heart doth faint and faile,
To heare their cry they me prouok't,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: BEcauſe for ſinne the moſt are ſlaine,
I would ſhed ſtore of teares;
Like bowes they bend their tongues for lyes,
COuragious for the truth none is,
they grow from euill to worſe,
Nor neighbour, nor a brother truſt,
they taught their tongues to curſe.
Of man and beaſt, for all theſe ſinnes,
I gall and wormewood will them giue,
As dung on field dead bodies lye,
death kills both more and leſſe.
GLorie thou not in wit and wealth,
• ut that thou knoweſt me thy God,
HE ſaith that he will puniſh ſore,
Who are not circumcis'd in heart,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 0
lg.l: ISraels houſe learne not the waies
O • trees they make them guilded gods,
KIng of all nations thou art great,
and madſt the heauens ſo high:
Thee will we feare, the ſtockes doe teach
LIke Idols is not Iacobs God:
By brutiſh Paſtors all are ſpoyl'd,
MAn cannot guide his ſteps himſelfe,
On Iacobs foes poure out thy rage ,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: Which was obey and you ſhall be
To bring vpon them grieuous plagues,
PRay not for this ſinfull crew ,
for ſure I will not heare:
As ſtreetes ſo altars vnto Baal,
QVite broket are thy branches off ,
For thy reioycing in thy ſinne,
RIght like an oxe to ſlaughter brought,
When they ſaid kill and cut him off,
SHew me thy wrath on them that ſaid
preach not on paine of death.
Let ſword their ſonnes and daughters ſlay,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
