lg.l: THou Lord art iuſt, yet tell me why
Thou lett'ſt them grow and bring forth fruit
they feele no kind of woe.
VNto the Lord, I well am knowne,
For ſinne the Land ſhall mourne, the beaſts,
A Number of thy fathers houſe
Beleeue them not, for all their words,
BEaſts of the field , come and deuoure,
Yet no man grieues, they reape no wheat,
but thornes for all their toyle.
COmpaſſion will I haue on them,
and bring them to their land:
If they obey they ſhall be ſure
to haue my helpe at hand.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 3
lg.l: • s it was ſpoil'd; ſo God for pride
to his folke dealt, and did.
FEare ye the Lord (before he plague)
• y ſoule ſhall weepe, to ſee you brought
GReatneſſe of ſin great plagues haue brought
• o more can you your lewdneſſe leaue;
when will ye ceaſe to ſinne?

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 4
lg.l: • o raine did fall vpon the earth
nor graſſe grew on the ground.
• N places high, wild aſſes did.
• he Hindes did calues, and in the fields
KInde Lord the hope of Iſrael,
• et we are called by thy name,
LOuing to wander from his wayes,
• ay not for them: I will not heare,
MY name falſe prophets ſtill doe vſe
The ſword nor famine; yet by theſe
NOne ſhall there be to bury them ,
Their wickedneſſe I will poure out,
O Let me weepe for people ſlaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: PEople ſo graceleſſe I will plague ,
Swords, beaſts, and doggs ſhall ſtroy them for
QVite backward art thou gone from me,
Of children they ſhall be bereau'd
Woe is me a man of ſtrife,
SAfe ſhall thy remnant be, and though
your foe ſhall vſe you well,
Yet for your ſinnes to a land vnknowne
with them you ſhall goe dwell.
THou knowſt I ſuffered for thy ſake ,
Auenge me on mine enemies all,
thy word was my ſweet ſtay.
VPon me (Lord) why haſt thou brought,
I eate thy word I found.
AS mine owne mouth ſo ſhalt thou be
a wall I will thee make
Vnto this people; if the vile,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: BEware thou ſhalt not take a wife,
They ſhall all dye of grieuous deaths,
not one their life ſhall ſaue.
COme not in houſe where feaſting is,
For ioy ſhall ceaſe, all mirth depart
DEmaunding why they thus are plagu'd,
and what had beene their ſinne?
Say that their fathers me forſooke,
and they farre worſe haue bin.
as when I ſhall them ſaue:
And bring them to their land againe ,
FRom euery mountaine, hill and hole,
I will them hunt and call:
And double pay them for their ſinnes;
Once I will cauſe them know my name,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: HIgH places, groues, and ſuch great ſinnes
Haue caus'd the ſpoile of treaſures all,
IN man who truſts, and turnes from God,
But who ſo truſts, and hopes in God,
KNowne vnto me are all mens hearts,
moſt wi • ked full of guile:
To giue according to their wayes,
LOrd heale and ſaue, thou art our hope,
Who thee (the wel of life) forſakes
that at Gods word doe ſcoffe.
NO bleſſings could, nor curſes cauſe
Till he ſet fire vpon their gates,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: OF Iſraels houſe as potters deale
with clay they haue in hand:
So haue I power (as they deſerue)
to make or marre a Land.
They ſaid they would doe what they liſt,
and what came in their heart.
QVickly will I ſpoile their land,
Becauſe that they my ancient pathes
REgard not what the Prophet ſaith,
Gods word we ſhall haue ſtill;
Come let vs ſmite him with the tongue,
and doe euen what we will.
SAue me (ô Lord) but pay them home,
that pay me euill for good:
• a • ue vp their children, pitty non • ,
nor ſpare to ſhed their blood.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 9
lg.l: TAke pot'ers veſſell, and the heads ,
• oe tell a • Tophet all the plagues,
VNto their Gods they burnt their ſonnes,
• hich I commanded not, nor ſpake,
nor came it in my head.
AN hiſſing ſhall this place be made,
the beaſts ſhall eate their fill;
• nd fowles of their dead carkaſſes ,
which cruell foes ſhall k • ll.
and car'd not for my word;
They ſhall their ſonnes and daughters care
Puts him i'th ſtockes, but he is plagu'd;
his friends ſlaine in his ſight.

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: DEliuer will I all the ſtrength,
Of Iudahs King, both thou and thine,
I ſaid, I will reproue no more ,
FOrbeare I could not, for as fire
thy word did in me burne:
They me defam'd, and frighted ſore,
they watch'd when I would turne.
Vpon my foes: prayſe ye the Lord,
his birth doth curſe and blame,
Becauſe he griefe and ſorrow ſaw,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: I Pray thee know if God will ſaue
No, God will ſmite you all himſelfe,
Shall captiues goe and in great woe,
them elſe the foes will ſlay:
Who yeeld ſhall haue their liues beſtow'd
MY face againſt you haue I ſet,
This City Babels King ſhall haue,
and burne it all with fire.
Or elſe, (for all thy truſty rocke)

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: O King of Iudah , thou and thine,
be iuſt, doe no man wrong:
Then will I bleſſe , if not Ile burne
POure forth no teares for thoſe now dead,
Who muſt forſake their natiue ſoile,
QVite quaſht ſhall King Iehoiakim be,
His heart is all for auarice ,
But woe to him that builds with wrong
SPeaking to thee in proſperous ſtate
thou ſaidſt I will not heare:
Thou and thy Paſtors plagu'd ſhall be
THough Coniah were moſt deare to me
He ſhall be baniſht; neuer thriue,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: that will not ſtarue them ſo:
A Righteous branch the Lord will raiſe,
By him his people ſhall be ſafe,
BOth Prieſts and Prophets are prophane,
The land laments and mournes for oathes,
CAn any hide himſelfe from me?
I heauen and earth do fill:
The Prophes feed my folke with lies,
DOting dreamers let them dreame on,
Like fire and hammer t'is which breaks

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: EVen as ſome figges are paſſing good,
So will the Lord bring backe his owne,
As naughty, bad and bitter figges,
no man can eate, nor taſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: GOd hath me ſent and many moe,
both early and late to call,
And bid you leaue your falſe worſhips
HAuing oft heard and not obeyed,
No milſtones mirth, nor candle light,
the King there ſhall they ſerue:
But after I will plague that land
KIngs cauſe to drinke of this wine cup,
My ſword ſhall moue and make them mad,
LOth if ſtrange nations be to take,
the cup, and drinke of it:

Say that my people haue
• begun
and you ſhall not goe quite,
Mens carkaſſes ſhall be as dung,
NOw ſhepheards howle ye chiefe of flocks,
The dayes of ſlaughter are at hand,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: OF all the words I bid thee ſpeake,
If they obey they ſhall be bleſt,
PRieſts, Prophets, and the people all
The Princes ſaid no cauſe of death,
QVit then in iudgement Ieremy is
And is preſeru'd from peoples rage

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l:
REmaine ſhall they in their owne
• land,
But who refuſe I will conſume,
SVch Prophets falſe, as tell you lies,
The treaſures which were left behind,
Of wood, and ſaid, thus ſhall the yoke
BRoken they haue the yoke of wood,
but thou for them ſhalt make:
Strong yron yoakes, they muſt ſerue him,
and he their beaſts ſhall take.
CAſt off, and curſed ſhalt thou be
that mak'ſt them truſt a lye:
this yeare thou ſure ſhalt dye.
EAte you the fruites of gardens there,
which you your ſelues did plant,
Take wiues , and pray for Babells peace,
then peace ye ſhall not want.
The dreames ye cauſed them to dreame
My promiſe made of your returne,
and free you from all feares.
HOme ſhall ye come, and if you ſearch
for me with all your heart,
I will be found, and heare your pray,
and will not from you part.
I Will the ſword and famine ſend
on King that ſit, on throne;
And on the people here at home
KNow now the cauſe you hearkened not
But ſaid, the Lord hath Prophets rays'd,
LYing Prophets here two are ſlaine,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: the time to be at hand,
That all his people ſhould returne
O Iacob I will breake thy yoake,
Now ſhalt thou ſerue me and the King
and ſhall be plagu'd no more.
PVt feare away, thy ſpoylers all
Becauſe they thee an out-caſt call'd
I will giue health to thee.
A whirlewind from the Lord ſhall fall

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: REſtore and build will I againe,
Reioyce; of old I did thee loue,
and ſtill will loue thee well.
SHew farre and neare that God will call
His folke, who ſhall in Sion ſing,
THeir Preiſts with fatneſſe, people eke
As vnyok'd bullocke haue I beene,
Aſham'd I was, I ſmote my thigh,
Thy bowels yearnd, thou brought me backe,
BEhold how Chriſt is promis'd here,
COuenant now then will I make,
I in their hearts will write my lawes,
their ſinnes I will not ſee.
DEuider of the Seas hath built
his Church ſo large and ſure
That it ſhall fi • me and ſtable ſtand,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: EScape thou canſt not, Babels King
thou ſhalt ſee face to face:
For this he was in priſon caſt,
FOr rhine owne ſelfe buy thou my field,
The writings Baruck keepes as ſignes,
that once they there ſhall dwell.
GOod Prophet here to God complaines,
Here grieuous plagues are threatned them
HArtily after a while will I
Ile bring them backe, renew their heart,
they ſhall me feare and know.
I Will reioyce to doe them good,
My couenant will I make with them,

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: KIngs houſes and the Citie's ſpoyl'd,
they come to fight in vaine:
To fill themſelues with dead coarſes
whom I in wrath haue ſlaine.
LEauing to puniſh, Ile them bleſſe
Their ſinnes Ile cleanſe, they ſhall reioyce,
MEn ſhall inioy their flockes and fields,
to ſaue, Chriſt ſhall be ſent.
NEuer ſhall Dauid want a man

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: See and how ſeruants freed , are forc'd
PLague, ſword and famine for this ſinne,
Your Cities ſhall be burn'd with fire,

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: and bid them drinke ſome wine,
REturne (ſaid I) and leaue your ſinnes,
You will I curſe : but Rechabites

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: SHut vp I am: ô Beruch write
and in Gods houſe doe read
Theſe words of God in ſome (perchance )
THey doe proclaime a ſolemne faſt,
the roule is read to all:
VNto the King the Princes will,
Goe hide thy ſelfe and Ieremie.
let none know where you are.
A Part of Gods word King heares read,
he cuts, he burnes the reſt;
A new roule Beruch writes wherein
BVrning Gods word the King himſelfe
Some did intreat him to refraine ,
the Lord both them doth hide,
For this the King and ſeruants all,

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: The King here to the prophet ſends
that he for them ſhould pray.
In dungeon long he lyes, yet tells
GRant liberty ô Lord my King
He yeelds and bids while bread doth laſt,
he ſhould haue ſome each day.

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: doth get him out at laſt.
IF thou wilt ſaue thy life (ô King )
goe yeeld thee to thy foe:
If not this Citie ſhall be burn'd,
And he himſelfe in priſon kept,

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: King flies, ſonnes ſlaine in ſight:
His eyes put out, to Babylon ſent,

MAke much of Ieremie (ſaith the
• King)
From furious foes whom he ſo feares,
he put his truſt in me.

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: To goe with him to Babylon
OF victualls ſtore a good reward
And to Gedaliah then hee goes,
POore men and rich all flocke to him,
To ſerue the King of Babylon,
to them he there doth ſweare.
Then all the Iewes diſpers'd abroad
he ſaith it is a lye.

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: SLaine is Gedaliah and many moe,
From him the captaines reſcued are,

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: And know of God what they ſhould doe,
ASſured are they to be ſafe,
but to be ſlaine in Egypt land,
when me to God you ſent,
In Egypt which you ſo deſire,

lg.head: Chapt. 43
lg.l: That the Chaldeans might them kill,
Which Ieremie ſaith the Lord will giue,

lg.head: Chapt. 44
lg.l: FOr their Idolatries foule and vaine
GOd hath done this in your owne ſight,
But anger him in Egypt here,
That you to doe as bad or werſe
IN Aegypt therefore by the ſword,
None ſhall returne, you ſhall be curſt,
KNowing that they had incenſe burnt,
And offer cakes to th Queene of heauen,
let him ſay what he liſt.
LEauing long off t' offer to her,
we haue felt woe and want:
But then we had a merry world,
no kind of food was ſcant.
King Pha • 'oh alſo ſhall be plagu'd,
marke then whoſe words shall ſtand.

lg.head: Chapt. 45
lg.l: NO reſt I find (thus Beruch moanes)
I mourne, I faint with griefe
Now woe is me, I ſee no hope,
O Beruch I will quite breakedowne
And plucke vp plants I planted erſt,
the Land Ile plague full ſore.
Be glad that I haue granted thee,

lg.head: Chapt. 46
lg.l: His mightie men ſhall be ſtrucke downe,
RIſing much like a raging flood,
they •• y they • e conquer all,

• ut w th their blood
• ſwords ſhall be drunke,

SEruant Iacob be of good
• cheare
• e • ring thy ſeed from captiue ſtate,
THee for thy ſinne I will chaſtiſe,
• ut thou ſhalt be at reſt and eaſe,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 7
lg.l: are ſaid to be at hand:
AT ſtamping of their ſturdy ſteeds,
• he fathers look'd not backe vpon
by Gods ſword muſt be ſlaine.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 8
lg.l: COntempt of God and of his folke
〈◊〉 Moab howle for all the land
DEſtroy'd ſhall all thy Cities be,
• nd curſed ſhall they be that doe,
Feare pit and ſnare ſhall be thy ſhare,
I will in l • tter dayes
to giue them cauſe of praiſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 49
lg.l: Vpon your Cries for your ſinnes;
Them Ile preſerue and keepe a liue;
Ile plague both ſonne and fire.
That of their goods they ſhould be ſpoyl'd,
LAment thou Elam, God will breake
thy Law, thy might and maine:
Yet after many dayes hee'l bring

lg.head: Chapt. 50
lg.l: Bell and Babell are quite deſtroy'd,
NAtions ſhall come out of the North,
•• d many Kings to make the like
O Come let vs now ioyne our ſelues
in firme league with the Lord,
all Iſrael then and Iudah ſay,
let nought of her be left.
〈◊〉 plague her as ſhe plagued you,

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 1
lg.l: REuenge will God all Iſraels wrongs
leſt they doe feele his hand.
SEarch out and read his prophecie,
and to it bind a ſtone;

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 2
lg.l: THen was Ieruſalem ſackt and ſpoyl'd,
• is eyes put out, he's caried
• ods houſe he burnes, and eke the Kings,
BY this ſame King foure thouſand Iewes,
by new King Iewes King fed.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: her ſinne hath wrought her ſhame:
Her ſtate is now moſt miſerable,
BEcauſe none come to ſolemne feaſts,
The Prieſts lament, of Sabbath dayes
no griefe is like to mine:
The cruell force of furious foes,
A grieuous rebell to thy Lawes,
my greife to heare and ſee:
O plague them for their ſinne (O Lord)

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: FRom heauen to th'earth, how hath the Lord
His Sabbath feaſts are all forgot,
and houſe where he did dwell.
GOd hath caſt off his holy Altar,
HEr Elders ſit vpon the ground,
mine eyes with teares do faile,
To ſee that famine in the ſtreets
IN wrath ſhall women eate their babes?
ſhall young and old be ſlaine?
Thou call'ſt my terrours round a bout,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: KNow that I haue affliction ſeene,
My fleſh and skin, he withered hath,
LOrd thou art good to them that ſeeke,
Its good that men euen in their youth,
his yoke ſhould beare and proue.
MEn willingly he doth not grieue,
To cruſh the priſoners vnder foot,
NO pity haſt thou had on vs,
When he is puniſht for his ſinne?
O Lord, thou quickly heardſt my voice,
when I on thee did call:
Thou plead'ſt my cauſe, redeem'ſt my life
Reward them as they well deſerue,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: for ſinne, were not ſo great,
As ou • s, when louing mothers ſod
REd ſcarlet they that vs'd to weare,
None thought that Salem ſhould haue ſeene,
or beene in ſuch a caſe.
SVre hopes and helps did faile vs quite,
Shed by the Prieſts and Prophets falſe,
Thou Edom muſt drinke of his cup,
hee'le make thee quake and feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: VNto vs (Lord) our wood is ſold,
ALL mirth is vnto mourning turn'd:
all ioy of heart is gone:
Seruants beare rule, and vs to helpe ,
BRead was with perill of life procur'd,
Princes are hang'd vp by their hands,
CAſt is our crowne vnto the ground,
Turne vs, and turned ſhall we be,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: When to Ezekiel from the north ,
BEhold they had the face of man ,
Of Lyon fierce, theſe that way went,
the which the ſpirit did goo.
DOwne to the ground then did I fall,
when I the throne did ſee:
And him that ſate vpon the ſame,
moſt like a man to be.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: To tell what plagues they ſhould indure,
FEare not their faces, though thou doſt,
GOe ſpeake; whether they heare or no.
Yet ſhall they know, that to inſtruct ,
HEare what I ſay, be not like them,
In which there was on both ſides writ,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: I Eate the booke, and in my mouth
Speake not to ſtrangers , they would heare ,
and doe what thing is meet.
KNow that my people will not heare,
Ile make thy forehead full as hard,
and face as ſtrong as theirs.
LOe I a watchman haue thee made,
And men ſhall leaue their wickedneſſe,
then thou and they ſhall liue.
MEn vpright if they fall, and ſhall
And thou forewarne not, thou and they,
NOw when I ſaw the glory of God,
Then ſaid the Lord, they will thee bind,
goe ſhut thee in thy place.
O Sonne of man Ile make thee dumb,
But when I ſpeake, then ſhalt thou ſay

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: Pitch campes againſt her round about,
QVietly firſt on leſt ſide lye ,
their ſinnes lay on the City:
Then lye on right ſide, to foreſhew,
Make bread thereof, and with mans dung,
ſee that the ſame thou bake.
SO ſhall they eate defiled bread,
And for their ſinne ſhall pine away,
when all their food is ſpent.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: THine haire cut oft, burne ſome with fire,
Some few bind in thy skirts; reſt burne,
VPon them will I powre my plagues,
All people ſhall admire the plagues
which I on them will powre.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: BRoke downe ſhall all your Idols be,
your ſlaine men ſhall be caſt
ſome few ſhall ſcape the ſword;
Who ſhall lament, and loath themſelues,
That they ſhall know I am the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: Ile ſend vpon the land (ſaith God)
But plague them for their ſinfull pride;
Thoſe that eſcape ſhall for their ſinne,
on hills mourne like a doue.
HOrror and ſhame ſhall couer them,
Their ſiluer ſhall they caſt ith ſtreets,
〈◊〉 no wealth ſhall ſaue from woe.
KIng, Prince and people ſhall be vex'd,
NEere them did Iſr'els ancients ſtand,
•• enſe went vp, and then they ſaid,
O Turne about, and thou ſhalt ſee
PErceiu'ſt thou not (thou ſonne of man)
QVickly call them that haue the charge
RAyment of white, one of them had,
SET thou a marke (ſaith God) on thoſe
that mourne and crie for ſinne:
Kill all the reſt, man, woman, child,
THen did I cry, and ſay (Ah Lord)
He ſaid their ſinnes were wondrous great,
VNto the man in linnen cloath'd,
And bids him fierie coales diſperſe
Of Cherubins, and wheeles which ſtood,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: BEcauſe like heathens you haue liu'd,
COnfounded ſhall you be with ſword,
my plagues on you • le ſpend?
Downe then I fell, and ſaid (ah Lord)
DEclared then it was to mee
though they faire off doe dwell;
Hee'l bring them backe, giue them againe
My ſpirit, all their ſtony hearts
GRacious God to them I'le be,
to me they ſhall be deare:
But I will ſurely plague them all,
my name that will not feare.
HEre Iſraels God the city leaues,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: IN midſt of a rebellious houſe
thou ſonne of man doſt dwell;
Who though they haue hoth eyes and eares,
heare and ſee ne'r a deale.
KNit vp thy ſtuffe; goe from thy place;
So ſhall the King and people all
LIke as thou didſt dig through the wall
Vpon thy ſhoulders; in that ſeige,
tell them that ſo ſhall they.
It may be (though they trecherous be)
NO bread nor drinke ſhall they receiue,
Without great terrour; for the land
O Trecherous houſe, becauſe you ſay
Euen in your daies Ile ſpeake the word,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: PRopheſie woes and plagues to light
QVite ouerthrowne you ſhall all be,
you ſay Thus ſaith the Lord;
Setting your owne lyes ſtill abroach,
when I ſpake no ſuch word.
REnt in my rage with ſtormie ſhowers,
and winds ſhall be the wall
to th' ground it ſure ſhall fall.
SO ſhall the daubers alſo fall
When there was none, but bloody broyles
That hunt the ſoules of my deare Saints,
VIlely will you pollute my name
Will you make ſtrong the wicked crew,
AGainſt you will I ſet my ſelfe,
whom you hunt I will free:
And take them from your cruell hands,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: Should I (ſaith God) to ſuch as theſe
COncerning mee, who comes t' enquire,
A ſigne and Prouerbe ſhall he be,
I'le cut him from his place.
Falſe Prophet and the man deceiu'd
EVen now repent, from Idols turne,
That I may bee your louing Lord,
FOr when a land ſhall grieuouſly.
GOe through the land when my ſword ſhall,
Should onely haue their liues preſeru'd,
HOw much more when I ſend foure plagues,
And peſtilence to cut off all.
IN it a remnant I'le preſerue,
Whom when you ſee what I haue done,
you'l ſay I had good cauſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: KNowne tis to all, the vine branch is
No man can make a pinne thereof
to hang a thing on it.
LOe, being caſt into the fire,
both ends and midſt doe burne;
So fruitleſſe Salem ſhall be burnt
for ſinne they ſore ſhall mourne.

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: MOſt wretched was thy naturall ſtate,
Caſt out, polluted in thy blood,
NO man did pittie thine eſtate,
I tooke thee vp, and bad thee liue,
OF bare and naked breaſts, I did
I put on bracelets on thy hands,
Then thou on Idols all beſtow'd,
and for no coſt didſt ſpare.
QVickly hadſt thou and quite forgot
And with ſtrange whoredomes euery where
ROund thee about, I'le gather them
STone thee with ſtones they ſhall, and burne
Thou ſhalt no longer play the whore,
VNto the poore they ſhew'd no loue,
yet thou art worſe then they,
Thou haſt deſpiſ'd the oath thou made,
AT laſt I will call into minde
And thou of all thy former wayes

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: BY parable of two Eagles here,
Gods plagues on Salem are ſet downe,
From him, to Phar' Egyptian King,
DOwne will I bring the high greene tree,
it ſhall dry vp and periſh;
The Cedar of the Goſpell then

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: EVery ſoule that ſinnes ſhall dye,
Who keepes my lawes, and truely deales,
GOD ſaith who doth beget a ſonne
that hates the thing that's good,
And liues in ſinne; that ſonne ſhall dye,
HIs ſonne that ſees his father ſinne,
and will doe no ſuch thing,
He ſhall not dye: but fathers ſinnes
IF wicked men will turne from ſinne,
and doe the thing that's right;
Their ſinne ſhall not be mentioned,
nor once come in my ſight.
KNow alſo if a righteous man
LIue godly therefore, make your hearts,
I haue no pleaſure in your death,
which for your ſinne is due.

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: MOurne for the Kings of Iſrael,

NO vine
• more fruitfull was then thine,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: OF me dare you come to enquire,
Cauſe them to know how fearefully
QVite from among you will I purge
And by my goſpell gather you,
So for thy ſinne hee'll thee deſtroy

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: SIgh ſonne of man with bitterneſſe
My ſword ſhall cut off good and bad
THus ſaith the Lord, a ſharpened ſword,
It's put into the ſlayers hand,
VPon the Princes ſhall it be,
O cry and howle, it ſpareth none,
where e're they goe or dwell.
APpoint a way, that this my ſword,
Their oathes and other ſinnes are knowne,
Thy crowne I'le giue to him, to whom
They ſhall be ſlaine, and all be made

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: DIuers foule ſinnes are here ſet downe,
By Parents deare; the poore were ſore
HEare therefore I haue ſmit my hands,
I will diſperſe thee farre from home,
thy ſinnes ſhall be thy bane.
KNowne are her Prieſts my law to breake,
LIke rauening Wolues her Princes are,
The people vex the need' and poore,
MY wrath therefore on them I'le powre,
for not a man did ſtand
Before mee, to intreat for grace,
that I might ſpare the land.

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: NAmes of two Siſters here obſerue,
and play'd the whores with them:
PLagu'd by th' Aſſyrians both muſt be,
• o Idols, and then in my houſe
• hat others may like lewdneſſe leaue,
when they your plagues ſhall ſee.

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: REport the parable of a pot
with fleſh and bones that boyles,
All burnt, ſo is the Citie of blood,
SHee wearied out her ſelfe with lyes,
was filth' in all her wayes;
My ſutious force ſhe ſore ſhall feele,
THine eyes deſire, thy wife ſo deare
Yet neither ſhalt thou mourne nor weepe,
VNto the houſe of Iſraell ſay,
Which is your eyes and hearts deſire,
AS I haue done, yet you ſhall doe,
But for your ſinne, each one of you

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: BEhold the vengeance of the Lord
CLapping their hands, they did reioyce
But they that ſo laught at their harme,

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: Becauſe ſhee ſaid, Aha, the wealth
ENgines of warre againſt thy walls
To plague thee for thy ſcoffing ſpite
When they ſhall ſee thy woefull caſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: With all the nations of the world,
which thee ſo rich hath made.
HOwle ſhall thy Mariners, Merchants eke
To ſee thee caſt into the ſeas,

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: thou ſaiſt I am a god,
O Prince of Tire, but thou ſhalt feele
KIng, thou waſt perfect in thy waies
till ſinne was found in thee;

LEt Zidon know, that for her
• ſinne,
shee needs muſt feele my hand,
will bring ſafe to their land.

lg.head: Chapt. 29
lg.l: • riuer is mine owne, and I
• t for my ſelfe haue made.
NO foot of man, nor beaſt shall paſſe
〈◊〉 fortie yeares; that I am God,
OF beaſts thou shalt be eaten vp,
QVick ſeruice King of Babell did
• e shall haue Egypt for his paines,

lg.head: Chapt. 30
lg.l: RElate and ſay, woe worth the day,
the time is neare at hand,
SOre plagues and paines shall vex, and ſpoile,
The King of Babell shall be ſtrong

lg.head: Chapt. 31
lg.l: THou Pharaoh King, whom art thou like?
for pride cut downe is he.
like plagues the Lord will bring,
Downe to the death thou ſhalt be brought,

lg.head: Chapt. 32
lg.l: Who (though thou bee young Lyon like,
and as a great ſea Whale,)
BY many people in my net,
thou ſhalt be caught at length,
And ſhalt by King of Babels ſword
be ſpoyl'd for all thy ſtrength.

lg.head: Chapt. 33
lg.l: CRie to the people, warne them of
Who heares and will not warned be,
his ſinne and ſhame ſhall beare.
DVely, if thou wilt not forewarne
Thou ſhalt be guiltie of his blood,
Shall liue: O turne, why will yee dye,
FRom vpright waies, when vpright men
he ſure ſhall dye in it.
GOds wayes are equall, iuſt and right,
HOe, come and let's goe heare the word,
• hey ſit before thee, and they heare,
• N word they loue, their hearts are naught;
of thee they make their ſong:
• ut they ſhall ſay another day,

lg.head: Chapt. 34
lg.l: • f whom the fat and fleece much more
LOſt ſheepe they ſought not, but like Lords
• ut of their power, I will them free,
and them t' account will call.
MY ſheepe, I will ſeeke out my ſelfe,
• hough now they eat, and drinke of that,
where your foule feete did tread.
NO longer ſhall they be your prey,
• hall be their Shepheard; they are mine,
and I their God will bee.
OVt of the Land ill beaſts ſhall ceaſe;
• f peace with them; bleſt ſhall they be,

lg.head: Chapt. 35
lg.l: • hey loued blood, blood ſhall they haue,
Againſt my people; whom you did,
REioyce will I to plague you all,
As you with them, ſo I with you,

lg.head: Chapt. 36
lg.l: SPightfully did thy foes then ſay,
The ancient places, all is ours,
Your heatheniſh foes that dwell about,
their ſinne and ſhame ſhall beare.
Ile bleſſe them more then at the firſt,
in men, in flockes, in fields.
AS they prophan'd my holy name,
by their owne wayes and deeds:
So I diſpers'd them all abroad,
BVt I had pity for my name,
Ile bring you home, from Idols clenſe,
COrne will I call for, with encreaſe;
from all your ſinnes Ile ſaue:
All needfull bleſſings for your ſoules,

lg.head: Chapt. 37
lg.l: DEad hope of Iſraell is reuiu'd,
• hey ſhall haue life, and be reſtor'd
FRom Idols and falſe worſhips all,
I will them clenſe and keepe:
• heir God and ſhepheard I will be,
couenant with them will I make,
they ſhall lacke no good thing.

lg.head: Chapt. 38
lg.l: HEre bloody Gog, his army great,
• ho ſayd he would deſtroy their land,
• N that day God will plead with him,
• nd will bee knowne in all mens eyes,

lg.head: Chapt. 39
lg.l: My name ſhall not polluted be,
thou then ſhalt feele my power.
who for ſeuen yeares did burne
Gogs weapons; all that ſpoiled them,
MVch ground for graues are giuen to Gog,

The Iſraelites for ſeuen months
• ſpace
NOte here the feaſt that God doth make
How Iſr'el (once plagu'd for their ſinne)

lg.head: Chapt. 40
lg.l: Hee's bid to ſee, heare and obſerue
POrch of the houſe with pillars, poſt;
The gates, courts, chambers, tables right

lg.head: Chapt. 41
lg.l: QVickly then after was I brought
Where I ſaw meaſured euery thing,
ROund about all the wall was made
The Altar, table of the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 42
lg.l: SOuth, Eaſt, Weſt, North ſides meaſured are
THE chambers where the Prieſts did eate,

lg.head: Chapt. 43
lg.l: and ſpake to me the while:
Saying, this people ſhall no more
AWay with all your whoredomes vile,
•• r poſts, and threſholds ſet by mine,
• VT a wall onely was betweene
• ell in the midſt of you will I,
• Vely let Prieſts and Levites keepe,
• nd they ſhall find my grace.

lg.head: Chapt. 44
lg.l: • EAſt gate for Prince aſſigned is;
the Prieſts liue all at large,
•• om Prieſtly office and holy things
Prieſts that mee forſooke, and did
• Ates of the houſe yet they may keepe,
Zad • cks ſonnes ſhall be my prieſts,
• Ere learne how Prieſts in th'inner cou •
•• re the people when they ſerue
• ynd they are no wine to drinke,
• ddowes muſt they take for wiues,
KEepe his lawes in aſſemblies all,
They muſt; and teach the people how

lg.head: Chapt. 45
lg.l: And what the other tribes ſhall haue,
MY Princes, let this land ſuffice,
But iuſtly deale with euery man,
And people, at each ſolemne feaſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 46
lg.l: PRinces, and people both are taugh •
How for to worſhip, what to doe,
The peoples land he ſhall not take,
And boyle the ſin and meate offrings,

lg.head: Chapt. 47
lg.l: SEE (ſon of man) how from Gods h •
•• ey from my ancles, to my loynes,
from loynes to floods did grow.
THeſe heale the waters of the ſea,
• all not be heal'd, but into pits
of ſalt they then ſhall turne.
ALL trees for meat vpon the bankes
of them ſhall grow and ſpring,
• hoſe fruit endures, whoſe leaues likewiſe,
BY lot the land ye ſhall diuide
• e ſtrangers alſo lands ſhall haue,
and names here read and ſee:
• he Cities name (from that day forth)

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: Who him and holy veſſels eke
That they might ſtand before the King,
CRauing that they foure might abſtaine
And might haue pulſe and water giuen
Then they that daily were refreſht
Both dreames and viſions: King could find
none ſuch in all his land.
FOr all the ſorcerers in the land,
• o ſhew him his forgotten dreame, An. Mundi 3348
and ſaid that he would kill
The wiſe men all, who his deſire
He giueth thankes vnto the Lord,
and is brought to the King.
IN latter times, what things ſhall be
By this ſame partie image of clay,
KIng hauing heard the dreame declar'd,
Did worſhip Daniel, gaue him gifts,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: LO here a golden Image made,
Excepting three that would not kneele,
MAD is the king, and doth command
NOw marke the wondrous workes of God,
No fire doth burne, or hurt an haire
O Come ye forth (then ſaid the king)
bleſt be your God for aye,
That ſent his Angels to preſerue
PVtting their truſt in him alone,
Then at the Kings command to bow,
QVickly will I now make a law,
that who ſo ſpeakes a word

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: A mightie tree▪ both high and broad,
SHake off the leaues (ſaith watcher then)
And let his portion be with beaſts,
THis is the meaning of the dreame,
Saith Daniel thou muſt leaue thy ſtate
and like a beaſt muſt be, An. Mundi 3377
VNtill thou know , and well perceiue,
Both men and kingdomes, giuing them
Breake off thy ſinnes, if by this meanes
Then came a voyce and ſaid (O king)
CAſt out he is, among the Beaſts
But after is reſtor'd, and ſet
by him, here are ſet downe,
Who makes the ſtouteſt Prince to ſtoope,
and fall when he doth frowne.

lg.head:
Chapt.
• 5
lg.l: EVen to a thouſand of his Lords,
A feaſt did make; veſſels prophan'd
FOR which he was affrighted ſore
His ſorc'rers could not ſerue his turne;
He read the writing to the king,
HAuing firſt checkt the wicked king
That no foes could (although they would)
LAw of his God he would not breake
but did three times a day
They Daniel ſpare: deuoure his foes,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NIght viſions ſtrange here Daniel ſees,
Which ſhew foure Kings, and what by them,
OF Gods moſt glorious kingdome know,
Who ſits in iudgement: books opened,
POſſeſſe a Kingdome ſhall his Saints,
The beaſts ſhall vexe the Saints , change times,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: QVarrelling ramme, with his two hornes,
The hee-goat, with one mighty horne ,
breakes off the Rammes two hornes.
RIght ſo the King of Grecia,
with his great horne of might,
STout, great and ſtrong this hee-goat grew,
and then his horne was broke:
There did ariſe foure other Kings,
By him the Iewes were murthered
VExing ſtill Gods deare holy ones,
Without mans hand he broken is,
of loathſome death he dyes. An. Mundi Mac. 9. •
BY prayer then he ſeekes to God,
Of all eſtates; intreats that he
Thy Prophets ſent, and teaching vs
how we thy name ſhould feare.
For we haue all done wickedly,
ENcline thine eare, for thy names ſake
FOrgiue vs Lord, grant our requeſts,
Thy City is call'd by thy name,
GAbriel then from heauen is ſent,
That he is much belou'd of God,
HOw long the Iewes ſhould captiues liue,
Repaired be, when Chriſt ſhall come,
and for our ſinnes be ſlaine.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: A glorious viſion then I ſaw
that I am ſent to thee:
Thy words were heard when thou began
LOe with the Prince of Perſia
None holds with me but Michael,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: Kings of the North, and of the South,
OF God he ſhall haue no regard,
Aboue all Gods ſhall lift himſelfe,
PViſſant Kings from North and South,
Againſt him, and all helpeleſſe lie

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: The dead ſhall wake , ſome ſhall be ſau'd,
RVn too and fro then many ſhall,
And ſhall turne men to righteouſneſſe,
SEt times appointed by th' Angel,
Confirmes by oath; but wicked men
THe wiſe ſhall vnderſtand theſe things:
all they that wait are bleſt:
for thou in peace ſhalt reſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: God ſo commands, becauſe the Land
That God would plague both Iehu's houſe,
To ſhew that God would Iſr'el bring
The reſt of Iud' and Iſrael

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: leſt that thou feele my rods;
And leſt I plague thy children deare,
FInding no helpe at Idols hands,
ſhe ſhall ſay I will goe
To my firſt husband, then I had
no ſuch great cauſe of woe.
GOld which I gaue and ſiluer ſtore,
Not knowing that I gaue them corne,
and wine, and oyle, and all.
HEr lewdneſſe I will open lay,
and make her mirth to ceaſe:
I will deſtroy her wines and figges,
and giue her each good thing:
Valley of Achor ſhe ſhall haue,
where ſhe for ioy ſhall ſing.
KIndly they ſhall me Iſhi call;
The names thereof they ſhall avoyd,
LYe downe in ſafety then they ſhall,
With all the Creatures for their good,
for ſpouſe I will them take.
MIne eares ſhall hearken to the heauens;
the heauens ſhall heare the earth,
The earth ſhall heare the fruits thereof,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: NO care ſhe had of pure worſhips,
To other Gods ſhe look'd, then I
OF Kings and ſacrifice they ſhall

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: For want of knowledge, mercy, truth,
QVite voyd of grace; they ſweare , and lye,
they ſteale, they drab, they kill:
Beaſts, fiſh, and foule Ile take away,
REproue them not, for they are ſuch,
as with the Prieſts will ſtriue,
Thou and the Prophet both ſhall fall,
SVch plagues for want of knowledge come,
THe more they had , the more they ſinn'd,
their heart on ſinne was ſet;
They haue left off to heare my voice,
VNto their ſtocks and ſtaues they goe
And vnder oakes, on mountaine tops,
The bribing rulers loue to ſay,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: COme heare (ô Prieſts) liſten ô King,
You were a ſhare and in your net
ſhall all fall in their ſinne:
To frame their deeds, to turne to God,
He is oppreſt, th' Aſſyrians could
GOe from them will I, till that they
Confeſſe their ſinnes, in their diſtreſſe

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: HE that hath wounded, he will heale,
Let vs returne, he will vs raiſe,
we ſhall liue in his ſight.
IF we hold on to know the Lord
And be to vs, as to the earth,
what ſhall I ſay to you,
Your goodneſſe is like morning cloud,
LIke Light my word and iudgements be,
with which I haue them ſlaine:
I mercy and knowledge more deſir'd
MVch murther did their Prieſts commit,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NOne did conſider in their hearts,
that I their ſinnes did ſee:
When I deſir'd to heale their hurts
OF theeues and robbers ſpoyling men
With lies, and wickedneſſe they make
PRinces with their bottles of wine,
Then he his hand with ſcornfull men,
QVite fallen away from me they are,
and will not on me call:
they ſeeke mee not at all,
they ſeeke for wine and corne:
For their ill tongues they ſhall be plagu'd

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: SEt thou the trumpet to thy mouth,
Againſt my Law they haue tranſgreſt,
THy ſiluer Idols, and thy calfe,
How long wil't be before that thou
VP to Aſſyria they are gone,

AS a ſtrange thing they did
• account,
the great things which I wrote;
BVt I will viſit for their ſinnes,
To Egypt: I will ſend a fire,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: thou haſt no cauſe of ioy
As others haue, thou God forſooke,
DWell in the Lords houſe they ſhall not,
which they to him ſhall make.
FOr thy great hatred, and much ſinne,
The Prophets fooles, their fearfull ſinnes
GIue them drie breaſts, and barren wombe,
I will them loue no more:
Their Princes did reuolt from him,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: And threatned them with direfull plagues,
But God will ſpoile them, breake them downe,
and will not let them ſtand.
KIng haue we none; we fear'd not God,
LEt mountaines hide vs (ſhall they ſay)
It is my pleaſure and deſire,
in them thou puts thy truſt:
ſo eate the fruit ye muſt.
Its time to ſeeke the Lord, till he,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: OVt of Egypt call'd I my ſonne,
and lou'd him from a child:
PEruerſe Eph'rim I taught to goe,
and led them by their armes;
And yet they knew not it was I
QVietly with the bands of loue
I drew them; gaue them meat:
Yet were they bent to back-ſliding,
As Admah City ſhalt thou bee,
SHall I doe this which am not man?
my heart is turn'd in me:
I will not execute my wrath,
THen ſhall they walke after the Lord,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: With them; and Iacob, for their deeds,
A Power he had for to preuaile,
He wept and pray'd, and found the Lord,
Yet ſhalt thou dwell in Tabernacles,
as in the dayes of feaſt.
DAyly I ſpoken haue to them,
My Prophets by their preaching ſtill
And therefore God vpon his head,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: FEaring, when Ephrim ſpake to God,
But then they dyed when they began
GRowing ſtill worſe and worſe in ſinne,
and bad men kiſſe the calues.
HOw chaffe is with a whirlwinde driuen,
So they ſhall be, and then ſhall know:
there's none can ſaue but I.
I Did them know in wilderneſſe,
I fed and fill'd them well,
They then wax'd proud, my lawes forgot,
KIll'd ſhall they be therefore , for I
(Rob'd of her whelps) will them obſerue,
LOe Iſr'el, thou haſt ſpoyl'd thy ſelfe,
the King whom thou didſt craue;
I gaue and tooke away in wrath,
there's none but I can ſaue.
MY people, ô turne to the Lord,
thy ſinne hath made thee fall:
NO more ſhall Aſhur, ſaue vs (Lord)
To Idolls, that ye are our Gods,
but praiſe thy name for aye.
O Lord in thee the fatherleſſe,
My wrath from them is turn'd away,
QVickly they ſhall as Lillies grow,
His beauty like the oliue tree,
my dew his root ſhal cheriſh.
REuiue as corne ſhall all thoſe folke
Vnder his ſhade, they flouriſh ſhall,
SAy then ſhall Ephraim what haue I
I then (ſaith God) did ſee and heare,
and heale them from their paine.
THe wiſe ſhall vnderſtand theſe things,
In them the iuſt and good ſhall walke;
in them the bad ſhall fall.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL ye Inhabitants of the Land,
To all theſe plagues ſent from the Lord;
BEhold, the wormes haue eate the fruits,
Your foes haue ſpoyl'd the fruits and trees,
and all your wine is gone.
COme faſt, and pray, lament and mourne,
All ioy is gone: the offerings ceaſe;
the heards and flocks make moane:
The paſtures all are parched vp,
EXtend thy loue to vs ô Lord;
to thee the beaſts doe cry:
The fire their paſtures hath deuour'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: FEare ye and tremble people all,
A darke and gloomie day 's at hand,
GReat Armies come againſt the Land,
Like hauocke in the ages paſt,
IN Sion ſound, and trumpet blow,
Let Prieſts, and Elders pray and ſay,
KInd then and gracious God will be
To fright away your fearfull foes
LEt feare depart , reioyce, be glad,
Corne, wine, and oyle, he giues, and ſends
MY ſpirit vpon all fleſh Ile poure,
Sunne ſhall be darke, and into blood
NO man in that great dreadfull day
But in Mount Zion ſhall be ſafe,
euen all whom God ſhall call.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: who tooke my ſiluer and gold,
• nto your temples, and my folke
PAy dearly ſhall you for this thing,
Who gaue, and ſold, their boyes and girles,
QVickly will I my people raiſe,
To thoſe, whoſe ſonnes ye ſold before,
RIpe for the ſickle harueſt is,
Your plowſhares, and your pruning hookes,
to ſpeares and ſwords doe beat.
SVn, Moone and Starres ſhall looſe their light,
The earth ſhall quake, but God ſhall ſaue
THen ſhall the mountaines drop downe wine,
the hils with milke ſhall flow:
In vallies watered from Gods houſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AMos doth plainly here ſet downe
their walles are ſet on fire.
EDom did his deare brother hate,
Both theſe are plagued for their ſinnes,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: FOr burning King of Edoms bones,
He, and his Princes ſhall be ſlaine,
GOds lawes, did Iud'and Iſr'el breake,
Their liues did cauſe them all to erre,
HE ſaith, becauſe they ſold the iuſt
Becauſe the father, and the ſonne
IN mine owne houſe, becauſe they much
Lying on clothes are laid to pledge,
KInd haue I alwayes bene to them,
I gaue them land of th'Amorites,
and brought theit power to nought.
And Nazarites? yet haue you done
MVch like a cart ſore preſs'd with ſheaues,
ſo I with you am preſs'd:

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: NOw heare what God againſt you ſaith,
Of all the families of the earth,
and lou'd you as my owne.
O Iſrael therefore thy great ſinnes,
None euill in a Citie 's done,
but God hath wrought it ſtill.
RIghtly to deale, they haue no skill,
houſes are fill d with ſpoiles;
Their foes therefore ſhall compaſſe them,
As when men pull from Lyons mouthes

two
• legs and halfe an eare.
THen will I viſite Iacobs houſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: Which crush the needy, God hath ſworne,
for this thing likes you well.
BRead was in all your Cities ſcant;
Yet would ye not returne to me,
CIties with raine, ſome I refreſht,
From towne to towne they water ſought
to drinke, but could find none.
With ſword and peſtilence I ſmote,
yet turn'd ye not to me.
EVen as a brand pluckt out o'th fire,
Yet would ye not returne to me,
FEare, and prepare to meet thy God,
All things he made, ſhewes men their thoughts,
HEare what God ſaith , ſeeke me and liue,
And ſpeakes vprightly him they doe
KNowne vnto me are your great ſinnes,
They take a bribe, they turne the poore
LOue ye, and euer ſeeke the good,
but hate the thing thats ill;
MOurning ſhall be in euery ſtreet,
And in all vineyards (ſaith the Lord)
for I that way will paſſe.
NO light, nor brightneſſe to be ſeene,
Woe then to them, that doe deſire
that day of God the Lord.
O Iſrael I deſpiſe and hate
I care not for your melodie,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: QVake for the woe that God prouides
for them that liue at reſt;
no griefe at all they take.
The Lord hath ſworne that he abhorres
TEn in one houſe if there remaine,
VNto our ſelues, by our owne ſtrength
But I will raiſe a nation ſtrong,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: AMos by praying to the Lord,
that they on them ſhould fall.
I ſayd (ô Lord) forgiue their ſinnes,
COntent he was then for to heare,
By which he ſhew'd, that Iſrael
DYe by the ſword Ieroboam ſhall,
And eke that Iſrael ſhall be led,
EAte thou thy bread in Iuda land,
At Bethel here, the Kings Chappell,
I charge thee not to teach.
FLocks did I feed (ſaid Amos then)
From them to preach to Iſrael,
GOd ſaith to thee, (who me forbids
Thy wife an whore: thou and all thine,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: HEre by a basket full of fruit,
And for oppreſſion of the poore,
IN that day all the Temple ſongs
Dead bodies caſt out here and there,
to ſee ſhall be moſt ſtrange.
KNow this all ye that pinch the poore,
LOnging to haue the ſabbaths gone,
that you may ſell your corne;
To plague you for this wickedneſſe,
Shall be as for an onely ſonne,
NO bread nor water ſhall they want,
But they ſhall wander farre and neare,
and ſhall not heare my word.
O How ſhall yong men in that day,
marke how they here are curſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: POſts of the doore, and lintels ſmite,
and cut them all i'th head;
To ſhew that not a man ſhall liue,
but all cut off and dead.
QVite ouerthrow the land will I,
Deſtroy the houſe of Iacob then,
RAiſe vp the ruines then will I,
Of Dauids houſe they there ſhall dwell
that on my name doe call.
SWeet wine ſhall all the mountaines drop,
Ile plant my people in their land,
A Rumor from the Lord is heard,
Let vs goe warre againſt Edom,
Although thou neſts among the ſtarres,
Ile bring thee to the ground.
CVt off for euer ſhalt thou be,
thou ſhould'ſt not haue them grieu'd
Nor cut off thoſe that did eſcape,
EVen like as thou haſt done to him,
ſo ſhall it be with thee:
Good Iacob ſhall poſſeſſe their Land,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A • Ioppa Ionas tooke a ſhip,
BVt God ſent out a mightie ſtorme,
wares were all caſt i'th deepe:
(The Maſter ſaid:) then caſt they lots,
that ſo it might be ſeene,
DIſtinctly for whoſe cauſe it was
The lot on Ionas then did light,
and he did bid them caſt
EVen him into the raging ſea,
That for my ſinne this ſtorme is ſent,
Who being caſt into the ſea,
GReat fiſh did ſwallow Ionah vp;
They vow, and pray, and Ionah lay
i'th fiſh three dayes and nights.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: HIs God did Ionah pray vnto,
out of the belly of fiſh;
The Lord then heard his wofull cry,
I Am caſt out of ſight (ſaid I)
KEeping me in on euery ſide,
my head is wrapt in weeds,
Within me when my ſoule did faint,
I call'd to mind thy deeds.
But I will ſacrifice to thee,
MY ſauing health is from the Lord,
to him Ile pay my vowes;
The fiſh at Gods commandement then

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: NOw Ionah is ſent the ſecond time,
For to repent in forty dayes,
OF this when King and people heard,
they all did faſt and pray;
The King put off his Royll Robes,
PRoclaiming that no man nor beaſt,
Should eate, or drinke, but ſtrongly cry,
and turne from all their ſinne.
QVaking for feare, who knowes (ſay they)
And turne from all his anger fierce,
and grant that we may liue.
God did repent him of the euill,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: SEe here how Ionah doth rep'ne
I knew ſo much (quoth he) before
TAke therefore now my life away,
What Ionah? doſt thou well to frett,
VNder a booth did Ionah ſit;
The Lord prepar'd a ſhrowding gourd,
A Worme this pleaſing gourd did ſmite,
An eaſt winde beat on Ionah's head,
which made him faint, and ſay,
BEtter it were for me to die,
Doeſt well to fret thus for the gourd?
COmpaſſion hadſt thou on the gourd,
for which thou tookſt no paine:
And would'ſt thou haue in Niniueh,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL people dwelling on the earth,
BEhold hee comes, and will tread downe
the earth with workes of wonder,
The mountaines then ſhall melt like wax,
CAuſe of all this is Iacobs ſinne
DOwne will I bring Samaria's pride,
Their Idols, which are harlots hires,
EVen likes the Dragons, and the Owles,
Ile waile and mourne for them:
A deadly wound to Iuda's come,
FOR Aphrah rowle thy ſelfe in duſt;
GIfts ſhalt thou giue to Moreſheth;
yet will I bring an heire:

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: HOuſes and fields they take away,
They miſchiefe muſe vpon their beds,
I Therefore haue deuis'd a plague,
from which they ſhall not flee:
KNow that no man hereafter ſhall
My word doth good to thoſe that haue
MY folke of late are riſen vp;
of poore haue made a prey:
The wiues are caſt out of their homes,
NO reſt therefore, here ſhall you finde:
Of ſtrong drinke and of wine to preach,
O Iacob I will gather thee,
as ſheepe in fold to ſlay,
Thy gates are broke, thou and thy king

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Who hate the good and loue the bad
QVietly ſhould you not beare rule,
But ye plucke off my peoples skinnes,
and fleſh from off their bones.
RObbing his thus, God will not heare
when they ſhall call and cry;
But hide his face, becauſe they dealt
SO will he deale with falſe Prophets,
Againſt the man that bribes them not,
THerefore ſhall their bright ſun goe downe,
Such Seers ſhall be ſore aſham'd,
VNt' Iſrael to declare their ſinne,
The Lord hath giuen me might and power,
Who Zion build with guiltleſſe blood,
BEcauſe your Iudges judge for bribes,
and Prieſts doe preach for hire;
And yet will ſay, we ſhall doe well,
the Lord great heapes will make.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: The mountaines and the houſe of God,
and folke ſhall flock thoſe waies.
EAch nation then ſhall ſay, let's goe
to th' mountaine of the Lord:
From Zion ſhall the law goe forth,
FOR God will teach vs there his wayes.
He ſhall among the nations iudge,
and plague them for their ſinne.
GReat plentie and peace the Church ſhall haue,
Vnder his figtree, and his vine;
HEr that halteth, and is caſt off,
I will aſſemble: God ſhall raigne
Thou ſhalt goe forth to Babylon,
Ariſe, and threſh, their gaine Ile giue

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: LOe here the birth of Chriſt our Lord,
How they ſhall ſmite this Iſraels iudge,
Yet out of thee Meſſiah comes
He ſhall bring peace; defend from foes,
and helpe his in their need.
OF Iacob they that ſhall remaine,
ſhall be as dew on graſſe:
And as young lyon among the Sheepe,
which ſpoyles where he doth paſſe.
PReuaile thou ſhalt againſt thy foes,
who ſhall be foil'd and ſlaine:
Their Cities ſack't, no witchcraft ſhall
QVite will I cut thine Idols off,
Thy handy works; in fury I.
SHew me (my people) if thou canſt,
I brought thee out of Egypt land,
what good thing didſt thou lacke?
THat ye may know my righteouſneſſe,
VNto the Lord what ſhall I giue
Will offerings pleaſe? a thouſand rammes,
And that thou humbly walke with God,
BEhold the rod which God appoints,
for them that get their treaſures
By bagges, and ballances of falſe waights,
CRuell and violent in their deeds,
Are rich and poore, the Lord therefore,
will ſmite them with the ſword.
DEſolate ſure I will thee make,
For Omri's lawes, and Ahabs wayes,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: EVen as the gleanings of the grapes,
Am I, (woe is my heart therefore)
FOr blood they all doe lye in wayt,
each man doth hunt his brother:
The Prince, the Iudge, the mighty men,
GIue truſt to none the beſt's too bad;
HOpe will I ſtill in God my Lord,
I know he will me heare:
For though I fall, yet ſhall I riſe,
O foes I doe not feare.
I Patiently will beare his rod,
Becauſe againſt him I haue ſinn'd,
I ſhall, my foes ſhall ſee

And be aſham'd when
• they behold
LEt all thy folke in Baſhan feed,
ſhall then be ſhew'd and told,
MOu'd and confounded at their might
Thy peoples ſinnes thou doſt forgiue,
and caſts them out of ſight.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: God is a God of dreadfull wrath,
BEhold he is full ſlow to wrath,
His way is in the whitlwinds fierce:
clouds are duſt of his feet.
CArmel doth languiſh at his looke:
the rocks he downe doth thruſt:
But he is good and kind to thoſe,
in him that put their truſt.
DArkneſſe ſhall ſtill purſue his foes:
thy bands yet ſhall be burſt:
Thine images I will cut off,
Thy graue Ile make i'th duft.
ESteeme the feet of him that brings,
(O Iudah) keepe thy feaſts and vowes,
Like flaming torches in the ſtreets,
HVzzab the Queene ſhall captiue be,
Take ye the ſpoyle of ſiluer, gold,
IN all their loynes much paine is felt,
I am againſt you ſaith the Lord,
Ile driue you from your places.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: thy wofull pl • gues now heare:
The ſouldier ſhakes his brandiſh'd ſword
Becauſe of all thy filthy ſinnes,
I will procure that nations ſhall,
NIniueh now is laid full low,
No was as populous as ſhe,
O King thy ſhepheards are a ſleepe,
Thy men diſperſt vpon the hils,
in whom thou put thy truſt.
PLagu'd for thy ſinne moſt grieuouſly
thou art with fire and ſword:
No man vnto thy deadly wounds,
BEhold the burden of the Lord,
And yet thou wilt not heare me cry,
nor ſaue vs out of thrall.
will I worke in your dayes;
EVen as the Eagles flie to eat;
ſo they ſhall come from farre:
FOR violence they all ſhall come,
They ſhall at Kings and Princes ſcoffe,
Thou for correction haſt them ſent:
HOld'ſt thou thy tongue at wickedneſſe?
or can thy pure eyes ſee
When ſinfull men deuour the iuſt,
IN nets, and drags of yron they catch.
To them with ioy they ſacrifice;

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: KEepe well my watch will I and ſee
He bade me write, and waite a while:
the iuſt ſhall liue by faith.
Their ſoules within them are not right;
MArke here the iudgements of the Lord
The bloody ſpoyling of the land,
OV • of the wals of that mans houſe,
Which he hath built with ſinfull gaine,
to ſet his neſt on hie.
PRoud builders of a towne with blood,
they are of God abho • d:
That people toyle and work i'th fire,
all this is from the Lord.
QVake for thy woes (who euer thou be)
That thou maiſt ſee his nakedneſſe;
REproach and ſhame ſhall thee befall:
The violence of thy furious foes,
to ſpoyle thee is at hand.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Reuiue thy worke in midſt of yeares,
O Lord make knowne the ſame.
His glorie couer'd heauen and earth,
The ſunne ſtood ſtill at thy command,
Who to deuour the needy poore
COmming vp with his mightie troupes,
to ſpoile vs all at once:
I quak't for feare, and rottenneſſe
DEſtroy'd though fruits and flocks ſhall be;
Yet in the Lord will I reioyce,
he is my ſtrength and ſtay.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL men and beaſts, all fiſh and fowle,
with plagues I meane to pay.
BAals remnants all, I will cut off,
CHemarims names, with all falſe Prieſts,
and them that ſweare by God,
And alſo by their Idols ſweare,
Gods day of vengeance is at hand;
Let all men hold their peace.
EVery one both King and Prince,
Who get their gaine by force and fraud,
FRom fiſh-gate is an houling heard
GOD will doe neither good nor ill;
And who are ſetled in their lees,
full ſore I make them ſmart.
The ſtranger shall drinke vp your wine,
I Will bring great diſſtreſſe on men
Their fleſh as dung, their blood as duſt,
KNow that thy ſiluer and thy gold
in no ſtead shall thee ſtand;
A ſpeedie riddance will he make
of all that dwell i'th land.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: LEſt yee be plagu'd, returne to God,
Seeke ye the Lord ye meeke on earth,
As Sodom ſalt-pits shall be made,
OF theſe, and more (for cruell pride)
And euery one shall worship him,
and for their God him take.
In it the fowles shall ly them downe,
and Owles shall make their neſts.
Her Prieſts and Prophets all pollute,
to God thy drew not neere.
SHameleſſe are all the wicked ſort,
To bring his iudgements ſtill to light,
THE other nations when I plagu'd,
and made their towers to fall:
I thought thereby they would mee feare;
VNtill I riſe vp to the prey,
Waite ye on me and I will turne
ALL then ſhall call vpon my name,
BEhold a remnant will I leaue,
Shall truſt in mee, ſhall holy be,
whoſe tongues no lyes ſhall ſpeake.
CAſt out are all thy enemies,
The Lord is in the midſt of thee;
thou ſhalt be plagu'd no more.
And thoſe that did you ſore afflict,
ſhall haue as ſore a fall.
and get you a noble name.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL yee that ſay, it is not time
Gods houſe to build as yet;
• t time for you (this lying waſt)
BEhold and ponder in your hearts,
much ſeed is ſowne i'th field,
• nd little reap't, meate, drinke, and cloath,
DEawes from the heauen, fruits from the earth,
• th wine, and oyle, cattell and corne,
EArn'd wages with great paine procur'd
In bagges with holes were put:
I blew vpon their goods brought home,
FOR this the Rulers, people, Prieſts
And in Gods houſe moſt cheerfully

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: That in reſpect of former houſe,
the glorie of this is leſſe.
For I am with you (ſaith the Lord)
Ile ſee you take no wrong.
I Once againe the heauens, the earth,
the land and ſeas will ſhake:
More glorious ſhall this laſt houſe be;
KNow of the Prieſts, if man vncleane
doe touch bread, wine, or oyle,
Shall they be cleane: the Prieſts replpy;
LIke ſuch a man, this people is
Their workes are all vncleane and naught;
MArke that your ſinnes haue hindred much
this worke you haue in hand;
And made me plague you fore, yet you
NOw marke the time ſince you began
this houſe of mine to build:
The fields and trees abundant ſtore
Thee as my ſignet I will make,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AS your forefathers did, doe nor;
Nor did repent and turne to me,
BVT tell me where your fathers are?
Did they not of your fathers all
COnfeſſe they did as much themſelues,
A man on red horſe riding then
DEclaring that the earth ſate ſtill,
The Angel prai'd that at the laſt,
FOure hornes I after did behold,
I ſaw to breake the horne
I (Saith the Lord) will be a wall
Ho, you that dwell in Babylon
ſet free your ſelues; come out.
KNow he that toucheth you doth touch
Ile ſpoyle your foes; in midſt of thee
And I will Salem chooſe againe,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: MArke here the high Prieſt Ioſuah
As brand out of the fire that's pluck't;
ſo he is through my loue.
O Take away his garments foule,
With change of raiment Ile him cloath,
PLace among theſe that ſtand here by,
I ſure will giue to thee,
If thou wilt walke in all my wayes,
QVite contemn'd of all the world
the BRANCH ſhall forth be brought.
REgard the STONE that I haue laid,
Will then remoue: from vnder vines

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: bowle, lampes, and pipes moſt fit;
Two Oliue trees were by the bowle
THE Lord workes not by armies ſtrong.
but by his ſpirit of might;
O Mountaine I will make thee plaine,
VNto this building men ſhall wiſh
As he did well begin the worke,
ſo ſhall he end it well.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: A Flying rowle here doe I ſee,
Which ſhall the theeues and ſwearers houſe
BEhold a woman in the midſt
The which is wickedneſſe, a weight
of lead is caſt on it.
An houſe to build and on her owne

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: DOwne from betweene two hils of braſſe
With horſes ſome red, black, and white,
They are the ſpirits of the Heauens,
FOrthwith the Angel ſpake to me,
Loe theſe that goe toward the North
GOe make thee Gold and ſiluer crownes,
Tell him the man whoſe name is BRANCH,
HE ſhall the holy temple build,
And he ſhall be a Prieſt alſo,
IN building of the temple they
Thus ſhall it be, if to the Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: KEepe faſts or no, what they ſhould doe,
they ſend to know and ſee:
In all your faſts you made (ſaith God)
LOe ſhould you not haue yeelded to
my words ſpoke early and late?
By former Prophets? when your land
ſee that you harme or hurt:
Againſt thy brother thinke no ill,
ſo much as in thy heart.
OF all theſe things they had no care,
they made their harts as ſtones:
And therefore from the Lord of hoaſts,
came wrath on all at once:
PRaying to me I would not heare,
they would not heare me call:
Among ſtrange nations for their ſinne,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: It ſhall a citie of truth be call'd,
that men that are full old
Shall dwell therein, boyes in the ſtreets
SAy it be maru'llous in mens eye,
ſhould it be ſo with mee?
Ile bring them home from countrie ſtrange,
THen let your hands be ſtrong, all ye
that here theſe words this day;
Great bleſſings both from heauen and earth
VNto your neighbours ſpeake the truth,
let peace bee in your gates;
Thinke ye no hurt; loue no falſe oath,
for all theſe thing God hates.
ALL ſolemne faſts, to chearefull feaſts,
Loue peace and truth therefore: to you
BEfore the Lord let vs goe pray;
They ſhall reioyce with Iewes to ioyne

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: CAſt out ſhall all the Gentiles bee;
thy King doth come to thee.
DOminion ſhall thy iuſt King haue
from ſea to th' vtmoſt lands;
He by his blood hath quite ſet free
EVen double will I giue to thee.
when I haue giuen thee power
FIlled ſhall they be with all good things,
for his he will them take:
Young men and maides with corne and wine

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: GOD giues his people graſſe i'th field,
he giues them ſhowers of raine;
Aske it of him, all Idols hate,
they are both vile and vaine.
IVda his houſe, as goodly horſe
of his in warre he makes:
From out of him the corner naile,
KNock downe their enemies in the mire,
LOrd, euen their Lord and God am I,
and I will heare their voyce;
Ile bring them to their place againe,
ME in farre countries ſhall they mind,
and I will bleſſe them all;
Th' Aſſyrian, and th' Egyptian pride,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: NAked O Lebanon ſhalt thou be
The fire the Firre trees eke ſhall burne:
OF howling ſhepheards voyce is heard,
Of Lyons Roaring, for the pride,
that they of right ſhould feed;
And ſay, the Lord be bleſt, for I
am rich by this my deed.
QVite pitileſſe I ſure will be
to th' dwellers in the land;
Ile them deliuer to the Kings
I will both watch and feed.
STaues two of beautie and bands I broke,
The wages I was valued at
THe foolish shepheard will not feed
Nor heale their hurts, but eate their fleſh,
VPon his arme and his right eye,
the ſword of God ſhall bee;
O Idoll ſhepheard God will take

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: A Cup of trembling will I make
A heauy ſtone to cruſh and cut
BEhold with madneſſe horſe and man,
in thoſe dayes will I ſmite:
In Salems ſtrength (the Lord of Hoſts)
COales of hot fire among the wood,
and like a torch Ile make
in thoſe dayes you ſhall ſee,
EVen as the Angell of the Lord,
To looke on him whom they haue pierc'd,
as one for his firſt borne.
FOr good Ioſiah as they mourn'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: which they haue thought or done.
HE alſo will cut, off the names,
IF any in the name of God
ſhall preach lyes in that day,
KNowne by their garments made of haire,
They ſhall not be; but then shall ſay,
Man hath me taught and trained vp,
ſince firſt I was a child.
MY ſhepheard that's my fellow ſmite,
The ſheepe shall then be ſcattered,
the ſmall ones I will take.
NOne in the land shall ſcape with life,
but third part of the ſame
I ſure will try as gold i'th fire,
they shall call on my name.
OF them thus clenſed I will ſay
And they shall ſay the Lord's my God
whom I will loue and feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: PLagu'd be by nations Salem ſhall,
Halfe of the townes ſhall captiues goe,
QVickly then will the Lord goe forth,
The Mount of Oliues shall be cleft,
ROyally then the Lord shall reigne,
And there ſhall be one God, one faith,
SOre plagues Iehouah then will ſend,
THe reſt of all the nations then,
ſhall goe vp yeare by yeare,
To keepe the feaſt of tabernacles,
who will not take the paine,
To worſhip there; vpon their land
and them ſhall fall no raine.
ANd if that Egypt goe not vp;
The plagues that light on other lands
BOth bells and bridles of the horſe,
A Canaanite in Gods owne houſe,
no more then ſhalt thou ſee.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Tender loue I haue you borne,
Louing good Iacob, I did hate
BVild vp againe will we the walls,
hee'le pull them downe as faſt:
COncerning me, if I your Lord
Where is the feare and honour which
you ought to yeeld to me?
yea worſe and worſe ye grow.
EVery blind thing, lame and ſick,
Would hee be pleaſ'd with it or thee
This you haue done will God regard,
or like ſuch men as yee?
GOD asketh who would ſhut the doores,
I like you not, nor will accept
HEathen Gentiles, both Eaſt and Weſt,
Pure offerings ſhall be giuen to me,
IT hath beene much prophan'd by you,
You wearie were, and ſnuft at me,
KNow hee's accurſt, that hath a male,
My name is dreadfull (ſaith the Lord)

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: LAy to your hearts this law of mine;
O Prieſts, elſe Ile your bleſſings curſe,
yea I haue curſt the ſame.
MY cou'nant made with Leui old,
was of long life and peace:
He fear'd my name; he kept my Law,
NO fraud was found within his lips,
all men the law ſhould ſeeke.
OVt of the way all yee are gone;
PArtiall in the Law yee were,
and haue not kept my waies:
I made you be deſpis'd therefore,
and vile in all your dayes.
Why breake we fathers cou'nant then,
And matcht with Daughters of ſtrange gods,
SEruant and maſter Ile cut off
And alſo him that in my houſe
THE cauſe of this you ſtill demand;
VNchaſtly haſt thou dealt and done
With whom thou mad'ſt a couenant,
her ſtill to loue and cheare.
AT firſt did God not make them one,
Although he had of ſpirit ſtore,
BE ſober therefore in your minds,
In ſaying, that man pleaſeth God,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: My meſſenger firſt will I ſend,
DAy of his comming who can bide,
for he ſhall purge with fire
The Leuites, that they may bring gifts
EVen as of old, the offerings then
FAlſe ſwearers alſo he will plague,
GOne quite away from my decrees
ye are, yet rob no more;
Ye aske wherein; I ſay by tithes
HAue any people rob'd their Gods?
For ye haue rob'd and ſpoyled me,
INto the ſtorehouſe bring the tithes,
that there, there may be meat,
And therewith proue me, ſaith the Lord
I then on you will poure,
My bleſſings, and I will rebuke
Lofty lewd words yet haue you ſpoke,
you aske what we did ſay?
That it is vaine to ſerue the Lord,
no gaine is got that way,
we count them bleſt to be;
They are aduanc'd that tempt the Lord,
NOw they that truly feared God,
The Lord did heare, a booke was writt
for thoſe that did him ſeeke.
O Then they ſhall my deare ſonnes be,
Then ye ſhall iudge betweene the bad:

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: PRoud perſons, and all wicked men,
As ſtubble in that fiery day,
QVietneſſe, peace and health ſhall be
to you that feare my name,
As duſt the wicked vnder foot,
ye ſhall tread downe with ſhame.
The ſtatutes and the iudgements all
SEnt shall Eliah be to you,
He fathers harts and ſonnes shall turne,
that ſo my curſe may ſtay.

div.p: A TRVE CHRISTIANS DAILY DELIGHT: Being The Summe of euery Chapter of the new Teſtament, ſet downe Alphabetically, in Engliſh Verſe, that the Scriptures we reade may be remembred, and the things forgotten more eaſily recalled.
By Simon Waſtel, ſometimes of Queenes Colledge in OXFORD, now Schoole-Maſter of the Free-Schoole in Northampton.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: BY ſtarre the Wiſemen guided are
They offer gifts; King Herod frets;
Ioſeph is ſore afraid, yet comes

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: DOwne comes the holy Ghoſt on Chriſt,
whom God from heauen doth grace:

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: and heales both all and ſome.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: FOr bleſſed men Chriſt theſe eſteemes:
The Candle; Salt; light of the world:
GIue eare and learne what murther is:

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: HEre Chriſt of prayer, of faſting, alme •
Of treaſure; mammon: bids that we
firſt heauen, then earth ſhould ſeeke.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: IVdge not; nor caſt pure things to dogs;
To enter: heare, and doe the world;
LEarne how Chriſt muſt be followed;
the ſea made calme and fine:
Two men of Deuills are diſpoſſeſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: MAtthew is from the Cuſtome call'd;
Dumbe Fiend caſt out, the blind haue ſight,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: OVt are the twelue Apoſtles ſent
Are charged what to doe, and ſhun;
All, that for feare of man ſhall flinch,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: QVickly Iohn Baptiſt ſends to Chriſt,
He calls him; and three Cities doth
REuealing to the poore theſe things,
And calls to him all burd'ned ſoules
The ſeekers of a ſigne are check't;

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: VIew here the Parable of ſeed,
A Parable o'th Pearle, and Net,
And how Chriſt of his Country-men

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: In Deſert he fiue thouſand feeds
with loaues and fiſh then brought.
CHriſt walkes to his vpon the Sea,
He heales the ſicke by garments hemme,
which was but toucht with hand.

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: Foure thouſand men and moe he feeds
EVil thoughts defile, and not mans food;
And multitudes of ſicke and lame,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: FOr ſigne the Sadduces doe call;

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: Learne in all ſcandalls how to deale
KIng calls his ſeruants to account:
by this thou well mayſt know
How oft to pardon; how he's plagu'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: Shewes who and when men marry may:
MArke yong man, rich, how hardly ſau'd;
Who ought forſakes to follow Chriſt

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: NOw are the Lab'rers call'd, and ſet
God is a debtor vnto none;
OF Mothers ſuite for her two Sonnes,

he giues two
• blind their ſight.

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: PVtting their cloathes vpon the Colt,
Out of the Temple Chapmen whips;
QVite put to ſilence are the Prieſts;
Vpon them all, becauſe they ſlew
The Lawyer anſwer'd: ſome are pos'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
lg.l: THeir doctrine follow, not their liues;
ANd ſignes before he comes to iudge;
As faithfull ſeruants we muſt watch

lg.head: Chapt. 25
lg.l: BRidegroome is met, ten Virgins marke;
The iudgment day; the ſheepe are bleſt,
the Goats caſt in hell fire.

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l:
Sits
• downe with twelue; by Iudas ſold,
DEnyde is he by Peter thrice,
An eare cut off: accus'd and ſcoff'd ;

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l: his wife puts him in minde:
He waſh't his hands: Iudas is hang'd;
is crown'd , and nayl'd toth' croſſe,
graue ſeal'd, they watch his coarſe.

lg.head: Chapt. 28
lg.l: GReat earth-quak ſeen, an Angel ſhewes
He bids them teach all his commands,
BY him are many perſons cur'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: CHriſt Matthew cals; and heales the ſick
who was by foure men borne:
He eates with ſinners; his defends

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: DOwne fal the fiends, whom he rebuk'd,
And many moe: then chooſeth twelue
ETernall plagues for them that ſaid
Who doe his will, by him are call'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: FOwles eat ſome ſeed; the meaning's told;
Some ſeed growes well; the muſtard ſeed,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: GReat Legions of Deuills caſt out;
He heales the womans bloody flux,

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: HAted is Chriſt euen of his owne;
he feeds with loaues and fiſh:
He giues them power ouer Deuills:
Iohns head brought in a diſh.
IVdgments are diuers of our Chriſt;
Chriſt walkes on ſea; who touch his hem,
are heal'd of all their paine.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: KEpt are mens precepts more then Gods;
A Deuill's caſt out; deafe doth heare,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: LEauen beware, with Ioanes he feeds;
They ſay he's Chriſt; exhorts to th'croſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: His death he doth foretell; caſts out
That giue no ſcandall to the iuſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: OF diuorcement; the babes are bleſt,
the rich are ſau'd full hard,
But not with God; who loſeth ought
They're taught to beare: his death's foretold,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: QVite dead is curſed fruitleſſe tree;
Doth purge the Temple, bids all his
REceiue ye ſhall, if ye beleeue,
By Iohns witneſſe, (not ſent from men)
they know not what to ſay.

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: STout Iewes caſt off, the Gentiles call'd;

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: VNknown to all when Chriſt ſhal come
he bids vs watch and pray:
A Stone ſhall not be vnthrowne downe;
how Chriſt out Iudge ſhall call.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: BY craft they ſeeke our Sauiours death,
CHriſt keeps his Supper, ſhews their flight

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: He faints in bearing of • is croſſe:
mock'd , crown'd with thornes is he.
EVen hang'd with theeues, reproacht of Iewes •
Ioſeph doth beg and bury him,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: FRighted full ſore , the Angells doe
That Chriſt is riſen from the dead;
the place he bids them ſee.
To the Apoſtles ſent to preach;

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Preface of Lukes Goſpell here,
BLeſt be the God of Iſrael
Both of Iohn Baptiſt, and of Chriſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: CHriſt here is borne; the world is taxt;
By Angels: for this bleſſing great,
DAyes eight once paſt he's circumciſed,
Of Simeon , and of Anna old,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Here Chriſt baptiz'd, is grac'd from heauen:

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: Beginnes to preach, caſts out a Deuill:

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: HEE preacheth out of Peters ſhip;
he makes them fiſh for men:
IN Leuies houſe with ſinners eates;
To bottles are the weake compar'd:
LEarne who are bleſt and curſt of Chriſt
Loue ye your foes: heare and obey,
leſt like an houſe ye fall.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: MOre faith in the Centurion found;
From death is rais'd the widowes ſonne;
the Iewes no meanes can win,
A friend he is to ſinners all,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: And of the Candle: Chriſt declares

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: QVickly ſends Chriſt th' Apoſtles forth:
Fiue thouſand fed: aske what men thinke,
REbuk't are they that ſought reuenge:
He heales a man of Lunacy:
SEE patterne of his patience mild:
His death foretold: ſome follow would,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: THe ſeuenty are ſent out to preach:

Wherein to
• ioy; for graces giuen
whom he ſhould loue in heart:

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: AS Iohn taught his, ſo teach thou vs:
all good things God will giue:
Dumb fiend caſt out; blaſphemers check't:
BVt ſigne of Ionas none ſhall be:

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: Of auarice, by that rich man
DEſire not wealth: Gods kingdome ſeeke:
Giue almes; attend ; looke for the croſſe;
ô take this time of grace.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: ENter in at the narrow gate;
The tree cut downe; the crooked heal'd;
growth where the Lord doth cheriſh.
FOwles build their neſts; the leauen'd meale;
O Salem thou my Prophets ſton'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: GOe ſit below; the dropſie heal'd;
Feaſt thou the poore; all worldly men
in heauen can haue no place.
Leſt they reuolt, and be like ſalt

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: IN heauen (when ſinners turne to God)
This taught by ſheepe, ſiluer, ſonne,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: KNow th' vniuſt Stewards dealings prais'd;
Rich Glutton damn'd; the poore mans ſoule

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: LEpers here ten are clens'd by Chriſts
The power of faith, they're curſt by Chriſt
MEn bound to God, Chriſts day deſir'd,
as in the time of Noe
So ſhall it be, ſome ſhall be ſafe,
and ſome ſhall taſt of woe.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: A Ruler would haue followed Chriſt,
OF children that were brought to Chriſt,
The blind reſtor'd, they heau'n ſhall haue

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: With triumph Chriſt to Salem rides,
QVite out o'th Temple Sellers driuen,
The Rulers ſought to take, his life,

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: REhearſe from whence Iohns baptiſme was,
they ſay none riſe from graue:
Beware of Scribes which make great ſhewes,

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: The ruine of the temple told:

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: Chriſt ſits at ſupper with the twelue,
ASſur'd is Peter of his faith;
BAthed he was in bloody ſweat,
Abus'd; that hee's the Sonne of God,
Prayes for his foes; two theeues with him;

lg.head: Chapt. 24
lg.l: EArly, euen in the dawning, came
Vnto the graue; two Angels tell
them that hee was not there.
FEarfull, they this to others tell,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AT firſt the Word with God, was God;
Iohn beares record: the Word made fleſh;

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: BEhold the water's turn'd to wine;
he of their faith doth doubt.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: CHriſt ſaith man muſt be borne againe;
His loue to th'world; who want true faith,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: to them he ſhewes his zeale:
Many men doe beleeue on him;

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: The Iewes repine for healing one
FOr this he anſwers, and reproues;
And ſhowes by Fathers witneſſe, and

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l:
GReat multitudes are fed by
• him.
they then would make him King:
But he departs, walkes on the ſea,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: KNow, ſhe was taken in the act,
but Chriſt doth ſet her free;
He ſaith he is the worlds great light,
and proues it true to be.
LEwd Scribes doe brag of Abrahams ſeed,
and ſay they're free each one:
from them that would him ſtone.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: MAn blind from's birth is cur'd by Chriſt,
They caſt him out; Chriſt him receiues;

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: NO ſtrangers voice will Chriſts ſheepe heare,
Who doth eſcape their bloody hands,
ON him a number did beleeue,
He proues (by wondrous works he wrought,)
that he's the Sonne of God.

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: But many Iewes beleeue on him,
QVarrelling ſtill they ſought his life;

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: the Greeks faine would him ſee;
Prieſts would he ſlaine ſhould be.
SOme chiefe Rulers in Chriſt beleeue,
The moſt are blind, Marie's excus'd;

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: THE feet of the Diſciples waſh'd:
He bade by his example learne,
That it was Iudas ſhould betray,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: A Place he goes for to prepare,
he's truth, the life, the way:
He loue requires, and that they ſhould
BEhold your prayers in my name,
A Comforter I will you ſend,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: Is by the Parable of Vine
DOubtleſſe they will deale ſo with you,
as they haue dealt with mee:
The Office of the holy Ghoſt;

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: which he to them doth make.
FEare not, what you my father aske
In me is peace; but in the world

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: O glorifie in heau'n both theſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: And Peter ſmites off Malchus eare:

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: KIng of the Iewes is ſcourg'd & crown'd:
Yet giues him to be crucifi'd,
LOts for his garment they doe caſt:
He being dead his ſide is peirc'd:

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: Yet both were ignorant as yet

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: NOw Chriſt appeares againe to his:
much fiſh drawne from the deepe:
He di • es with them: bids Peters thrice
to f • ed his lambs and ſheepe.
O • Peters death he doth foretell:
If all were writ, I thinke the world

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: Vntill the An. Mundi 4000. holy Ghoſt be giuen
BY power whereof they witneſſe muſt;

And of his ſecond
• comming, ſo
they bid them ſee their heart.
by lot they ghooſe and take.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: To heare them ſpeake what they had learn'd
EL •• e where to Peter 〈◊〉 doth defend,
proues Chriſt ran'd from the dead:
Knowne by hi • workes, not crucifi'd,
they liue in loue and peace:

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: GOd and his Son through faith doth heale
HE bids them by repentance ſeeke
Becauſe they did they wiſt nor what,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: IEwiſh Rulers full ſore are grieu'd
KIndred of high Prieſts now doe • meet
LOe then they charge Peter and Iohn
that they ſhould preach no more:
Church prayes, God heares, & them confirmes

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: in theſe too dea • ly bought:
Faith is encreaſt by wonders great
And bids them preach: they twice are ſau' •

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: OF preaching chiefly they haue care,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: He ſaith, God chooſe their forefathers,
and that they did him ſeeke
THeir murthering Chriſt be then repro • es
They ſtone him: he commends his ſoule
to God, and for them prayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: VNto his death Saul doth conſen • ,
Was there baptiz'd: and gifts of God
Then he with Iohn preaching the word,
CAnſt vnderſtand theſe things thou read'ſt?

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: DOwne Saul is ſtrucke: Apoſtle call'd,

He
• preacheth Chriſt: the Iewes lay wai •
EVen ſo the Greekes: but he eſcapes.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: muſt not be ſet at naught:
GOd to mens perſons doth not looke,
On them the holy Ghoſt doth fall,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: to them that did him blame
IN places where the word was ſpred,
a whole yeares ſpace was ſpent.

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: Peter he doth in Priſon caſt, An. Mundi 4010.
when Church for him did pray:
Proud Herod made a glorious ſpeech,
MArke how Gods Angel ſtrikes for pride:
After his death the word of God

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: NOw to the Gentiles theſe two goe:
one faine would heare of Chriſt:
OF Chriſt at Ant'och Paul doth preach,
They turne to th'Gentiles: all that were

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: RAis'd are diſſentions great in Church,

SHarpe ſtrife and great contention
• is

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: THE Spirit for Bids the Apoſtle here
VIle ſpirit caſt out, they both are whipt,
and they ſet free at laſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: COmming to Corinth, there he works:

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: ſome will not heare, nor turne,
The Iewes blaſpheme his doctrine pure,
FOr filthy gaine, by ſiluer Smith
by Towne Clarke it's appeas'd. An. Mundi 4020.
HEre are the Elders call'd, and charg'd
the flocke of God to feed:
Commends to God, of falſe teachers
he bids them take good heed.

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: IN Phillips houſe we did abide,
Paul feares no bands: at Salem he,
KNow Paul in danger of his life;
Hee's reſcu'd by the chiefe Captaine,
and ſpeakes to all the rout.

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: how he was turn'd and call'd:
MArke how they would haue ſcourged him,
but that he then did claime
The freedome of a Romane borne,

lg.head: Chapt. 23
