lg.l: NOw Paul doth plead, the high Prieſt bids
them ſmite him on the mouth:
God bids him ſtand for truth.
OF bloody purpoſe Paul to kill
And vnto Foelix ſends him then:
Out of his office then he goes;
SEE now how Feſtus to the King
And cleares him to haue nothing done

lg.head: Chapt. 26
lg.l: THe life hee led he ſhewes to th'King,
To be a Chriſtian: all men ſay,
nought was by him ill done.

lg.head: Chapt. 27
lg.l:
With tempeſt
• oſt, they ſhipwrackt
• are,
yet all come ſafe to land.
COmming to Rome, vnto the Iewes
Some were perſwaded; ſome were not;

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALl grace and peace to th' Saints at Rome
His Goſpell is •• ie (prayer of God,)
BY ſinne Gods wrath pro •• re 〈◊〉
Yet were they vaine, committing ſinnes

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: COndemning ſ •• ne no which you liue in,
if in the law they faile.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: EVery way are the Iewes prefer'd,
they haue not loſt their grace:

Both they and we haue
• ſinned all,
FOr by the law no fleſh is iuſt:
but all are iuſt by faith:
And yet the law is not made voyde,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: GOD did count Abram iuſt by faith,
By faith, he and his ſeed obtain'd
HE Father is of faithfull all;
by faith he doth vs take
As heires of life, and counts vs iuſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: IN him by faith we iuſtified,
We ioy in hope, he lou'd vs foes;
now friends he ſure will ſaue.
KNow that as Adams ſinne did bring

So Chriſt much more by
• righteouſneſſe

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: LIue not in ſinne, y' are dead thereto,

Obey not luſt, nor ſuffer
• ſinne
MAde free from ſin, your members yeeld
Who ſinne, muſt for their wages looke

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NO longer then a man doth liue,
the law hath power or might:
But we by Chriſt are dead to th' law,
O Say not then the law is ſinne,
But by the law I knew not ſinne,
it ſaid, Thou ſhalt not luſt.
PAſſing great ſins it doth reueale,
and makes me full of blame:
And grieu'd I am, becauſe that I
REgard the bleſſings of Gods childe,
all long to ſee him freed:
Nothing can ſeuer him from God;

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: The ſeed of Abraham for to ſaue;
THe Lord ſhewes loue to whom he will.
So dealeth he; it was foretold,
VNder the law they needs would liue,
they ſought not life by grace;
But ſtumbled at that ſtumbling ſtone;

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: ALL iuſt by faith, not by the law,
• ll that by faith take hold on him,
BY Preachers ſent, this faith is wrought
〈◊〉 his Iſrael knew, for all day long,
the Lord on them did call:

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: CAſt off they are not all from God,
• ome are elected, and there's hope
DEſpiſe them not, nor boaſt thy ſelfe,
His iudgements are paſt finding out:

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: EVen all Gods children muſt be mou'd
None of himſelfe muſt thinke too well,
FEruent in ſpirit let vs ſerue God;
thy foes feed when they call.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: The man that loues, fulfills the law,
owe nought but loue I ſay.
HIgh time it is now to awake ;
••• ſſ your ſinnes and put on Chriſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: In them; for that is prou'd ſinne,

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: KNow how the ſtrong muſt beard with we • ke
our ſelues we may not pleaſe:
Chriſt did not for his loue to all

He will come ſee them and
• deſires

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: MY helpers in Chriſt Ieſus greet:
of ſuch men take good heed
As cauſed diſſentions in the Church;
NOte and auoide them, they are ſuch;
The ſimple hearts they doe deceiue,
and them with faire words pleaſe.
ON your behalfe I doe reioyce,
Satan ſhall ſhortly be trod downe
to God be praiſe for aye.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: CHriſt, crucified to you I preach • ,
Yet with ſuch power as far doth paſſe

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: with milke I did you feed:
EVery man muſt looke what he builds;
we muſt keepe chaſt and pure.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: FAithfull muſt all Chriſts Stewards be,
all things are from the Lord:
GOds Kingdome's not in word, but power,
Him muſt they follow, he will come
with loue or rod to feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: HEe's cauſe of ſhame, and not of ioy,
KNow that your bodies members are
O'th holy Ghoſt, therefore you muſt

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: Know how and when to vſe the ſame,
MEn in that calling muſt abide
Keepe wedlocke band; why virgins life

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: NO meats to Idolls offered eate,

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: OF his freedome he doth intreat,
Paſtors to liue by Chriſts Goſpell,
our life is like a race.

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: QVite ignorant you ſhall not be,
Are types of ours; examples eke
Chriſts cup, and cup of Deuills to drinke,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: SEE Chriſt diſhonor'd when men pray
And when their women in the Church
THeir meetings were not for their good
BY it we ſtill reioyce in truth,
It neuer failes, but is prefer'd
EVen of their husbands let them learne,
• onfeſſe theſe are the lawes of God:

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: he proues that we muſt riſe,
GReat fruit to mankind comes thereby
How dead ariſe; how men aliue
at that day chang'd ſhall be.

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: HEE bids them ſuccour Salems Saints,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: AGainſt their troubles for the truth,
He calls to witneſſe how he preach'd

That not for lightneſſe he
• refrain'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: DEclaring why he did not come,
that did lament at his fall,
He praiſeth God for that ſucceſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: FAlſe teachers ( charging Paul with pride)
he ſhewes their faith and grace
As far as thoſe that preach of life,
and thoſe that damne to hell.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: HEre he declares how he had vs'd
And how all troubles he endur'd
IN euery place, did ſtill redound
To th' praiſe of Gods moſt glorious power,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: KNowing he hath an houſe in heauen,
He ſtriues to keepe his conſcience pure,
LIfe hauing once receiu'd from Chriſt,
to Chriſt he ſtriues to liue;
And by his preaching faith in Chriſt,
NO iuſt offence by him was giuen,
Of ſufferings he doth boldly ſpeake,
OF them the like loue he expects,
he bids them all to flee

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: to clenſe their ſoules with care,
To loue him as he loued them,
QVite for to put them out of doubt,
He ioy'd likewiſe for that great ioy

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: STirr'd vp they were franckly to giue
TH' example of our Sauiour Chriſt.
Which would redound to them thereby,
Who purpoſely were come for helpe

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: A Reaſon yeelded why he ſent
He ſtirs to bounty; who ſowes much
BY giuing almes vnto the poore;
And for the ſame great praiſe • yeeld

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: As baſe in perſon and preſence;
He will be found as ſtrong in word,
EVen euery one that reacheth out
Of vaunting pride them to reproue,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: FOrced he is to praiſe himſelfe,
The falſe Apoſtles more then him:
HEE hauing freely preach'd to them,
that he more paines did take,
In Churches care; in ſeruing Chriſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: blames them that made him boaſt;
LEſt he ſhould be too much puft vp;
Hee'l come to them in loue, yet feares
their ſinnes will make him ſad.

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: MArke how he threatneth not to ſpare
Who haue not faith, nor Chriſt in them,
NExt he exhorts to godly life;
He bids them all be of one mind;

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: A Wonder great it is to Paul,
• o ſoone from him, and his Goſpel,
BY him are men and Angels curſt,
CHriſts doctrine he of Chriſt did learne,
His deeds vncall'd, and what once call'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: DEclared is the time, and cauſe,
right hands to them were lent.
EVen to the face he doth reſiſt
in Chriſt we truſt moſt ſure:
All that are iuſtifi'd by Chriſt,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: your faith in Chriſt to leaue:
To hang vpon the law, from which
HE that hath faith is iuſtifi'd,
This proued is by reaſons ſtrong,
but curſt are all the reſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: IN bondage to the Law we were,
Till Chriſt did free vs from the Law,
KNowing then this, why turne ye backe
that loſt is all his paine.
LOue borne to him, and his to them,
He ſhewes that we are Abrams ſonnes,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: MAde free by Chriſt, in freedome ſtand,
But faith which worketh ſtill by loue,
NOw fleſhly workes are reckned vp,
The firſt condemnes, the ſecond makes

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: Reſtore him mildly, and one beare
PAul bids them vſe their teachers well,
he boaſts in croſſe of Chriſt.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: and thanks; Paul in this place
Doth treat of our ſelection; and
That they in Chriſt may haue their hope,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: DEad are we all in treſpaſſes
We quickened are, and rais'd with Chriſt,
EVen for good works he hath vs made;
by Chriſt we are brought neere:
We ſhould not walke as Gentiles doe:
as Saints we muſt him feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: To Paul, that Gentiles ſhould be ſau'd,
GReat grace was giuen to him, that he
to them the ſame might preach:
He praies that they may feele Chriſts loue

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: H • e now exhorts to vnity:
To put on Chriſts: to lye no more,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: KNow how he bids them walke in loue,
With all vncleanneſſe; and to ſhun
LEt men be wiſe; fill'd with the ſpirit;
To feare their husbands, let them learne
of Chriſt our Lord to loue.

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: MArke children how you honour muſt
Marke ſeruants, how with ſingle hearts,

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: NOte our warfare with fleſh and frends,
By compleat armour well put on;

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL Saints, which then at Philippi
With Biſhops and the Deacons there,
BEcauſe of their great fruits of faith,
He teſtifies his thankes to God,
He ſhewes what good the Goſpel had
DEclaring that his bonds at Rome
And how that ſtill he ready was
for Chriſt to liue or dye.
and Chriſts croſſe vp to take,
He ſaith it is Gods gift to them,
• s lights to th'world, that he thereby
HAuing no long time for to liue,
IN any caſe he warnes them here
KIndly to them, that he himſelfe
LOſſe yet and dung he counteth it,
• nd righteouſneſſe which is by faith,
MEntion he makes of many wants,
• et bids them all be of his mind,
NOt walking as the foes of Chriſt,
Whoſe end is hell: but bids them liue
in Chriſt the Lord to ſtand:
In him to ioy, and ioy againe
PVre things he bids them thinke vpon,
To pray and prayſe God, that his peace
He thankes them for their kindneſſe which
REioycing more for that good grace,
which God had in them wrought;
Then for the comforts and ſupplies
which pleas'd the Lord full well:
He ends with prayer, and ſalutes

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL grace and peace he prayeth for,
from God and Chriſts our Lord:
He thankes God for their faith and loue,
He prayeth for increaſe of grace,
CHriſt he doth truely here deſcribe
to be both God and man:
The Churches head, and ruling all,
DIuinely he doth ſtirre them vp,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: leſt they from Chriſt ſhould fall;
GReat heed he bids them take that they
Nor humane precepts taught by men,
HE from the worſhip of Angels,
(Which ſhadowes haue an end in Chriſt)

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: IN heauen he bids them all ſeeke Chriſt,
and on him ſet their heart:
KNowing Gods wrath doth daily fall
He bids them put off anger, wrath.
LYes alſo they muſt lay aſide,
and Chriſt they muſt put on,
MAn , wife and children here may learne
what vice to ſhun and fly:
Seruants muſt not their maſters ſerue,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: NOte that all thoſe that maſters be,
And muſt deale well with their ſeruants,
he bids them liue in loue.
O Let your ſpeech bee gracious,
from God to them be ſent.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: How he at all times thought on them,
when he on God did call.
BOth when he pray'd and prayſed God,
How well he was perſwaded of
From whom the word was publiſhed,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: And how that they receiu'd the ſame,
when it was preacht and taught.
and kept him from their ſight:

He long d to
• ſee them, for they were

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: the loue that he did beare
Paul alſo in their well doing
he hath to ſee their face.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: He bids them holy be and iuſt,
KIndly to liue in loue with all,
LAment and mourne for thoſe that dye,
Whom Chriſt will come to iudge and free

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: When wicked men ſhall not eſcape,
that they their ſoules may ſaue.
from all the ſhewes of ſinne:
He prayes they may be ſanctified

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL grace and peace from God and Chriſt,
And what he thought of their true faith,
BOund to prayſe God (he ſaith) he is
DAily he prayeth God for them,
Worthy of ſuch an high calling,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: In faith and truth, which they had learn'd,
That Chriſt ſhall not come, till there be
IN them what confidence he hath,
He • raues their prayers for himſelfe,
He doth command them in Gods name,
And charged, that who would not worke
they ſhould in no caſe eate.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A Charge was giuen to Timothy,
which he to mind did call.
BEſeeching him that he would charge
men that they would not preach
COunt that the law is paſſing good,
• t is not giuen to righteous men,
DVe thanks are yeelded vnto Chriſt
Who him that was a blaſphemer,
• nd caſt to Sathan , that they might
the Lords name learne to feare.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: FOr all men he exhorts to pray,
For Kings and Magiſtrates that ſway
GIuing this reaſon, that we may
He bids that woman be attir'd
HEE will not haue a woman teach,
For all the treatnings of Gods wrath,
IF ſhe continue in the faith,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: KNow here how Biſhops, and Deacons,
What kinde of wiues they ought to take,
LEarne why th'Apoſtle wrote theſe things,
It was that he might rule the Church
MArke here the bleſſed truth profeſt,
Chriſt God and man of Angells ſeene,
who now in heauen doth raigne.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: NOw doth the Spirit plainly ſpeake,
Men ſhall depart from Chriſtian faith,
Paul bids him in this place;

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: SEE here what rules muſt be obſeru'd
ſtarke dead in ſinne are prou'd.
THoſe Elders that rule well the Church,
But chiefly thoſe that preach the word
He wine, no water bids him drinke,
AVoyd and ſhunne all ſuch teachers,
To wholſome doctrine, but to ſtrife

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: From loue of money (root of euill)
To keepe theſe lawes without all ſpot,
And Timothy is charg'd to keepe

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL mercy, grace and peace from God,
On Timothy, for whom he prayes,
COncerning gifts giuen him of God,
Which he hath heard and learn'd from him,
and was both ſound and ſure.
EVen all that were in Aſia,
with Paul they would not ſtay.
HE bids him ſtriue to winne the crowne,
who ſtray'd out of the way
• e ſpeaketh her • but Gods ground-worke
KNowne are to him his holy ones,
but he that would be ſure,
• nd calleth on the name of Chriſt,
LEt luſts of youth he laid aſide,
• th meekeneſſe teach all Sathans ſlaues,
MEn ſhall in latter daies be proud,
OF ſuch deceiuers to take heed,
And ſaith that all muſt ſuffer wrong
in things taught him of old,
The profit which by Scripture comes,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: QVickly he bids him come to him,
That he be inſtant euery where
He maketh mention of his death,
SHewing that men with itching • ares,
But for him (hauing kept the faith)
a Crowne was laid vp ſure.
THat Demas had imbrac'd the world,
and would goe preach no more;
And that the Lord in that diſtreſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: To gouerne well the Church of God,
BEing for that end left in Cree • ,
That he in euery City ſhould
CHooſe blameleſſe Biſhops there hee muſt,
And ſtop the mouthes of thoſe, that at
the truth doe kicke and wince.
EVill beaſts, ſlow bellies, and lyars,
Titus he bids rebuke them, that
they might be brought to faith.
Which turne men from Gods holy word,
GOod men and pure, haue all things pure,
Whoſe mouthes profeſſe, whoſe workes deny,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: both how to teach and liue.
What precepts he to young and old,
INſtructing old men to be graue,
Old women muſt teach holy things
KEepers at home, chaſt and diſcreet,
Still ſhew themſelues, leſt Chriſts Goſpel
LIkewiſe yong men are bid to liue
And Titus muſt a patterne be
MAſters muſt be obey'd and pleas'd
NOte that Gods grace hath now appear'd,
That he might ſaue vs, and our ſoules

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: PAul here bids Titus to exhort,
and but them all in minde
and to be meeke and kinde.
QVicke, ready, forward eke to be
And that they ſhould in goodneſſe ſtill,
was in times paſt moſt vile,
SEruing his luſts, vntill Gods loue,
THat Chriſt he ſaith hath ſaued vs
Waſhing vs in his blood, and by
VPon vs richly which he ſhed,
that be our ſoules, might ſaue,
And iuſtifie vs by his grace,
ADuis'd is Titus this to teach,
Should carefully ſhew forth good works,
and in his feare ſhould liue.
BVt fooliſh queſtions all ſhould hate,
An hereticke twice warn'd they muſt
COndemned eu • n in his owne heart,
He bid, that Titus ſhould with ſpeed,
To doe ſome workes of curteſie,
Paul bids him take ſome paine.
EXhorting them to ſhew good workes,
He greets them all that faithfull be,
for grace and peace then prayes.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: and with Saint Paul did ſtay.
BY whom when he was wonne to Chriſt,
He proueth by ſtrong reaſons ſent

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: • ow by his Sonne the truth he hath
BY whom, and by his mighty word,
Who by himſelfe hath purg'd our ſinnes,
and all things vp doth beare.
To whom by men and Angells both,
DEclar'd he was vnto the world,
EVen as garment heauens waxe old,
They ſhall be chang'd, but Chriſt our Lord
FVll great heed therefore muſt we take
That we forget none of his words,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: GReat plagues they had that did deſpiſe
HE crowned is with glory great,
Through death he hath deſtroy'd the Deuill,
IN all things he was made like vs,
In no ſort tooke, that he to vs
KNowing well how to comfort them,
And for the ſinnes of Saints to make
LOe Moſes here to Chriſt compar'd,
As ſeruant to his maſter is)
MOre glory farre the houſe builder
• hen doth the houſe, or doth the ſonne
NOte that we are this houſe of Chriſt,
if that we ſhall hold faſt
• ur confidence and hope in him,
as long as life ſhall laſt.
OBſerue how he bids vs therefore
to heare his voyce to day,
• nd that no longer with hard hearts
•• ſt that in wrath he baniſh vs
QVickly take heed that there be not
• or if we keepe faith to the end,
we Chriſt, and heauen ſhall haue.
SOme when they heard obey'd him not,
but ſtill in ſinne did liue;
• o whom he ſware that he no reſt
at all to them would giue.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: THerefore let vs take heed, and feare,
They heard, but through their vnbeliefe,
VNto vs was the Goſpell preach'd,
For all the godly of the world,
WHich reſt who ſo hath entered,
from his owne worke hath ceaſt:
(As God from his) let vs then ſtriue
ASunder doth the word of God
And as a ſharpe two edged ſword,
ſinne in th' elect doth kill.
BEcauſe we haue a great High Prieſt,
Who feeles our wants, let's boldly goe

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: He ſhewes wherein they doe agree,
To offer gifts, that pardon ſo
EVen for his owne , and peoples ſinnes,
None but the call'd (as Aaron was)
FOr Chriſt did not this honour take,
an high Prieſt to be made:
But God, who ſaid, thou art my Sonne,
GOd ſaid thou art a Prieſt for euer,
To him that able was to ſaue;
who freed him from his feares.
HE though he were his deareſt Sonne.
Did learne obedience, and is he
who were ſo dull to heare:
That though they had beene long time taught,
yet ſtrong meat could not beare.
KNowledge they had but very ſmall.
of milke they ſtill had need;
• trong meat belonged not to ſuch,
on milke they ſtill did feed;

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: Of faith and of the ſacraments,
MOre forward he would haue them led,
he would not haue them faint:
• ut to be ſtedfaſt in the faith,
NOte here the danger of all thoſe,
PRaiſed and bleſſed is the earth,
that drinkes in ſtore of raine:
And for the dreſſer bringeth forth
hearbes, fruits, and ſtore of graine.
Is neer to curſing, muſt be burn'd
He ſtill rewards their workes of loue,
SEe here how God euen by himſelfe,
That he would bleſſe him wrondrouſly,
TO him, and to the heires of life,
Sith by his word, and oath he binds
WHereby we haue a refuge ſure,
Moſt firmely for to hold that hope
A Stedfaſt anchor of the ſoule
Where Chriſt is entred, to prepare

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: and Prieſt of God moſt high,
Is father Abraham bleſt, when he
COnſider how that he is ſaid
That he vnto the Sonne of God
of this High Prieſt I ſay,
the tithes of ſpoyles did pay.
EVen by commandement, by the law,
did pay them, and was bleſt:
Becauſe that he, when they two met,
GReater is this his Prieſthood then,
Then that of Leuies, or of that
HE (euen our Lord) of Iuda came
That either Iuda or his tribe
IT is a thing moſt euident,
That he was made Prieſt by an oath,
by whom we all draw neere.
KEeping the faith, to Gods owne throne
LIuing for euer, he is of power
to ſaue all thoſe from thrall,
That unto God doe come by him,
MOſt perfectly he doth them ſaue,
An holy harmleſſe Prieſt is he,

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: NOte well the ſumme of all that's ſaid;
we haue a Prieſt moſt high
That fits at Gods right hand in heauen,
as well as did high Prieſt.
PRieſts offer gifts euen ſo doth he;
which he from God did take.
place ſhould not haue beene ſought,
If that the firſt had faultleſſe beene,
As with their fathers, when he did
THey therin did not long perſiſt,
But in their minds hee'll put his lawes,
and write them in their hearts.
VNto them I will be their God,
and they my folks ſhall bee;
Thus ſaith the Lord, both great and ſmall
WIth mercy I will them behold,
to them I will be kinde,
I will blot out of minde.

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: A Large deſcription here is made
Which God taught Moſes, and which he
which made mens hearts more glad.
With name of holy places was
DIſpos'd and plac'd within the vaile
Was golden cenſer, and the Arke
EVen Aarons rod, and golden pot,
GOD bad the high Prieſt for to goe
Into the holy place of all,
HE for himſelfe, and peoples ſinnes
IN conſcience, for it did conſiſt
Which were commanded, till Chriſt came
KNow here that Chriſt is our high Prieſt
of good things yet to come,
Who not by blood of Goats nor Calues,
LEarne that that blood did outwardly
O how much more ſhall Chriſt his blood
MAking vs ſerue the liuing God,
and all dead workes to hate,
And entred hath the holyeſt place,
for he to heauen is gone.
ONce hath he offered vp himſelfe,
And ſhall againe come iudge his folke

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: POwer for to clenſe away our ſinnes
the law had none at all
QVite impoſſible a thing it is
By blood of Buls, or by the blood
of Goates or ſuch like things,
REdeem'd we are from death and hell
by Chriſts blood, which hee ſhed
Once for vs all, when he on croſſe
SO that he hath for euermore
THis doth the holy Ghoſt witneſſe,
My law I will write in their hearts,
their ſinnes thinke on no more.
VNto him then let vs draw neere
with hearts made pure by faith,
he will doe what he ſaith.
WEE willed are here to conſider
And vnto loue, and to good workes
ALL are exhorted thus to doe,
When Chriſt (to iudge the quicke and dead)
BVT if we ſhall ſinne willingly,
when we this truth haue knowne,
Wee haue no ſacrifice for ſinne,
but muſt in hell be throwne.
CHriſt who forſakes and doth deſpiſe,
And doth deſpiſe the ſpirit of grace,

the Lord will root
• him out.
DAyes that are paſt, he bids call backe,
How after light receiu'd they did
The ſpoyling of their goods, becauſe
Haue in the heauens with Chriſt our Lord,
HE alſo ſaith that we had need
That after we haue done his will,
IN meane time, for a little while
To come with ſpeed, without delay,
KNow that the iuſt ſhall liue by faith,
In him the Lord takes no delight,

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: LO faith is here defin'd to bee
Of things we hope for, not ſubject
MAny Elders had by their faith
By it of all things in this world,
NOte that by faith good Abel brought
And by it of his righteouſneſſe
OBſerue how Enoch by his faith
Before which time men did report,
PLeaſe God we cannot without faith
That he to all that ſeeke him right,
QVickly did Noe by faith prepare
Of things not ſeene, whereby he ſau'd
but when he did not know.
SO he by faith in promiſt land
• n tents, as Iſaac and Iacob,
THrough faith old Sarah ſtrength receiu'd
• nd was deliuered of a Child,
VP ſprang there one, from her wombe then,
So many as the ſtarrs and ſands
WIth eyes of faith all theſe did ſee,
but in that faith did dy.
AN heauenly country they ſought for,
God therefore would be call d their God,
BY faith, when God had Abraham tri'd,
That God could raiſe him up againe
COncerning things that were to come,
Of their departure; of his bones
hee bids they care ſhould take.
ENdu'd with faith, Moſes was hid
They ſaw he was a proper child,
Kings charge they did not feare.
FAith cauſed Moſes when as he
For to refuſe once to be call'd
GOds people he doth rather chooſe
• hen to enioy theſe ſinfull ioyes,
which laſt but for a while.
HEE the rebukes of Chriſt eſteem'd,
• Nuiſible God by faith he ſaw,
• ng Pharaohs rage hee feared not,
KNow that through faith the paſſouer,
• eſt hee that the firſt borne deſtroid
LEarne that by faith they paſſed through
the ſea, as by dry land;
Which when th' Egyptians ſought to doe,
were all drown'd out of hand.
MArke how the wals of Iericho
by faith did all fall downe,
When the ſeuen dayes had compaſſed
NOte how by faith Rahab is ſau'd,
and did not with them dye
That diſobey'd, when ſhe had vs'd
O What a number more there are,
time will not ſerue to tell;
PRophets alſo, which all through faith
Of weake, made ſtrong and valiant,
RAis'd were the women dead to life,
ſome rack'd would not be free;
That they might riſe againe to life,
SOme haue by mockings and ſcourgings,
And ſome by bonds and priſonment,
THey tempted were, ſlaine with the ſword,
In ſheepes and goats skins wandering,
The world not worthy of ſuch men,
All theſe through faith had good report,
A Better thing the Lord for vs
That they without vs ſhall not be

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: Let's caſt away all preſſing things,
and ſtriue to ſinne no more.
CHeerfully let vs run the race,
That's ſet before vs, and looke vp
for the ioy before him ſet
ENdure he did the vile ſpeeches
Which we muſt thinke on, leſt we ſhould
be weary and faint in mind.
〈◊〉 haue put out of your mind,
G • uen to you as to his ſonnes,
HEe doth chaſtiſe and ſcourge each one,
No ſon he hath but doth ſometime
As vn • o ſonnes God vnto you
KNow that if any doe not feele
That they are baſtards and no ſonnes,
LOuing kind parents we haue had,
And we did giue them reuerence,
MVch more our ſelues to him that is
NOte that they did but for few dayes,
Correct vs, but he for our good,
To be delightſome for the time
QVickly therefore lift vp your hands,
and knees that are ſo weake,
And ſee that ſtraight and ſteddy ſteps
RVn on ſtill in a godly courſe,
Be turned quite out of the way,
SEe that ye follow peace withall,
Without the which no man ſhall ſee,
TAke heed that no man from Gods grace
And let no fruit of bitterneſſe
As Eſau was, who his birthright
God did reiect him, and no place,
ALthough hee ſought the ſame with teares,
That ye are not come to the mount
which might be touch'd with hand.
To tempeſt, trumpets, ſound nor voice,
COncerning which, all they that heard,
And for to heare it ſo againe,
DEclaring that they in no caſe
So dreadfull were the ſights then ſeene
EVen to Mount Sion are ye come
FIrſt borne, which written are in heauen,
To Ieſus which for vs doth make
God Iudge of all, and to the ſoules
To ſprinkled blood which better ſpeakes
then that blood ſhed by Cain.
HEare therefore and deſpiſe him not,
Who Moſes words refus'd to heare,
Gods plagues did taſt and proue.
IF we refuſe and from Chriſts word
We ſhall not ſcape, for greater plagues
KNow that his voice did ſhake the earth,
That once againe he will it ſhake,
Of ſhaken things made with mens hands,
That cannot ſhaken be nor mou'd,
let's ſtriue ſuch grace to haue.
NOw ſo to ſerue the Lord, that we
With feare and reuerence, for God

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: O Let the loue of brothers deare
Be not forgetfull, to your power
in bonds, in griefe, and woe,
As if you were in bonds with them,
REad here how God hath honored,
And be content with that you haue,
THe Lord hath ſaid I will not faile,
So that we all may boldly ſay,
the Lord my part doth take.
VNto me what vaine man can doe
Chriſt is, and was, and will be ſtill,
BEware (ſaith he) and be not led
For it is good to haue our hearts
COunt ye that meates and legall rites
To them that haue beene exercis'd
DEſpiſing them, let vs to Chriſt
Fruit of our lips: let vs confeſſe
God is well pleas'd with ſuch offrings,
FReely obey all thoſe that haue,
Submit your ſelues, they for your ſoules
doe watch both day and night.
GIue an account for them they muſt
which that they may with ioy
Performe, and not with griefe of heart,
HE bids them here for him to pray,
His conſcience to be good, and ſtriues
IN earneſt ſort he them deſires
That vnto them with much more ſpeed,
KNow here the prayer made for them
That he would make them righteous,
He doth beſeech them to endure
He bids ſalute the Saints, and ſaith
BIdding them vnder croſſe of Chriſt
To aske for patience, and to pray
CRowned with glory ſuch ſhall be,
but yet let no man ſay,
That he is tempted of the Lord,
DEare brethren erre not (ſaith Saint Iames)
From him that with the word of truth,
EVery man be ſwift to heare,
They blamed are that heare, and then
Nor godly life; their godly ſhewes
are all both vile, and vaine.

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: GOod Chriſtians muſt not more regard
HE guilty is of all the law,
IN vaine it is to brag of faith
The Deuils beleeue there is a God,
KNow that the workes of Abraham,
Did ſhew that they were iuſtifi'd
by faith in Gods owne eyes.

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: Becauſe that we in many things
MAn muſt looke well vnto his tongue,
NO man can tame a wicked tongue,
with it men bleſſe and curſe:
Wild beaſts and ſerpents haue been tam'd,
PVre is Gods wiſdome from aboue

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: come from our luſts and pleaſures;
• Gainſt auarice we are to ſtriue,
RAſh iudgment here Saint Iames forbids,
He bids vs ſtill draw neere to God,
and he will be our guide.
SVbmit to God , reſiſt the Deuill,
In good ſucceſſe of worldly things,
THy life thou art vncertaine of,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: VEngeance the wicked rich may feare
Their ruſty ſiluer and their gold
A Loud the hire of labourers
Wantons, and who in pleaſures liue,
And (as the Prophets did and Iob)
In mirth to ſing and ſtill to pray
DIſtreſs'd, and ſicke, for th'Elders ſend,
that they for ſuch may p ay:
Their prayers much preuaile to driue
EElias prayed it might not raine,
He pray'd againe that it might raine,
FRom truth if any man hath ſtray'd,
That man ſhall hide a many ſinnes,
and ſaue a ſoule from death.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ATtend how Peter writes to th'Iewes,
Elect of God kept by his power,
BLeſſing the Lord, who of his loue
where they with Chriſt ſhould reigne.
COunting the tryall of their faith,
To be more precious then gold,
DEclaring that this grace by Chriſt,
was no ſtrange nor new thing,
Becauſe the Prophets did of old,
And to a new and godly life
FEaring for to offend the Lord
From which they were redeem'd by Chriſt,
who for their ſinnes was ſlaine.
that man is like a flower
Soone fading, but that Chriſts Goſpell

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: HEre Peter bids them lay aſide
And to deſire the word of God,
is their moſt ſu • e foundation:
A ſtumbling ſtone to rebels all
KNow, that we are his people deare,
Abſtaine from luſts, which to your ſoules
And that all Maſters ſhould be ſeru'd
MIlde Maſters if they be, or curſt,
And of our Sauiour Chriſt muſt learne
NO ill he did , yet ſuffered wrong,
He bare our ſinnes vpon the Croſſe,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: O Wiues come learne your duties here,
• hat you may winne the vncall'd to God
when they your grace ſhall ſee.
• Vt ye not on gay coſtly attire,
〈◊〉 men of knowledge with their wiues,
and all ill ſpeech to ſmother.
• e bids them feare no force of foes,
TO ſanctifie God in their hearts,
With meekeneſſe; of their faith and hope
VS, and our ſinnes he ſuffered for,
The loue of Chriſt to the old world,
which he long time did ſpare.
AT laſt the Arke by Noe was made,
which ſaues vs from our ſinne
• o whom all powers ſubiect are,

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: he bids them ceaſe to ſinne,
DAily to doe the will of God,
And raile when they behold, and ſee
in them ſo great a change.
He bids them haue among themſelues
FOr loue doth couer many ſinnes,
Giue as the Lord hath giuen to thee,
GRudge not, nor thinke it ſtrange (ſaith he)
But when ye ſuffer ought for Chriſt,
HAppy are they that are reuil'd,
But as a thiefe and murtherer
IVdgement doth now at Gods owne houſe
O then what ſhall become of them,
that ſtill liue in their ſinne.

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: KNow here the Paſtors duty is
the flocke of Chriſt to feed
Moſt willingly, and not as Lords,
LIkewiſe he bids the yonger ones
MOſt humbly ſtill ſubmit to God,
on him caſt all your care:
• atch, and be ſober; Sathan ſeekes
〈◊〉 mens ſoules to ſpoile and teare.

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL grace, and peace from Ieſus Chriſt,
• o all things for a godly life,
• to that faith which they in Chriſt
CHriſts knowledge they ſhall neuer la •••
they ſo make ſure and ſound.
bring theſe things to their thought,
in truth might all be brought.
ETernall Sonne of God who is,
By God, and his Apoſtles all,
FVll well (he ſaith) they all ſhall doe,
if that they take good heed
GReat light it is, and ſhineth bright,
Vntill the day and lightſome Starre

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: HE here fore-tells of falſe prophets,
as there had beene of old,
IN like ſort all their followers,
Nor the old world, when they for Noe,
Iuſt Lot preſeru'd whoſe heart was vext
LEft for examples are all theſe,
God knowes well how to ſaue his owne,
MEn walking after their owne luſts,
NO Angells (though full great in power)
But theſe bruit beaſts, ſpeake ill of things
O See how theſe ſeducers all,
if all ſuch men had beene:
• t had beene better, then like dogs,
and ſwine, to leaue them cleane.
That Chriſt ſhould come to iudge the world,
SVch doctrine; asking when comes he?
we ſee no change at all;
• ut Peter bids them all repent;
THE Lord (ſaith he) will ſurely come,
euen as a theefe in night:
When elements ſhall melt with heat,
and all be burnt vp quite.
• ut Peter bids them grow in grace,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: A True deſcription here is made
of Chriſt both God and man,
Who with the Father equall was
a true man for to be,
CHriſt hee declareth thus to vs,
To God the Father, and the Sonne,
and ſo full ioy might ſee.
DEclare he doth that God is light,
If we in ſinne and darkeneſſe walke,
then are we none of his.
So that the blood of Ieſus Chriſt
doth clenſe vs from all ſinne.
FAith this effects: but if wee ſay
that we no foule ſinne haue,
We haue no truth at all in vs,
to clenſe vs from all ſinne,
• f we acknowledge them to God,
HIs word in vs is not at all,
• f that we ſay we haue not ſinn'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: IN louing ſort he calls them babes,
That they no more ſhould liue in ſinne,
KNowne this he makes yet to vs all,
That if we ſinne, an Aduocate
we haue; euen Chriſt the iuſt.
LOuing vs, he is for our ſinnes
Yea for all faithfull in the world,
MAde ſure hereof we are hereby,
and that we know him right,
• f that we keepe his precepts pure,
and walke as in his ſight.
NOte him that ſaith he knoweth him,
His precepts, that man hath no truth,
but lyes what e'er he ſay.
OBſerue that he that keepes his word,
In him is perfect, he is in Chriſt;
we need not doubt nor dread.
PVrely (as Chriſt did) muſt he walke;
no ſinne his life muſt ſtaine;
That ſaith, that he is ioyn'd with Chriſt,
he here doth write and tell;
But that ſame word which they of old
REnew'd is now that old command,
Becauſe that both in Chriſt and vs
SIth that the darkneſſe now is paſt,
and light doth ſhine forth plaine;
He wils vs walke as ſonnes of light,
THat man that ſaith he is in light,
He is in ſinfull darkneſſe ſtill,
VNto his brother who is kinde,
and loues him with his heart;
He bides in light, and with no euill;
will ſuch a man take part.
AS for that man that brother hates,
He knoweth not whither he goes,
BEcauſe your ſinnes (for Chriſts name ſake)
O little babes, my children deare,
COme learne how that th' Apoſtle Iohn
To write to fathers, and to babes,
DEhorting from loue of the world,
• f any loue this world (he ſaith)
Gods loue is not in him.
EAch worldly thing (as luſt and pride)
But to the world, which with worlds luſts
FOr euer doth that man endure,
Hating all pride and ſtriuing ſtill
his luſts in him to kill.
GIuing them warning to take heed
He ſhewes why ſome did them forſake,
and would not with them bide.
HE ſhewes that he is Antichriſt
He bids them hold on in the truth,
IN Chriſt he bids vs all abide,
We may be bold and not aſham'd,
KNow, and admire the wondrous loue
The ſtile and title of his ſonnes
LEtting vs know, that for this cauſe
Nor know vs, for it knowes not him,
MAking vs now the Sonnes of God,
He ſaith, we ſhall be like to him,
and ſhall him ſee full cleare.
NO man that hath this hope in him,
but euen as Chriſt is pure,
So he doth purge himſelfe from ſinne,
Chriſt came to take away our ſinnes
PErfectly pure is Chriſt our Lord,
in him there is no ſinne,
He ſinneth not, who by true faith,
QVake ſinners. He that ſinne commits,
He knowes not Chriſt, and here Iohn ſaith.
that man is of the Deuill.
REvealed was the Son of God,
That he might ſinne deſtroy in his,
SO that in him that's borne of God,
no ſinne at all doth reigne,
THus are Gods children knowne from Devills,
Is not of God, nor who no loue
VNto you all, and vnto vs,
Came, that we ſhould loue one another,
AS cruell Cain we muſt not loue,
Becauſe his owne workes wicked were,
BY this we know that God from death
CVrſt manſlayer he here is call'd,
Who loues him not, abides in death,
DEare loue we haue perceiu'd from Chriſt,
who for vs ſhed his blood,
So ought we to lay downe our liues,
ESteeme him voyd of Chriſtian loue,
And ſees his brother ſtand in need,
and wil not giue him food.
FRom ſincere hearts, in deed and truth,
he bids vs ſhew our loue,
And not in word and tongue alone,
GOds Sons we know ourſelues to be,
And haue aſſurance in our hearts
HE bids vs here looke to our hear • ,
God (who is greater then our hearts)
IF that our hearts condemne vs not,
with God we may be bold
To aske and haue: no good thing he
doth from his ſons with hold.
KNow what this his commandement is;
it's faith in Chriſt to haue,
And that we one another loue,
LEarne that in him that keepes his Iawes,
And by that ſpirit giuen to vs,
we know this thing full well.

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: MArke here how Iohn bids not beleeue
Whether they be of God or no▪
NOte him to haue the ſpirit of God,
That Ieſus Chriſt is come in fleſh
OF Antichriſt this is the ſpirit,
and from the world doth ſpeake;
The world doth heare him, and they both
PErſwading them they are of God,
Iohn doth exhort them for to loue
QVite deſtitute he is of God
In this thing Gods loue did appeare
his Sonne that we might liue,
SO lou'd of God, we ought to loue
Which if we doe wee dwell in God,
and God in vs doth dwell.
THis thing we know, becauſe he hath
giuen vs his ſpirit of grace,
And ſent his ſonne to ſaue the world,
God dwels in him, and he in God,
ALL ſlauiſh feare true loue expels,
In that mans loue, that feareth ſo,
BVT we loue God, becauſe that he
did loue vs firſt of all.
Who ſaith he loues, and brother hates
COncluding that who loues not man,
Can neuer loue the liuing Lord

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: DEclaring here the fruits of faith,
He ſheweth what his office is,
EAch man that truely doth beleeue
Is borne of God, and loueth him
FIrſt, when we loue the liuing Lord,
and keepe his lawes with feare;
We know we loue the ſonnes of God,
GOds loue is this, that we doe keepe
his lawes, as in his ſight,
Which are not grieuous to Gods ſonnes,
HEE that is borne anew of God,
and this is done through faith.
IT's he that ouercomes the world,
That Ieſus is the ſonne of God,
KNow that this Chriſt by water came
Know that he came by blood alſo,
LEt vs not ſeparate theſe two,
Three from aboue, three in the earth,
MArke that the Father, Word, and Spirit
The ſpirit, water and the blood,
NOw if that wee mans witneſſe doe
Gods witneſſe greater is by much,
OBſerue Gods record, which is this,
Eternall life in Chriſt his ſonne,
Iohn ſaith he heares, and we our ſuits
QVickned by faith he bids vs pray

But for our
• brethrens ſinnes that they
we muſt not pray for all,
For ſinners that ſinne vnto death,
for ſuch we muſt not pray,
But who are borne anew of God,
THat we our ſelues are borne of God,
And that the world (by nature loſt)
VNto vs Ieſus Chriſt hath giuen
a minde to know his will,
This Chriſt is that ſame very God,
AGainſt this God, all Idols, and
From which th' Apoſtle bids them here

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: Reioycing that they walkt in truth,
BEſeeching her that ſhe would ſtill
Which ſhe from the beginning had
That he would haue her ſtill to walke
Is not as yet come in the fleſh,
EXhort he doth ſtill to perſiſt
That they a full reward may haue
FOR that man hath not God, that bides
Both God the Father and the Sonne
GOd ſpeed, you ſhall not ſay to him,
That brings you not this word of Chriſt,
HE that ſuch ſignes of fauour ſhewes,
as for to bid God ſpeed,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: euen as his ſoule did fare.
BEcauſe the bretheren ſaid he walkt
And that his ſonnes did ſo likewiſe,
DEclared was this loue of his,
Iohn bids him bring them on their way,
EVen for Chriſts name ſake they went forth,
Of Gentiles. Therefore of ſuch men
we ought full much to make.
GAjus is willed here to ſhun
the ill, and good t' imbrace,
Well doers are of God (he faith)
Of Truth it ſelfe, and of all Saints
To write of, but doth here refuſe
to write with inke and pen.
Shall ſpeake to him euen mouth to mouth,

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: ALL faithfull people which are call'd
Iude prayes that mercy peace, and loue
(Which once was giuen vnto the Saints)
CRept in (he ſaith) were certaine men
And now are kept in darkeſt chaines,
For our example are ſet forth,
HEE further checks ſuch drowſie drones
He durſt not vſe reuiling ſpeech,
KNowing it was the deuill that did
About the bodie of Moſes dead,
LEwdly theſe wretches ſpeake of things
And in the things they knew full well,
Who like to Korah and Balaam,
NOte how th' Apoſtle painteth out
Who feed themſelues, he ſaith they are
to clouds that haue no water,
Which bluſtring winds, with boiſtrous blaſts
Twice dead and pluck't vp by the rootes,
QVite void of grace as waues of ſcas
they are, which rage and roare,
For whom black darkneſſe is reſeru'd
Saying that Chriſt ſhould come to iudge
For all their curſt and cruell words,

Proud
• in their ſpeech; who men admire
VIle men, who were ſpoke of before,
Who ſhould be mockers; whom St. Iude
bids here to minde to call.
From other men, becauſe they haue
no ſpirit of grace at all.
BVt Iude bids them to edifie
Vntill the mercy of the Lord
in Chriſt, at laſt they proue.
COmpaſſion they muſt haue on ſome
Of ſinne, St. Iude bids them abhor,
Who can vphold, and them preſent
FInally Iude to God moſt wiſe;
Aſcribes all glory, power and might

lg.head: Chapt. 1
lg.l: Chriſt comes to iudge: all ſhall him ſee,

lg.head: Chapt. 2
lg.l: BEhold what Iohn to th' Angels writes
Th' Epheſian Church is greatly blam'd,

lg.head: Chapt. 3
lg.l: DEad Sardis is (though ſaid to liue)
They're bid repent; keepe what they heard,
EVen in that City ſome there were
Who worthy were to walke in white:
That God will ſpew her out, for ſhe

lg.head: Chapt. 4
lg.l: GOds throne, foure beaſts, ſeuen lamps he ſees
The Elders fall before the throne,

lg.head: Chapt. 5
lg.l: HEre opened is the ſealed booke,
by that Lamb which was ſlaine:
The Elders praiſe him, he by's blood

lg.head: Chapt. 6
lg.l: IN order opened are the ſeales:
Sun darke: ſtars fall: men call to rocks
to free them from their paine.

lg.head: Chapt. 7
lg.l: In Lambes blood are their white robes waſht:

lg.head: Chapt. 8
lg.l: LO Angels ſound their Trumpets ſeuen,
Great plagues doe follow: Chriſt perfumes

lg.head: Chapt. 9
lg.l: MArke helliſh ſmoake obſcures the Sunne:
Firſt woe is paſt: ſixt Angel ſounds,

lg.head: Chapt. 10
lg.l: NOw with the Booke (which Iohn muſt eat;
In belly bitter, ſweete in mouth:
an end of time he ſweares.

lg.head: Chapt. 11
lg.l: OF pow'r giu'n to two An. Mundi 4462 witneſſes:
Beaſt kils them and they lye
Vnburi'd , and yet riſe An. Mundi 5322. againe;

lg.head: Chapt. 12
lg.l: PAined in child-birth, An. Mundi 46. Dragon ſeeks
She flying is by him purſu'd:

lg.head: Chapt. 13
lg.l: QVelling Dragon here giues his power
A ſecond beaſt his Image makes; An. Mundi 4662.

lg.head: Chapt. 14
lg.l: REade how Chriſt on mount Sion ſtands
with his redeemed all, An. Mundi 5062
An Angel doth the Goſpell preach:
SOre plagues for all beaſt worſhippers,
who take his marke or name,
〈◊〉 head or hand, or print thereof,
THe harueſt of the world is here,
The Vintage, wine preſſe of his wrath

lg.head: Chapt. 15
lg.l: VNto the Lord the victors ſing:
The ſeuen laſt plagues; ſeuen vialls here,

lg.head: Chapt. 16
lg.l: ALL floods and fountaines feele theſe plagues
the earth, the ſeas, and ſu • :
The men that had the marke o'th Beaſt,
BEaſt ſeat is plagu'd, they all blaſpheme;
All they are bleſt that watchfull are,

lg.head: Chapt. 17
lg.l: COme ſee the purple ſcarlet Whore,
Drunke with the blood of martyr'd Saints
what by ſeuen heads are meant:
What by ten hornes: Lambs victory;

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: EVen as a cage of vncleane birds,
where ſp'rits, and fiends doe dwell,
and is falne downe to hell.

lg.head: Chapt. 18
lg.l: FLy out of her ( my people deare)
Lament for her, but all Gods Saints

lg.head: Chapt. 19
lg.l: and iudging the great Whore) An. Mundi 436 •
HEre is the mariage of the Lambe;
Iohn fals at th' Angels feet,
He him reproues; the fowles are call'd
the fleſh of Kings to eate.

lg.head: Chapt. 20
lg.l: INto the pit is Satan caſt;
That in this life riſe from their ſinne,
in heauen with Chriſt they reſt.
KNow Satan loos'd, Gog and Magog

The great
• Aſſize, the godly ſau'd,
they damn'd that did not well.

lg.head: Chapt. 21
lg.l: LOe both new heauen and earth appeare
nor Moone to giue her light.
MArke eke Chriſts Bride; all teares remou'd,
To Salem, Kings their riches bring,

lg.head: Chapt. 22
lg.l: NOte here the Riuer , Tree of life,
The Angell will not worſhipt be;

div.head: From the Creation of Adam to Seth were yeres 130

list.item:
From the birth of
Seth to Enos 105
Enos to Kenan 90
Kenan to Mahaleeel 70
Mahaleel to Iered 65
Jered to Chanoch 162 Gen. 5.
Chanoch to Methuſaleth 65
Methuſaleth to Lemech 187
Lemech to Noah 182
Noah to Shem 502
Shem to Arphaxad 100
Arphaxad to Shelach 35
Selach to Heber 30 Gen. 11.
Heber to Peleg 34
Peleg to Rehu 30
Rehu to Serug 31
Serug to Nachor 30
Nachor to Terach 29
Terach to Abram 130
Abram to Iſack 100 Gen. 21.
Jſack to Iacob 60 Gen. 25.
From the death of Iacob to the death of Ioſeph 53 Gen. 50.
From the death of Ioſeph to the birth of Moſes 60
From the birth of Moſes to the going forth of Aegypt 80 Exod. 7.10.
From the going forth of Aegypt to the building of the Tabernacle 1 Exo. 40.11.

div.head: The old mans A.B.C.

q.l: Ye Saints on earth be of good cheere,
The darts of Death ye need not feare.

div.l:
1 Cor. 15.55. 1 Theſ. 4.17. 1 Cor. 15.5. 2 Tim.
• .6. Heb. 9 • .27. Reu. 14.13. Phil. 1.23. Reu. 6.16. 1. Theſ. 4.14. Pet. 1.14. He • . 2.24.ACcountſt thou death a dreadfull thing,
which hath by Chriſt now leſt its ſting?
BE ſure, as Spring doth Winter blaſts;
ſo followes death, a life that laſts.
COffin this corps, and lay't in graue,
a glorious Riſing it ſhall haue.
DEbt due to God Phereby pay,
by dying at th' appointed day.
EXceeding welcome Death's to me,
all men muſt dye, no man is free.
FVll happy man that dyes in faith;
his wood works follow him, Chriſt faith.
GLad are the Saints diſſoul'd to be;
to liue with Chriſt his face to ſee.
HE well may quake and feare to dye,
that in his filthy ſinnes doth lye.
IN Death is gaine, it's gate of Life:
laſt night; a ſleepe; an end of ſtrife.
KNowne Gods Ambaſſador to be,
Death will I meet, I will not flee.
LOrd Paramount of death hath kill'd
Death by his death, and law fulfill'd.
MVſe oft vpon thy latter end,
the thoughts of death will make thee mend. An. Mundi Pſal. 90.12. Rom. 5.8. 2 Cor. 5.6. 1 Cor. 15.31. Eccleſ. 7 1. 1 Pet. 20. Heb. 9.27. 1 Cor. 15.26. Rom. 7.24.
NOught but Chriſts death doth ſin remoue
admite the greatnes of his loue.
OF earthly Pilgrims death from God,
makes vs poſſeſt of heauens abode.
P • ſſe not for death, I daily die,
why then doth death me terrifie?
QViet thy ſelfe, thy day of death,
excels that houre thou firſt tooke breath.
REceiuing but our due deſerts,
why then ſhold death afflict our harts?
SIth God from all eternity,
hath ſo decreed that all muſt dye.
THat deadly foe (laſt foe of all)
at laſt ſhall haue a deadly fall.
VAnquiſhed death I wiſh were nye,
It ends a Chriſtians miſery.

lg.l: BEfore my face the Picture hangs,
That dayly ſhould put me in mind
Of thoſe cold qual •• es and bitter pangs,
That ſhortly I am like to find.

l.hi: But yet alas, full little J
Doe thinke hereon that I muſt dye.

lg.l: I often looke vpon the face
Moſt vgly, griſly, bare, and thinne;
I often view the hollow place,
Where eyes and noſe had ſometimes bin:
I ſee the bones, a croſſe that lye,

l.hi: Yet little thinke that I muſt dye.

lg.l: That telleth me whereto I muſt:
I ſee the ſentence eke that ſayth,

l.hi: Remember man that thou art duſt.
But yet alas but ſeldome I
Doe thinke indeed that I muſt dye.

lg.l: An hearſe doth hang which doth me tell,
That I ere morning may be dead,
Though now I feele my ſelfe full well:

l.hi: But yet alas for all this I,
Haue little mind that J muſt die.

lg.l: The Gowne which I doe vſe to weare,
The knife wherwith I cut my meat,
And eke that old and ancient chaire,
Which is my onely vſuall ſeat,

l.hi: All theſe doe tell me I muſt dye,
And yet my life amend not I.

lg.l: My Anceſtors are turn'd to clay,
And many of my mates are gone,
And can I thinke to ſcape alone,

l.hi: No, no, J know that I muſt dye,
And yet my life amend not I.

lg.l: Not Salomon for all his wit,
Nor Sampſon though he were ſo ſtrong,
No King nor perſon euer yet
Could ſcape, but death layd him along:

l.hi: Wherefore J know that I muſt dye,
And yet my life amend not I.

lg.l: Though all the Eaſt did • ake to heare
And all the Weſt did likewiſe feare
To heare of Iulius Caeſars fame:

l.hi: Yet both by death in duſt doe lie,
Who then can ſcape, but he muſt dye.

lg.l: If none can ſcape Deaths dreadfull dart,
If rich and poore his becke obey,
If ſtrong, if wiſe, if all doe ſmart,
Then I to ſcape ſhall haue no way.

l.hi: O grant me grace, O God that I
My life may mend, ſith I muſt dye.

lg.l: LIke as the Damaske Roſe you ſee,
Or like the bloſſome on the tree,
Or like the daintie flower of May,
Or like the morning to the day,
Or like the Sunne; or like the ſhade,
Or like the Gourd which Ionas had.

l.hi: Euen ſuch is man, whoſe thred is ſpun,
Drawne out and cut, and ſo is done:
The Roſe withers, the bloſſome blaſteth,
The flower fades, the morning haſteth.
The Sun ſets, the ſhadow flies,
The Gourd conſumes, and man he dyes.

lg.l: Like to the Graffe thats newly ſprung,
Or like a tale thats new begun,
Or like the bird thats here to day,
Or like the pearled dew of May,
Or like an houre, or like a ſpan
Or like the ſinging of a Swan.

l.hi: Euen ſuch is man, who liues by breath,
Is here, now there, in life, and death:
The Graſſe withers, the tale is ended,
The bird is flowne, the dew's aſcended,
The houre is ſhort, the ſpan not long,
The Swan's neere death, mans life is done.

lg.l: Like to the bubble in the brooke,
Or, in a Glaſſe, much like a looke:
Or like a ſhuttle in Weauers hand,
Or like the writing on the ſand,
Or like a thought, or like a dreame,
Or like the glyding of the ſtreame:

l.hi: Euen ſuch is man, who liues by breath,
Is heere, now there, in life, and death.
The Bubble's cut, the looke's forgot,
The Shuttle's flung, the writing's blot:
The thought is paſt, the dreame is gone,
The water glides, mans life is done.

lg.l: Like to an Arrow from the Bow,
Or like ſwift courſe of watery flow,
Or like the time twixt flood and ebbe,
Or like the Spiders tender webbe;
Or like a race, or like a Gole,
Or like the dealing of a dole.

l.hi: Euen ſuch is man, whoſe britle ſtate
• s alwayes ſubiect vnto fate:
The Arrowe's ſhot, the flood ſoone ſpent,
The time no time, the webbe ſoone rent:
The race ſoone run, the Goale ſoone wonne,
The dole ſoone dealt, Mans life firſt done.

lg.l: Like to the lightning from the skie,
Or like a Poſt that quicke doth hie,
Or like a quauer in ſhort ſong,
Or like a Iourney three dayes long;
Or like the Snow when Summer's come,
Or like the Peare, or like the Plum.

l.hi: Euen ſuch is man, who heapes vp ſorrow,
Liues but this day and dyes to morrow
The Lightning's paſt, the Poſt muſt goe,
The Song is ſhort the Iourney's ſo,
The Peare doth rot, the Plum doth fall,
The Snow diſſolues, and ſo muſt all.
